DOC.HEAD: Mayor Elected By Drawing After Tied Election
DOC.TEXT: A judge drew the names of mayoral candidates out of a jar to settle a tied election on this popular vacation town on the island of Crete. But the loser says he'll appeal. Leftist leader Dimitris Kounenakis won Friday's drawing. ``I believe luck confirmed reality - that we were the better party,'' he said. Kounenakis and the conservative candidate, Giorgos Menagakis, each received 1,742 votes in October elections. A court in the city of Iraklion ruled that the election should be decided by lottery. The two candidates' names were put into a jar and drawn by a magistrate in the nearby town of Neapolis. Court sources said this was the first time a town's mayor was chosen in this way. But Kounenakis may still not be able to begin his four-year term on Jan. 1. ``The decision is unjust and wrong. We will appeal,'' his rival, Menagakis, told government television.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Emotionally Deny Wrongdoing in S&L Affair
LaserPhotos WX6-7-8-9-10
DOC.TEXT: The ``Keating Five'' senators struck emotional chords in defense of their integrity as the Senate Ethics Committee gave them their first chance to publicly respond to a special counsel's influence-peddling evidence against them. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., about to begin radiation therapy for prostate cancer, invoked the names of his son and sister Friday and said that with his career nearing an end, ``my cherished reputation'' was on the line in the savings and loan affair. `With all my heart and soul, I want to make very clear ... I engaged in no unethical conduct,'' the 76-year-old Cranston said. ``You know that I broke no law. You know that I broke no Senate rule. You know that I pocketed no money.'' Equally spirited declarations were offered by three of the other four senators: Republican John McCain of Arizona, and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. The fifth senator, Democrat Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, gets his chance to make an opening statement on Monday, when the panel holds its third day of hearings. After he speaks, committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett will begin presenting witnesses and offering evidence. Although no formal charges are pending against any of the five, the hearings center around their efforts on behalf of Charles J. Keating Jr., former owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan, whose bailout is expected to cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Keating was a major contributor to campaigns or causes of each senator, and each met with federal banking regulators when Keating was seeking waiver of investment limitations and other regulatory actions. ``John Glenn does not peddle influence, period,'' Glenn said when his turn came. ``At no time did I ask for special treatment for anyone,'' he said. ``At no time did I trade favors or perform actions in return for money. I acted honorably, I behaved honestly and I have neither tainted my own reputation nor tarnished the reputation of this body.'' Riegle, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, offered the longest personal defense - talking for an hour and a half without interruption about a case he compared to an ``exploding cigar going off in my face.'' ``I believe my conduct was absolutely proper,'' Riegle said. ``... It was ethical in every respect.'' McCain had received the easiest time Thursday when Bennett outlined evidence involving each. Bennett concluded he found no evidence of improper conduct by the Arizona Republican. McCain spoke briefly on his own behalf, then allowed his lawyer to make a point-by-point rebuttal. Later, McCain took telephone calls about the case from viewers live on the C-SPAN cable television network. ``I know I acted ethically and properly and in compliance with all applicable standards of conduct, including my own,'' McCain told the committee. Bennett concluded his opening description of evidence - a statement that ran more than seven hours over two days - by detailing Cranston's efforts on behalf of Keating. ``On approximately four separate occasions, Senator Cranston accepted or solicited several hundred thousand dollars from Mr. Keating'' for his campaigns or voter registration drives to which he was closely associated, Bennett said. ``Each of these four occasions was linked by time and circumstance to a request by Mr. Keating for assistance'' with federal bank regulators, Bennett said. In his response, Cranston said his efforts were not tied to Keating's money and that Bennett was suggesting an ethical standard had been violated where none existed. ``The fact is that the Senate does not have any rules like those Mr. Bennett seems to want,'' Cranston said. ``If it did, senators would be afraid to act on behalf of any constituents who have contributed or who may contribute in the future.'' To underscore his point, Cranston presented a list of all 100 senators and the staff members each has designated under Senate rules as authorized to solicit campaign contributions as well as conduct Senate business. ``If you decide that it's improper to take a lawful and proper action at any time in behalf of someone who has contributed legally and properly, then every senator, including every member of this committee, had better run for cover, because every senator has done it,' Cranston said. Cranston has said he will not run for re-election when his term is up in 1992, and he has given up his leadership post of Senate majority whip.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Drops Below 50 Percent in Poll
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's approval rating has dropped below the 50 percent mark for the first time in polling done for the Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press. Bush's approval rating in the Times Mirror poll slipped to 49 percent from 76 percent in August, 68 percent in September and 55 percent in October, the center said Friday. But those questioned still favored Bush, by a 50-37 percent margin, over New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, his most frequently mentioned potential 1992 Democratic rival. In another finding, little more than one-third of the people who didn't vote this year said they wish they had and about one-tenth said they were glad they didn't. Pollsters asked people whether they had the opportunity to vote on Nov. 6 or whether something came up that kept them from voting. Eighty-two percent said they voted and 8 percent said they didn't. Of those who didn't vote, 36 percent said they wished they had and 13 percent said they were glad they didn't. Forty-five percent said they had mixed feelings. The pollsters did not ask why. The polling group also asked voters to grade the press on its coverage of this year's political campaign. The average grade was a C-plus, compared with a D-plus average in a poll after the 1988 presidential campaign. The Democratic Party also improved its grade, moving up from an average of C-minus in 1988 to a C. Republicans averaged a C both times. The results were based on telephone interviews conducted among 1,208 adults, 18 or older, from Nov. 8 to 11. The error attributable to sampling and other random effects is plus or minus 3 percentage points, the polling group said. Times-Mirror is a news media organization whose publications include the Los Angeles Times.

DOC.HEAD: News Service Employees Accept Temporary 35 Percent Cut
DOC.TEXT: Union employees of United Press International are giving the financially distressed news service ``time to find a new home'' by accepting a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days while the company seeks a buyer. Members of the Wire Service Guild, in two weeks of balloting, voted by a 62 percent majority to accept the salary reduction. Ballots were counted Friday at WSG headquarters in New York. ``Given the extremely tough circumstances in which we are working, this is a courageous and responsible act by journalists who want to support each other and who hope to see UPI restored,'' said Pieter VanBennekom, executive vice president of the Washington-based news service. ``This gives us the time to find a new home for UPI,'' he said. Kevin Keane, WSG president, said, ``Through the vote our members demonstrated a willingness to make another huge sacrifice to keep UPI alive.'' The weekly salary of a top-scale newsperson at UPI will be reduced from $690 to $448. A first-year newsperson will be paid $234 a week, down from $360. The pay reductions take effect today and will end Feb. 14. UPI already had cut management salaries by the same percentage for 90 days. VanBennekom said more than a dozen organizations had expressed preliminary interest in purchasing all or part of the 83-year-old news service since plans for its sale were announced. He did not identify the organizations. At a meeting with the Washington staff after the vote, VanBennekom said UPI has been losing as much as $2.5 million a month, but has made some progress in reducing its losses, according to a UPI staffer. The staffer, who took notes during the meeting, spoke on the condition he not be identified. He quoted VanBennekom as saying, ``A sale must be accomplished by the end of January. We are confident we can affect a sale before the end of January.'' The executive vice president was also quoted as saying that at least one written letter of intent had been received for purchase of the company. WSG Secretary-Treasurer Chris Dahl said about 310 UPI employees are members of the guild. He said the total work force covered by the union contract, counting those who are not members, is close to 400. The numbers voting on each side were not disclosed. The news service, founded in 1907 as United Press, has changed ownership three times in eight years. The present owner is Infotechnology Inc., parent firm to a number of high-tech ventures. Infotechnology announced this month it hopes to sell its companies by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Rape Case of Interior Secretary's Son Sent to Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A woman says a shotgun-toting Robert Jeffrey Lujan, son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, loomed over her in the nude, talked endlessly and forced her to go to a hallway outside his parents' apartment before he raped her in her own bed. General District Court Judge Robert T.S. Colby on Friday ordered the 28-year-old Lujan, who has previous convictions for cocaine possession and drunken driving, held without bond on a rape charge while a grand jury considers the case. Defense attorney Robert Stanley Powell told reporters he expects the grand jury to indict his client Dec. 3, even though ``this was a consentual relationship between two people who lived in the same building and knew one another.'' But the alleged victim, the sole witness at Lujan's preliminary hearing, said the first time she ever saw the defendant was when she awakened at 4:41 a.m. Sunday, not long after she had arrived home from an evening of partying. The woman, 48, said she saw a man with a shotgun looming over her bed. ``As time went by, I realized he had no clothes on,'' she said. Powell repeatedly questioned the woman's sobriety that night. She acknowledged having at least two glasses of wine at a party she attended for several hours, then at least two Kier Royales - a mix of champagne and French liqueur - in a 2 a.m. visit to a Washington nightspot. By her account, Lujan told her he picked the locks to her apartment with a hairpin and entered it to hide from building security, for reasons he never explained. ``I assumed it had something to do with drugs,'' she said. ``He said he wanted to hide, but found me attractive and wanted to do more.'' The woman said they talked for about two hours, during which Lujan alternately handled the shotgun or left it in a corner of the room. Then Lujan, after donning his jeans and allowing her to put a robe over her nightgown, ordered her to accompany him up the stairwell to the eighth floor. There, he declared ``This is so stupid, I shouldn't be doing this. My boss is going to kill me,'' and took her back to her own apartment, she said. Lujan, a house painter, lives with his parents on the eighth floor of the apartment building in this Washington suburb. Upon returning to her efficiency apartment on the third floor, the woman said, Lujan repeatedly asked her to take her clothes off, finally demanding that she do so. When she complied, he performed oral sex on her and then forced her into intercourse, she said. She said Lujan left the apartment about 9 a.m., after which she went to the front desk and summoned police. Lujan, who was arrested Wednesday after police scoured the building with a composite sketch based on her description, sat impassively throughout the hour-long hearing, as his mother and two sisters looked on. Defense attorney Powell insisted the woman had known Lujan and had invited him to her apartment after a chance encounter in the elevator after each had returned separately from a night out drinking. But she denied that account. Powell acknowledged that police had found a shotgun in the Lujan apartment but disputed that the young man had ever carried it during his time with the woman. ``I would suggest to the court that a lot of these things happened in her mind,'' he said. But Colby refused the defense attorney's request for bond and release of his client to the custody of a local minister who operates a halfway house. A $2,000 bond was revoked a day earlier. Lujan was imprisoned for several months in 1983 for possession of cocaine and use of a telephone in a drug transaction. He served a one-year term in 1987 for drunken driving and driving on a suspended license.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Chief Says Social Security Will Survive Intact for Affluent
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is considering a new assault on government spending by trimming government benefits paid to affluent Americans, but the White House budget chief wants to make clear that Social Security will not be touched. Richard Darman, director of the president's Office of Management and Budget, said benefit reductions going to well-to-do Americans in a variety of programs would be seriously reviewed as the administration prepares its fiscal 1992 budget request to Congress. He specifically mentioned subsidy payments to farmers and the giant Medicare program that provides health care for the elderly, two areas where the administration has tried in the past to achieve cost savings. But Darman branded as inaccurate reports quoting unnamed administration officials as saying that the administration was also looking for savings in the Social Security program. He said the administration had no intention of ``tinkering with Social Security. We are not doing that as part of this review, but everything else is certainly in the equation.'' In remarks Friday before the Council for Excellence in Government, Darman said the administration was seriously studying proposals to trim government benefits paid to affluent Americans. He suggested that part of the savings could be used to boost payments made to lower income individuals. ``There are lots of ways you can do that and it varies from program to program,'' Darman said. The administration in the past has tried to make higher income individuals pay more for their Medicare health insurance and to reduce subsidy payments received by high-income farmers. However, those proposals have been defeated in Congress and Darman acknowledged in his speech that it was difficult to attack benefits received by the middle class because of their political might. But he said the administration may well renew the effort in next year's budget because of added leverage it received in the deficit-cutting bill approved by Congress last month. That measure, which calls for $492 billion in savings over the next five years, included new ``pay-as-you-go'' enforcement mechanisms that Darman said should make it easier for the president to block unwanted spending. ``We may be able to break free, somewhat, from the consume-now, promise-to-pay-later approach that characterized the '70s and '80s,'' Darman said. But even with the new deficit-cutting procedures in place, Darman predicted that the deficit for the current fiscal year would hit a record somewhere between $250 billion and $300 billion. The deficit for the 1990 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, was $220.4 billion, just short of the all-time high of $221.1 billion set in 1986. Darman blamed the higher red ink on a variety of factors, including the weakening economy and the rising cost of the savings and loan bailout. The economy's weakness was brought home to the White House this week in a seriesof meetings President Bush held with his own advisers and a group of 20 top business executives brought in to brief the president. Darman, who attended the sessions, said the consensus among both the president's advisers and the executives was that the economy was in a downturn, a word Bush himself used in a television interview Thursday. Amoco Corp. Chairman Dick Marrow told reporters, ``There is a general feeling that we are either in a recession or very close.'' Darman said the purpose of the hastily scheduled meetings Bush has held on the economy was to develop a strategy for cushioning the shock of any downturn. He said the president will probably make recommendations for stimulating economic growth in his budget, due to be submitted to Congress in February, but that no decisions were likely before late December ``at the earliest.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Opposition Groups Win New Friends, But Still Disunited
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, new doors have opened in the West for some of Saddam Hussein's opponents, but these exiles remain politically divided and scattered around the world. Opposition leaders, some of whom have opposed the Iraqi president for more than 20 years, say governments in Washington, London and Paris are finally starting to pay attention to them. ``A few months ago I couldn't hustle up a cup of coffee in the U.S. State Department,'' said Saad Jabr, leader of the New Umma (Nation) Party, a liberal democratic group. ``Now I am invited to lunch and they want to hear what we have to say.'' Jabr met senior administration officials during a visit to Washington in August, and the Washington Post published an interview with him. ``Jabr and his group are well known to people here and they have no qualms about meeting with him,'' State Department spokeswoman Diane Salisbury said. A Foreign Office spokesman in London said there had been regular contact with some Iraqi opposition groups before the Aug. 2 invasion. The number of groups seeking meetings has risen since the invasion and the Foreign Office is happy to hear their views, said the spokesman. Jabr estimates about 200,000 Iraqis are in Britain. Most exiles keep a low profile, fearing persecution by Saddam's secret services. Saddam was a leader of a coup that took power in Iraq in 1968; he has violently crushed dissent since becoming the country's top leader in 1979. Hoshyar Zebari of the Kurdish Democratic Party said Iraqi Kurds were well-received in September when they met in Paris with a deputy of French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. ``Belatedly, Western governments are recognizing Saddam has to be moved, and they are encouraging opposition groups inside and outside Iraq to stand up and be counted,'' said Middle East analyst Heino Kopietz, formerly of the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London. But the opposition movement remains badly divided. The broad ideological sweep of the opposition groups, some of them historical enemies, makes a united front difficult. They have also been weakened by Saddam's purges. Kopietz said the Iraqi resistance has suffered from the lack of a charismatic leader, and he doesn't see these groups leading Saddam's overthrow. More than two months of talks among 25 opposition groups in the Syrian capital, Damascus, have produced agreement only on the necessity of toppling Saddam, not on what comes afterward. Communists and Moslems have fallen out over the wording of communiques: the Moslems want to include references to Allah; the communists refuse. Iraqi opposition groups fall loosely into four camps: the democrats, who have tended to congregate in London; Arab nationalists and dissidents from Iraq's ruling Ba'athist Party who consider Damascus their home; Shia Islamic groups centered in Tehran, and the Kurds, a long-oppressed minority fighting for autonomy against Baghdad. Kurdish political parties have representatives in many countries. Attempts to unite have foundered on differences of allegiance and approach. Jabr's New Umma Party is not taking part in the Damascus talks because it believes the venue is not neutral, and that Syria's President Hafez Assad may seek to exploit the crisis to lead the Arab world. Jabr is also suspicious of the Iranian mullahs' influence on Iraq's Muslim opposition groups. ``When the Mullahs say `Jump,' the Muslims say `How high?''' he said. The opposition all want Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait, but Arab nationalists and others demand the simultaneous withdrawal of the U.S.-led force from the Persian Gulf. Some democratic groups want the United States to help democratize the region after Kuwait is freed. The opposition is also divided on whether a viable opposition exists inside Iraq. ``Don't let anyone tell you there is an organized opposition inside Iraq,'' said Jabr. ``Ninety percent of people inside Iraq oppose Saddam, but after 22 years of terror it is a silent opposition.'' But Zebari said the Kurd's internal front, at least, is still active. ``There are several thousand guerrilla fighters inside the country who are fighting on and thousands more in Iran and Turkey,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Chemical Arms Bill, Signs Numerous Other Measures
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in a last-minute flurry of domestic business before heading to Europe, vetoed legislation to thwart chemical weapons proliferation, barred U.S. mineral activity in Antarctica and acted on a spate of other bills passed by Congress. The president vetoed a measure designed to crack down on countries and companies that traffic in chemical arms, but at the same time he issued an executive order he said would achieve the same goals. The order imposes new export controls on chemical and biological weapons and provides sanctions against violators. In a statement, Bush said his major objection to the legislation ``is not the requirement of sanctions, but the rigid way in which they are imposed.'' ``The mandatory imposition of unilateral sanctions as provided in this bill would harm U.S. economic interest and provoke friendly countries who are essential to our efforts to resist Iraqi aggression,'' he said. The bill Congress sent Bush also would have forbidden trade with Cuba by overseas subsidiaries of U.S. companies, a provision that the State Department opposed. Bush directed sanctions against foreign countries and their citizens who use chemical or biological weapons or ``are making substantial preparations to use such weapons'' or have deeloped or stockpiled such weapons in violation of international law. The sanctions include cutting off U.S. foreign aid and arms exports, blocking loans to the country from international lending organizations and restricting U.S. imports from the country. The president signed the Antarctic Protection Act of 1990 and eight other environmental measures. The new law bans indefinitely U.S. mineral activities in Antarctica until Congress approves a yet-to-be-negotiated multinational minerals pact for the frozen continent. Environmental groups want Bush to commit the United States to join France, Australia and New Zealand in pushing to make Antarctica a permanently protected refuge. U.S. officials oppose the permanent ban, urging instead an international compact for a limited moratorium on oil drilling and other minerals development. Environmentalists contend that the indefinite ban merely gives industry time to prepare the technology for eventual development and mining. Bush also signed measures to: -Establish the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, designating 2,600 square miles off the keys as a national marine sanctuary. -Establish national wildlife refuges in the 18,000-acre Bayou Cocodrie in Louisiana and the 7,500-acre Walkill River area of New Jersey, and finance additional marine research programs and stepped-up enforcement by the Environmental Protection Agency. -Designate 83,100 acres in southern Nevada's Mojave Desert as the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation area. -Nearly triple the size of the Coastal Barrier Resource System by adding 818,000 acres along the Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico and Great Lakes coasts. The measure also limits federal funds for development within the coastal barrier areas and requires that any federal property in the coastal barrier regions be transferred to the system. -Provide grants and training to teachers for environmental education and create an office of environmental education at the Environmental Protection Agency. -Fund research on the global warming trend. The administration, bucking many of its allies, contends there is insufficient scientific data to confirm that the Earth is slowly warming due to gaseous emissions. Rather than committing itself to a reduction of those gases, the administration is putting more money into research. -Assist in the cleanup of toxic pollution in the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain, between New York and Vermont. -Upgrade airport security and develop guidelines to warn passengers of terrorist threats. -Spend $287 million for the National Community Service Act to encourage community service and volunteerism. -Enact the Excellence in Mathematics, Science and Engineering Education Act to establish a variety of fellowships, training programs and grants to foster and improve education in those fields. The bill authorizes $150 million for such programs in 1991. Bush vetoed the Indian Preference Act of 1990, which would have established a program to direct contracts and grants to Indian enterprises. He said the bill ``would impose new, expensive and often duplicative program responsibilities'' on the Interior Department, which administers Indian reservations. Because Congress is not in session, the president needs only to withhold his signature from a bill to constitute a veto, a process known as a ``pocket veto.''

DOC.HEAD: Suburban Pig Farmer Agrees To Quit, Still Faces Damages Claim
DOC.TEXT: The stench rising from a suburban Chicago hog farm will soon be just a rank memory, but a neighboring bank's claim for $250,000 in damages lingers on. Tenant farmer Douglas Daniels agreed in an out-of-court settlement announced Thursday to remove his 85 pigs from the 11-acre property by Dec. 12. In turn, Buffalo Grove will drop complaints that the farm was a public nuisance and an offensive and unwholesome business. First American Bank of Lake County in Buffalo Grove still wants $250,000 in damages to compensate its alleged losses in new customers and new loans during the five months Daniels raised pigs across the street. Daniels' lawyer, Robert Boehm, called the damages claim ``preposterous.'' Boehm said Daniels was hospitalized with pneumonia and unavailable for comment. Bank attorney Jeffrey Braiman said Friday there had been a substantial decline in use of automated teller machines located outside the bank. And he said the foul odor from the pig farm detracted from employees' enjoyment of their workplace. ``Many times they could not even have lunch in the bank because the smell was so overpowering,'' Braiman said. ``We think it has injured the business and injured the reputation of the bank.'' ``We're happy it's settled,'' said Phillip W. Versten, administrative assistant for Buffalo Grove, a community of about 35,000 people 30 miles northwest of Chicago. Daniels agreed to vacate the property because the owners, Joseph and Patricia Petrillo, found a likely buyer for the land and because Daniels' hogs will be ready to market in early December, Boehm said. First American said it would press both Daniels and the Petrillos for damages. The Petrillos' lawyer, James Graney, said the bank's damages claim was unfounded. A trial on the matter was set for Dec. 17.

DOC.HEAD: Guard Unit Leaves Behind Member Who Lost Court Bid To Block Gulf Deployment
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Virginia National Guardsman was left behind when his unit was sent to the Middle East even though he failed to gain a court order to block his deployment to Saudi Arabia, officials say. Medical tests have been ordered for Sgt. Michael R. Ange and he will remain at Fort Lee, Va., base spokeswoman Joy Whitmore said Friday. Ange's Army National Guard unit, the 1450th Transport Company, was deployed to the Persian Gulf on Wednesday. Ange's request for a temporary restraining order was blocked by a federal judge in Washington on Tuesday. Ange had sought to block his deployment on grounds that President Bush lacked congressional authority to wage war against Iraq. Ange, 26, a former Beaufort County, N.C., police officer, is now a student at Appalachian State University in Boone, N.C. He also claims that he is medically unfit for military service because of knee, leg and foot problems as well as an ulcer. Ange claims the Army began proceedings to discharge him because of his medical condition long before his reserve unit was activated last month. Whitmore said the decision to keep Ange at Fort Lee was in no way a concession by the Army of its legal right to ship the soldier to the Persian Gulf. Ange chalenged to the president's ability to send troops to the Middle East without either notifying Congress under the 1973 War Powers Act or obtaining a declaration of war as spelled out in the Constitution. The resolution requires presidents to notify Congress within 48 hours of sending troops to an area where hostilities are imminent. The troops must be withdrawn in 60 days without congressional approval. Bush, who last week ordered another 200,000 U.S. troops to join the 230,000 already in Saudi Arabia, this week told lawmakers that he has not decided whether to use force against Iraq. The 1973 act was passed over the veto of President Nixon and every chief executive since then has maintained the law is unconstitutional. In previous cases, courts have been reluctant to enforce the act, saying the dispute is a political matter between the president and Congress. U.S. District Judge Royce Lamberth refused to issue the temporary restraining order but said the case raised ``a difficult legal question'' and scheduled a Dec. 10 hearing on Ange's motion for a permanent injunction.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr isn't singing the blues over the discord surrounding her shrieking rendition of ``The Star Spangled Banner.'' In fact, the hit television comic says she wasn't even nervous when she warbled ``I Enjoy Being a Girl'' on Thursday night's videotaping of ABC's ``Into the Night'' show. ``You know, I got two standing ovations. So I think my career as a singer is back on track,'' she said in an interview. But the star of TV's ``Roseanne'' won't be doing any ``patriot songs'' after the drubbing she took for the way she sang the national anthem at a San Diego Padres baseball game this summer. ``Any anthem or something, I'm not going to sing them anymore,'' she said. --- HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. (AP) - Former President Carter says the pen is mightier than the peanut. Carter revealed Friday that he'd recently paid off a $1 million debt on his family peanut business in Plains, Ga., with proceeds from book sales. ``We've had very good income off the sales of our books,'' Carter said at Hofstra University, where a three-day seminar on his administration began Friday. ``They've all been best sellers.'' Carter's books include ``Why Not the Best,'' ``A Government as Good as its People'' and ``Keeping Faith: Memoirs of a President.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - ``Saturday Night Live'' alumnus Joe Piscopo surprised everyone but himself when he popped the question to his son's former babysitter during a videotaping of ``The Howard Stern Show.'' Piscopo, 39, proposed to 20-year-old Kimberly Driscoll as the WWOR-TV program was taped at its Secaucus, N.J., studio, said station spokeswoman Ellen Morgenstern. ``This was not one of our planned segments,'' she said. Piscopo had a jeweler deliver the engagement ring after the taping. It will be Driscoll's first marriage and Piscopo's second. Stern is a radio and television talk show host known for his confrontational style and explicit subject matter. --- FULTON, Mo. (AP) - Actor Bob Cummings, who for decades preached healthy living as the key to vitality, says Parkinson's disease has curbed his career. Cummings, a native of Joplin, Mo., retired from acting more than a decade ago, but that doesn't stop producers from urging a comeback. ``I read scripts, but I can't do them because of it,'' Cummings, 80, told The Fulton Sun. ``People ask me to do the scripts, but I tell them I can't. What if I should stumble and fall down?'' He visited Fulton for three days last week for dedication of a sculpture carved from pieces of the Berlin Wall. The Sherman Oaks, Calif., resident starred in the 1942 movie ``Kings Row,'' adapted from a novel about turn-of-the-century Fulton. Cummings was reunited with ``Kings Row'' co-star former President Reagan, who spoke at the dedication. Cummings appeared in more than 100 movies and starred in his own 1950's TV show. The long-time advocate of healthy habits wrote the book, ``How To Stay Young and Vital.'' Parkinson's diease is a neurological ailment that can cause tremors and severe muscle rigidity. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Look out Johnny and Arsenio: Ron Reagan, son of the former president, is getting his own syndicated late-night talk show. The show will be based in Los Angeles and co-produced by MCA-TV and Fox Television Stations Inc. The still-untitled show will be shown on the seven TV stations owned by Fox, and syndicated to other stations. Each one-hour program will feature talk, comedy and contemporary music. Reagan, 32, left ABC's ``Good Morning America'' last summer after four years as a contributing reporter.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Supports U.S. Proposal to Limit Mineral Extraction in the Antarctic
DOC.TEXT: Brazil says it supports a U.S. proposal to declare a 30-year moratorium on mineral extraction in the Antarctic. The agreement was signed Friday during a meeting in the capital between Marcos Azambuja, Brazil's Deputy Foreign Minister, and U.S. ambassador Curtis Bohlen, U.S. adjunct secretary of oceanic affairs and global environment. ``We've decided to work together to negotiate the moratorium,'' Bohlen said at a news conference. Azambuja said Brazil ``favored all measures to protect the fragile ecosystem and the Antarctic's environment.'' World environmental groups, supported by the governments of France, Australia and New Zealand, want to create a permanent international reserve in the Antarctic.

DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling Threatens Federal Employee Drug-Testing Program
DOC.TEXT: A federal court has struck down the Agriculture Department's testing of workers suspected of off-duty drug use leaving in doubt the future of a broader federal program. In its Friday decree, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit became the first federal appellate court to rule on whether the government may test employees suspected of off-duty drug use that does not affect on-the-job performance. In a case involving White House employees, however, the court ruled that government officials with access to ``secret'' information may be subject to random drug testing along with officials with ``top secret'' clearances. In the USDA case, the three-judge panel struck down regulations under which employees of the agency's Food and Nutrition Service could be tested if they were suspected of off-duty drug use even if it did not impair job performance. ``Because USDA regulations authorize urinalysis testing of ordinary employees who are not suspected of on-duty drug use or impairment, and because those regulations mandate needlessly intrusive testing procedures, we find them unconstitutional,'' the court said. While the ruling involved one component of USDA, it has government-wide implications because most federal agencies have adopted similar drug testing programs, said Elaine Kaplan, an attorney for the National Treasury Employees Union, which brought the case. The ruling means that ``in order to drug test the vast majority of federal employees, the government has to have individualized suspicion f on-duty drug use or on-duty impairment caused by drug use,'' Ms. Kaplan said. ``This is a significant limit on what they were trying to do.'' The panel, in an opinion by Circuit Judge Abner Mikva, said ``the government has not produced evidence that might establish a relationship between off-the-job drug use and government efficiency or on general integrity and deterrence rationales.'' ``The government may investigate and punish wrongdoing within the walls of its offices,'' Mikva wrote. ``What the government may not do in the case of ordinary employees is justify drug testing procedures that intrude upon constitutionally protected privacy interests with speculation about possible future job impairment or rules violations.'' Mikva was joined by Circuit Judges Laurence Silberman and Harry Edwards. The ruling, which partially reversed a lower court opinion, also struck down a portion of the regulations that allowed USDA officials to monitor employees while they provide urine samples without any suspicion that a worker might tamper with the specimen before it was tested. The court called this an invasion of privacy. The panel upheld random testing of USDA drivers because drug use might endanger public safety. In the other case, the same panel, over Edwards' dissent, upheld a policy of randomly testing employees of the Executive Office of the President holding ``secret'' security clearances. Courts had previously upheld random drug tests of employees with ``top secret'' clearances. American Civil Liberties Union attorney Arthur B. Spitzer said the case means that any government employee with a ``secret'' clearance will eventually be subjected to random drug testing. ``Its another diminution of important constitutional rights because of the anti-drug hysteria,'' Spitzer said. Edwards said that ``this case is not the first Fourth Amendment casualty claimed by the war on drugs. Nor, in all likelihood, will it be the last.'' ``I fear today's decision finds us unwilling to do what we must to preserve fundamental Fourth Amendment freedoms.''

DOC.HEAD: Lava Domes, Possible Fool's Gold, Found on Venus by Magellan Space Probe
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Thick, pasty lava once oozed onto the surface of Venus to form 15-mile-wide domes that look like giant pancakes or coconut macaroons in the Magellan spacecraft's newest pictures. Heat measurements made by the spacecraft show fool's gold or other iron-rich metallic minerals coat the slopes of the planet's tallest peak, 7-mile-high Mount Maxwell. Scientists released new radar pictures Friday during a news conference at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Engineers were relieved they were able to regain contact with the spacecraft after a 40-minute blackout Thursday. It was the third such communications failure in three months. Project manager Tony Spear said it could happen again, but called Magellan's health ``very good.'' Some pictures show 600-mile-long, 300-mile-wide horseshoe-shaped features, each surrounding a meteorite impact crater 10 miles to 15 miles wide. The horseshoes may have been formed by shock waves triggered by incoming meteorites or by windblown debris that settled to the ground after being kicked up by the impacts, said geologist Ray Arvidson of Washington University in St. Louis. They are ``unique in the solar system,'' he said. The space agency also displayed a computer-processed videotape that shows Venus' surface from the perspective of someone swooping over 130-mile-wide, half-mile-deep volcanic collapse craters and 38,000-foot-tall Mount Maxwell, the planet's tallest mountain. One of the new pictures shows seven lava domes, similar but much larger than the lava dome inside the crater of Mount St. Helens in Washington state, said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist. ``They look like coconut macaroons. They look like pancakes,'' he said. ``They're about 2,500 feet high and 15 miles across.'' Magellan's heat measurements show some of the middle slopes of Mount Maxwell contain ``mystery material'' that emits little heat, said Gordon Pettengill of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. That means the slopes are coated with soil containing metallic material, either iron pyrite - called fool's gold because it looks like gold - or iron minerals called hematite and magnetite, Pettengill said. Radar pictures show numerous mountain ridges and valleys created by squeezing of Venus' hot, thin crust, said Sean Solomon of MIT. In places, the mountains are no longer being squeezed upward, and are collapsing down onto lowland plains, he added. Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, arrived at Venus on Aug. 10 and formally started mapping the planet Sept. 15. Magellan has used radar to peer through clouds and map 18 percent of Venus' landscape, comparable to an area on Earth stretching from Los Angeles to Reykjavik, Iceland, and covering most of North and South America. Thursday's loss of contact with Magellan halted mapping for most of the day. Engineers still don't know the exact cause but suspect excess static sometimes disrupts one of Magellan's computers, Spear said. Those malfunctions and other problems will add about $3 million to $5 million to the $744 million cost of Magellan's mission, Spear said.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Atlantis Astronauts Deployed Satellite to Spy on Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis astronauts on a secret mission have deployed a surveillance satellite, possibly to spy on Iraq. A news blackout ordered by the Pentagon prevented NASA from discussing the flight, but sources speaking on condition of anonymity said the spy satellite was released Friday. Published reports have said the spacecraft will either eavesdrop on communications or conduct photo surveys of the Persian Gulf, where Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August and the United States promptly sent troops. The Air Force reportedly modified the satellite to spy on the Persian Gulf region while Atlantis was grounded this summer because of hydrogen leaks. But NASA remained mum about the mission, breaking the public silence just briefly Friday to announce the five astronauts would land at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., sometime between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. EST Monday. A more precise time will be announced 24 hours before landing. ``The crew is doing well, and the orbiter Atlantis continues to perform satisfactorily,'' said Mission Control commentator Kari Fluegel. Atlantis, with an all-military crew commanded by Air Force Col. Richard Covey, blasted into orbit Thursday night. The mission is the second shuttle flight in two months. Discovery flew last month when a nuclear-powered probe was dispatched on a journey to explore the sun's poles. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had planned to fly nine missions this year, but several flights have been delayed because of hydrogen leaks detected aboard Atlantis and Columbia. They were cleared for flight last month. Columbia's long-delayed astronomy mission now is scheduled to launch in early December. If successful, it would be the sixth shuttle flight this year.

DOC.HEAD: Worldwide Weapons Spending Declines For First Time In A Decade
DOC.TEXT: Spending on weapons by the nations of the world, including the Soviet Union, has decreased for the first time in 10 years, the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency reports. The agency said Friday that developing nations accounted for most of the decline, spending $25.1 billion less in 1988 than the year before. The overall drop was $36 billion. Even so, spending on arms surpassed $1 trillion for the second year in a row. Military spending in developing countries has been dropping since 1984. The $11 billion decline among the wealthier nations is the first drop in a decade. The Soviet Union, meanwhile, spent $299.8 billion on arms in 1988, a drop of 4 percent. The United States led the world with $307.7 billion, showing a slight increase over 1987. The Soviets are still in first place, however, in exporting weapons - $21 billion worth or 44 percent of the world's total in 1988. U.S. arms exports were $14.3 billion, the agency said. The end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988 contributed to a drop in military spending in the Middle East. At $60.7 billion it was at the lowest level in a decade. South Asian military spending continued to grow faster than any other region of the world - with an annual rate from 1978 to 1988 of 6.5 percent. The figures were all given in terms of dollars of 1988 buying power.
DOC.HEAD: VA Cuts Rate Ceiling To 9.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans Affairs is dropping the maximum interest rate for federally backed VA home mortgages by one-half percentage point to 9.5 percent, effective Monday. ``This should provide a significant stimulus to the housing market and the economy as a whole,'' Secretary Edward J. Derwinski said Friday. The new rate is for home and condominium loans. It means the monthly payment for principal and interest on a typical VA loan of $80,000 will total $672.29, down $29.37 a month from the previous rate. The department increased the rate from 9.5 percent to 10 percent last February. The department also lowered the rates for manufactured homes to 12 percent; graduated payment mortgages, to 9.7 percent; manufactured home and lot combination loans, to 11.5 percent; manufactured home lots only, 11.5 percent, and home improvement loans, to 11 percent. It said that in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, it guaranteed 196,600 home loans totaling $15.8 billion, compared to 188,000 home loans totaling $14.4 billion in the previous year. VA home loan guarantees may be used to purchase, improve or refinance a house or condominium and to purchase or refinance a manufactured home.
DOC.HEAD: CIA Employees Reported Fired In Stamp Case
DOC.TEXT: Four Central Intelligence Agency employees have been fired in an investigation of the sale of valuable mistakenly printed postage stamps, the agency said. The CIA said Friday night that five other employees were disciplined in unspecified ways. The case arose when the CIA purchased 95 of the $1 stamps at the McLean, Va., post office for its own use in 1986. The stamps showed an oil lamp, but the ones bought by the CIA had the body of the lamp upside down. Such misprints can be extremely valuable to stamp collectors. The nine employees sold 85 of the misprints to a New Jersey dealer, giving the dealer one torn stamp. Each employee kept one stamp, now worth a reported $17,000 each, and one of the nine employees is believed to have lost his stamp. The four employees who were dismissed were fired for lying to investigators, misappropriating government property and ``failing to return a number of valuable stamps purchased with agency funds after they were directed to do so,'' said spokesman Mark Mansfield. The dismissals were ordered ``reluctantly, only after all alternatives were fully explored, and this resolves the case from our point of view,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Charged In Capitol Bombing Given 10-Year Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: A woman who pleaded guilty to charges she helped bomb the U.S. Capitol seven years ago has been handed a 10-year federal prison term. Marilyn Buck, 42, also was ordered Friday to serve a concurrent five-year prison term for conspiracy in the Nov. 7, 1983 incident. The sentences, ordered by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene, will run concurrently with a 60-year sentence Buck is serving on other charges, prosecutors said. The U.S. attorney's office said repairs to the Capitol and art work displayed there cost $250,000. Buck pleaded guilty Sept. 7 to charges she was involved in the bombing and in plans to bomb other federal buildings. The remaining co-defendants in the case, Linda Evans, 43, and Laura Whitehorn, 43, also pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing. A group calling itself the Armed Resistance Unit claimed responsibility for the Capitol bombing, saying it was done in response to U.S. military action in Grenada. The bomb was placed in a public corridor near the Senate Republican Cloak Room and a few feet from the offices of Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who was then the majority leader. It was detonated with a time-delay device. Prosecutors said an investigation revealed members of the group also were involved in seven other bombings from 1983 to 1985 in the Washington and New York areas. Authorities said Buck participated in a 1981 Brinks armored truck robbery in Nyack, N.Y., in which four people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Help Locate Absent Fathers
DOC.TEXT: The government has agreed to help children fathered and left overseas by American soldiers to make contact with their long-departed parents. The National Archives and a British group, War Babes, on Friday released details of a draft settlement of a 2-year-old lawsuit intended to force the Archives and Defense Department to help children separated from, and sometimes unknown to, the fathers. The agreement was signed for the government Thursday and filed in federal court by Jay B. Stevens, U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia and Joan S. Meier, Washington-based lawyer for War Babes, a Birmingham, England-based organization of 300 sons and daughters of American fathers. Final court approval is expected. The breakthrough in the case came when Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in July ordered the Pentagon in its defense to produce affidavits from fathers declining contact from their offspring, Ms. Meier said. The settlement ``begins to redress the wrongs that started during the (World War II) when the Army encouraged men to have a good time, and then prevented them from marrying the mothers of their children and whisked them away so they could not be found,'' Ms. Meier said. She added that the settlement will help all children of American veterans who want to know their fathers, including those from the Korean and Vietnam wars. War Babes sought to establish that the right of children to information under the U.S. Freedom of Information Act took priority over the Privacy Act. The Pentagon has cited the Privacy Act to refuse requests to help reach veterans or active members of the armed forces even where the names and service numbers were provided. Calling the settlement ``a significant victory for families the world over,'' War Babes said the Pentagon had maintained that ``fatherhood of an illegitimate child during youth is at worst embarrassing and at a minimum highly personal. Contact by ... a long-lost illegitimate child, is clearly intrusive, whether welcome or not.'' Shirley McGlade, the founder of War Babes, said in an affidavit filed in the case that several fathers have been traced, and contrary to the U.S. government position, ``in almost every case the father welcomed his child, often with great joy.'' The government agreed in the settlement to forward certified mail from a son or daughter to the father at the last address listed in the National Personnel Records Center, operated by the Archives under Pentagon direction. If the father has died, the government agreed to disclose the address in returning the letter. In other cases, the city and state but not the street address will be provided, Ms. Meier said. Ms. McGlade was the daughter of a Welsh woman and an American soldier who left not knowing her mother was pregnant, she said. She found her father in California with the help of a U.S. radio program and his friends. Attorney Meier said thousands of sons and daughters in England alone could be affected by the settlement. Not all cases involve illegitimate births, she said, mentioning the sudden separations that occur during a war.

DOC.HEAD: Sarawak Natives Protest Logging of Tropical Forests
DOC.TEXT: Members of native groups in Borneo island's Sarawak region - the world's largest producer of tropical wood - say they are suffering from hunger and water pollution because of excessive logging. Friends of the Earth, an environmental group representing the natives, said Friday that nearly half the region's trees have been cut down. A study says the rest could disappear in seven years in Sarawak, a Malaysian state on nrthern Borneo. The native groups, in Tokyo for a meeting of the International Tropical Timber Organization, on Friday criticized Japan and tropical wood importers for violating their traditional rights over vast areas of forest in the Malaysian state. ``We are short of food. We hardly find anything from the jungle as we used to. But the ITTO pays no attention,'' said Jok Jau Evong, head of a Kayan residents association in Uma Bawang in eastern Sarawak, told reporters. ``In the past, it was still easy to live off the land. Since the timber companies came ... the fruits, edible plants and shoots were all damaged. Water pollution has killed the fish,'' said Juwin Lehan, who heads a Penan group in the area. ``The loss of the forest has caused massive erosion and sedimentation of rivers and creeks leading to flash floods. The water is contaminated and there are increasing reports of diarrhea and cholera,'' said Aster Soong of Friends of the Earth Malaysia. An official of the International Tropical Timber Organization, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the issue would be discussed Monday in a forum at ITTO headquarters in Yokohama, near Tokyo. Sarawak has a population of 1.3 million people and a land area of 49,000 square miles, about the size of New York state. Restrictions on timber exports from neighboring countries like Thailand and Indonesia have accelerated cutting in Sarawak in the past three years, making it the world's largest producer of tropical wood. Last year, Sarawak produced 543 million cubic feet of logs, up from 455 million cubic feet in 1988. Over half of Sarawak's wood exports are imported by Japan. Friends of the Earth, an environmental group representing the natives, says that only 60,600 square miles of Malaysia's original 117,700 square miles of forest land still have trees. At the current rate of logging, about 2,700 square miles a year, the nation's primary forest will be depleted in seven or eight years, according to a report by the University of Malaysia's botany department. Increased cutting has put loggers and natives, some of whom still live as nomads in the forest, in direct confrontation with each other. Native groups have attempted to prevent logging by setting up blockades and making appeals to government leaders, so far with little success, Jok Jau Evong said. ``We are the people who have been there for many generations. Somebody who just came yesterday is trying to get all the resources and we have no rights,'' he said. A recent ITTO mission to investigate conditions in Sarawak said that log production must be reduced by 30 percent, or 105 million cubic feet a year, to prevent depletion of the forests. It also recommended that forest management be improved. But Friends of the Earth and the native groups accused the mission of not thoroughly investigating the environmental impact of logging and said the recommendation would not save the forests. They are demanding a moratorium on all logging until policies are changed to prevent further damage to watershed areas and to protect the rights of people living in the forests.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean President To Make First Visit Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo has accepted a Soviet invitation to visit Moscow before the end of the year, a presidential spokesman said today. It would be the first trip to the Soviet Union by a president of South Korea, a fierce rival of Communist North Korea since the division of the peninsula in 1945. Moscow and Seoul have recently been improving ties, establishing formal diplomatic relations Oct. 30. Chief presidential spokesman Lee Soo-jung said the trip invitation wasincluded in a letter from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Roh, which was delivered by a visiting Soviet official. Vadim Medvedyev, a member of the Soviet Presidential Council, arrived Friday and said he was carrying a letter from Gorbachev to Roh. He met with the South Korean president this afternoon. Roh accepted the invitation, the spokesman said. The date of his Soviet visit will be decided later through diplomatic channels, he said. ``President Roh's visit to the Soviet Union will not only develop relations of the two countries but also provide a good opportunity to promote stability and peace on Northeast Asia,'' the spokesman said. Local newspapers, quoting unidentified high-ranking government officials, reported Roh's trip would take place around Dec. 18. The influential Chosun Ilbo newspaper said the Korean president's visit will last five days. It would be the second time that Gorbachev and Roh have met in less than six months. The two leaders met in San Francisco on June 4. Gorbachev is expected to return the visit before or after his scheduled trip to Japan next spring, Chosun said. Roh's trip would be a further setback for North Korea, which is allied with the Soviet Union. The two Koreas fought a bloody three-year war in the early 1950s.

DOC.HEAD: California Girl Sending Thousands Of Christmas Greetings to U.S. Soldiers
LaserPhoto VNY1
DOC.TEXT: Julie Setty is a card shark. A Christmas card shark, that is. The 16-year-old Simi Valley High School student has written more than 4,000 cards since July for mailing to U.S. soldiers around the world. Scribbling at a rate of 40 cards per hour, she plans to dash off a couple hundred more holiday messages before sending the whole batch on Tuesday. The idea is ``to let everyone out in the military ... know we're behind them 100 percent,'' said Miss Setty, who spent $350 on the cards. She and the 67 other members of her Air Force Junior ROTC program at the suburban Los Angeles high school hope to get about 9,000 cards to members of the military by Christmas. The greetings will be shipped by Military Mail Call, a nonprofit organization that distributes holiday greetings each year to troops in the United States and abroad. Although Miss Setty's card output is remarkably high, she's not the only person who enjoys sending Christmas cards. Her classmate Ben Schelb has completed 3,200 cards this year, and her brother, Jeff, sent 2,225 cards to U.S. servicemen last year.

DOC.HEAD: Scholarly Politics: Dispute Over New Editor for Ancient Manuscripts
DOC.TEXT: International scholars deciphering the Dead Sea Scrolls have chosen a new chief editor, hoping to speed up work on the ancient manuscripts. The incumbent called the move a power play by academic rivals. The scholars appointed Emmanuel Tov to share duties with editor in chief John Strugnell and complete work still unfinished about four decades after the documents' discovery. ``Once you get to a point where a whole generation who has looked forward to getting published are getting older and dying, the level of frustration gets higher,'' said Eugene Ulrich, theology professor at University of Notre Dame. The Dead Sea Scrolls, first discovered in 1947 in a cave in present-day Israel, are considered one of the richest religious libraries ever discovered from the period that gave birth to Christianity and modern Judaism. They date from about 100 B.C. to A.D. 70 and contain the oldest known copies of the Old and New Testaments, other Biblical writings, literature and poetry. Scholars editing the scrolls voted by mail in October to appoint Tov, of Jerusalem's Hebrew University, to share duties with Strugnell, of Harvard Divinity School, said Frank Cross of Harvard University, another member of the editing team. The Israeli Department of Antiquities, which proposed Tov, is making an ``alarming attempt'' to wrest publishing rights from current researchers, Strugnell said in a telephone interview Thursday. He wouldn't offer specifics but said he will fight Tov's appointment. Tov's appointment has not been announced, but Strugnell said the Israeli agency mailed notices to scholars earlier this month. It was expected to be formally announced to about 5,000 theologians and archaeologists at the American Schools of Oriental Research convention in New Orleans this weekend. Cross called Strugnell ineffective. ``There has been general criticism, both inside the team and out. It is not by chance that this move is being made,'' he said. The incumbent defended his program as being on schedule and said rivals are trying to grab power from him. Strugnell said he would agree to appoint a deputy editor in chief but not a co-editor. ``I don't see how it can be shared,'' he said. The shakeup is the latest in a years of academic dispute over who should control publishing rights to the scrolls. The first fragile documents were discovered by a Bedouin shepherd in a cave near the Dead Sea. Many manuscripts, which contained mainly Old Testament books, were published immediately. Many other documents unearthed uring the next 10 years in 11 caves remain largely undeciphered and unpublished. Strugnell said the remaining documents - as much as 45 percent of the total discovery - should be published by the year 2000. The manuscripts, particularly those discovered in 1952 in the fourth cave at Qumran, were found in fragments ranging from the size of a dime to the size of a human hand. Eight scholars, headed by Strugnell and overseen by the Israeli department, were given exclusive publishing rights to the scrolls, which remain sealed in aluminum boxes in the Rockefeller Museum in Jerusalem. The team was expanded in the mid-1980s, but still numbers fewer than 15. Ulrich, in a recent telephone interview, said Strugnell has not inspired others to work faster. ``You can certainly say that one would expect one volume to have appeared (from Strugnell) in the course of this time,'' Ulrich said. Strugnell blamed the slow pace on the painstaking task of piecing together the fragments, which can only be read under infrared photography, and a lack of ample funding. Other scholars like James VanderKam of North Carolina State University have offered unpublished photographs of the documents to other professors. VanderKam said that has helped quiet some criticism. ``People just seem to have lost their initial zeal,'' VanderKam said. ``That's why it's a good idea to pass it on to others.''

DOC.HEAD: Canceled Bret Easton Ellis Book Bought By Vintage
DOC.TEXT: Bret Easton Ellis' graphically violent novel about a serial killer has been purchased by Vintage Books after being dropped at the last minute by Simon & Schuster, it was reported today. Vintage, a division of Random House, will publish the book ``American Psycho'' as a trade paperback early next year, The New York Times reported. Simon & Schuster had planned to publish the book in hard cover in January, but rejected it as being in ``questionable taste,'' said the publisher's chairman, Richard E. Snyder. The book contains graphic descriptions of women being dismembered and cannibalized. The publisher paid Ellis a $300,000 advance, which he said he will keep. Vintage didn't disclose its purchase price. Ellis, 26, praised Vintage's decision to publish the book as a trade - or higher-priced - paperback, saying that will get it into stores quickly. Simon & Schuster, which had published Ellis' previous novels ``Less Than Zero'' and ``The Rules of Attraction,'' announced Wednesday it was dropping ``American Psycho.'' The author accused the publisher of censorship and of bowing to pressure from its parent company, Paramount Communications Inc. Snyder said he decided to scrap the book after reading it last weekend. ``I just decided it was an error in judgment to put our name on a book of such questionable taste,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump's Fall: Showpiece Casino Headed for Bankruptcy Court
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump christened the lavish Taj Mahal casino less than a year ago as the showpiece of his big-bucks empire. Now it's headed for bankruptcy-court protection. Trump and his Taj Mahal bondholders agreed Friday to a debt restructuring that will temporarily place the plush Atlantic City, N.J., gambling palace under bankruptcy-court protection and give the investors half ownership. The deal was reached more than 12 hours after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment on $675 million in junk bonds used to finance the casino. Some details of the agreement were still to be worked out, but bondholder representatives said it contained several incentives for Trump to improve the performance of the Taj Mahal. ``It's very much a carrot and stick approach here that we've adopted,'' said Robert Miller, an attorney for the bondholders. Trump, at a news conference with his aides and representatives of the bondholders group, said: ``The result is turning out to be a very positive one.'' Still, the flamboyant developer who once prided himself as a masterful businessman with enormous wealth looked grim during the news conference, held in another one of his swank properties, the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. He didn't shake hands with any bondholder representatives. The arrangement was the latest reversal for Trump, whose reputation as a jet-setting financial genius was shattered as New York's economy soured and he slid into multibillion-dollar debt. The Taj Mahal's bondholders had threatened to push Trump into bankruptcy proceedings and seize control of the casino. Under Friday's compromise, Trump and his investors agreed to restructure the debt in what is known as a ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy filing that will let the casino emerge from court protection within weeks, negotiators said. The interest rate on the bonds will be reduced to 12 percent from the current 14 percent and bondholders initially will receive 50 percent of the stock in the casino. Of the 12 percent interest, 10 percent must be paid in cash and 2 percent in bonds. But if Trump is able to pay the original 14 percent interest, his stake in the Taj Mahal will increase to 80 percent. The maturity date on the bonds will be extended from 1998 to 2000. The deal also requires that the Taj Mahal operate within 15 percent of its budget or Trump must turn control of it over to the bondholders. The cash-strapped Trump billed the 3-acre gaming hall the ``Eighth Wonder of the World'' when he opened it April 2, but it has been unable to take in the $1.3 million a day that industry analysts say is required for it to break even. The $1 billion resort, more than twice as large as any other Atlantic City casino, opened during an economic downturn that has placed financial pressure on several of New Jersey's casinos. Trump owns three casinos there - the Taj Mahal, Trump Castle and Trump Plaza - and all have high-yield junk bonds outstanding. The problems at the casinos as well as the depressed New York real estate market left Trump strapped for cash and helped bring on his current financial woes. The developer, who now owes an estimated $2 billion to banks, has been negotiating with his creditors since last spring to keep from losing his many properties.
