DOC.HEAD: Backers of Former Contras May Plot New Strategy in Nicaraguan Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Backers of former Contras who have occupied buildings and blockaded roads to pressure the government will plot new strategy if talks produce no results this weekend, a spokesman says. Mayor Armando Incer of Boaco, one of 18 southeastern towns supporting the ex-rebels' protests, said Friday his movement wants ``no government militarism and material aid for the disbanded Nicaraguan Resistance, so it can integrate into civilian life.'' Goverment commissions and mayors continued negotiations Friday to end the occupations and blockades along the Rama road, the only route between the capital Managua and the Atlantic Coast. Incer said that without progress in talks, his movement will meet Sunday to consider new measures. He did not elaborate. Police fired tear gas to break up a blockade by about 60 protestors Friday at the road's midpoint of Juigalpa, 90 miles east of Managua. The disbanded Contras and their supporters have been blocking the area all month to demand that President Violeta Chamorro live up to promises of aid to the former guerrillas she made when they agreed to disarm. The Contras had fought a U.S.-backed, 9-year war against Mrs. Chamorro's predecessors, the former Sandinista administration. Her insistence on allowing Sandinista leaders to maintain control of the army and police has become a central complaint in the blockades. ``The dismissal of the ministers of Interior and Presidency and the head of the army'' were at the top of a 12-point list of negotiation demands spokesmen for the dissident mayors presented in a news conference Friday. Also on Friday, lawmakers gave a vote of confidence to Mrs. Chamorro's attempts to handle the rash of disturbances without violence. ``In strengthening law and order, the use of the mechanism of dialogue and consensus reaches adequate solutions to political and social conflict,'' said a statement approved by 70 deputies with three abstentions. The remaining members of 92-seat assembly were absent during the vote. ``We condemn violence wherever it comes from and support the search for peaceful solutions,'' the lawmakers said. The army has been called out one time during the series of conflicts that has claimed at least 24 lives and left dozens wounded. Troops were deployed Wednesday to end a blockade at Sebaco, 50 miles north of Managua, after four police were killed and 23 other people were injured in a shootout. Mrs. Chamorro has warned, however, that she will call out the army if unrest continues.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraq Believed To Have Superguns
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq may have three superguns designed to fire 114-pound shells up to 465 miles and hit several neighboring capitals, but it's not known if the guns are operational, a newspaper reported today. The Independent, citing unidentified U.S. intelligence sources, reported the guns were made from parts manufactured by British companies and delivered to Iraq before the Iraqi project was uncovered by British customs officers last April. There was no immediate reaction from officials in Iraq, Britain or the United States. Cities such as Jerusalem, Tehran, Iran, and the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh are within 465 miles of Iraq. On April 12, British customs officers seized eight large sections of steel tubing at Teesport dock in northeast England. The tubes were about to be shipped to Iraq. The Iraqi government and the manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters of Rotherham in northern England, said the tubes were for an Iraqi petrochemical plant. Military experts at the time said the tubes appeared to be part of a barrel for a huge gun. But The Independent reported further customs investigations revealed the tubes were ``part of a ballistic test bed'' for a plan to fire satellites into space. It said the satellite plan was named Project Babylon and that the supergun Project 839 grew out of it. Also in April, Turkish customs officers seized a 30-ton steel cylinder from a truck heading for Iraq. British customs officers said they thought this was also due to form part of an Iraqi gun. Other suspected parts were seized in Greece and Italy. On Thursday, charges against two men accused of breaching Britain's arms embargo against Iraq were dropped at Sheffield Magistrates Court. Both denied any knowledge of the alleged gun. A lawyer for the Department of Customs and Excise told the court there was not enough evidence to bring a successful prosecution against businessman Peter Mitchell. The agency also did not wish to proceed against metallurgist Christopher Cowley. Mitchell, 43, had been charged with illegally exporting equipment. He is managing director of forgemasters Walter Somers Ltd., manufacturers of the pipe found in Turkey. Cowley, 52, faced two similar charges of organizing illegal exports. Press Association, the British domestic news agency, reported that Cowley is a former project coordinator for Canadian-born U.S. artillery expert Gerald Bull. Bull, slain by a gunman in Brussels, Belgium, on March 22, was reportedly hired by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to design a supergun. The Independent reported that Belgian police and justice sources believe the killing was linked to agents of Mossad, the Israeli security service. It said Walter Somers and Sheffield Forgemasters built three satellite guns for Project Babylon. It said the design work was completed by Cowley, who worked for Bull's Belgium-based Space Research Corp. It added: ``Project 839 was the work of an SRC company, and it borrowed heavily on the research conducted over the years by Dr. Bull. Most important, 839 was a gun in every sense.''

DOC.HEAD: Union Marchers Rally, Newspaper Drivers Arrested After Firecracker Attack
DOC.TEXT: Chanting ``Scabs go home,'' 2,000 demonstraters shut down traffic in midtown Manhattan with a march in support of striking Daily News workers. Striking Greyhound workers, members of city unions and others marched for nearly a mile Friday. They then held a rally outside the Daily News offices, where Newspaper Guild local president Barry Lipton directed a message to replacement workers hired after the strike. ``Get the hell out of town. We want our jobs back, and we'll get our jobs back,'' Lipton said. Earlier Friday, two striking Daily News drivers and a former driver were arrested after allegedly setting off two powerful M-80 firecrackers at a Long Island convenience store that sells the tabloid. Officials from the News and the unions condemned the violence. A customer was slightly injured when the firecracker dipped in wax and rolled in BBs exploded at a 7-Eleven store, Nassau County police said. Charles Esposito, 47, a striking driver, and Russell Kengott, 23, a former driver, were charged with arson, possession of a weapon, criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, assault and conspiracy, said Detective Sgt. Daniel Sheehan. Luke Fox, 31, a striking driver, was charged with the same offenses and an additional weapons possession count, police said. Sheehan said the men bought beer in the store and left one firecracker by the front door and another by a refrigerator. The explosions shattered glass and sprayed the store with BBs. A customer was struck in the arm and buttocks, but refused medical attention, police said. Violence has punctuated the strike since it began on Oct. 25. New York City police report that as of Thursday, there have been 173 strike-related incidents and 80 arrests. Many vendors, saying they have been intimidated, are refusing to sell the News, which before the strike was the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily newspaper. In Nassau County, where the News has a printing plant in Garden City, there have been 28 criminal incidents, 14 arrests and five injuries, police said. Three of those who participated in Friday's march were charged with disorderly conduct, harassment, obstructing governmental administration and resisting arrest, said police spokesman Officer Scott Bloch. A fourth man was charged with disorderly conduct. The Daily News, using management, replacement workers and returning Newspaper Guild members, has published every day since the strike began. But circulation has lagged. The News said last week that it was printing 600,000 papers a day and selling about 400,000, down from 1.09 million before the strike. It said 2,000 of its usual 12,000 outlets were selling the paper. The News has hired hawkers, including homeless and other unemployed people, in an attempt to fill the void.

DOC.HEAD: Milli Vanilli Says Record Company Knew They Were Fakes
DOC.TEXT: What did Arista executives know about Milli Vanilli's fake singing and when did they know it? Group members and a former manager claimed record company executives at Arista knew the dreadlocked duo was faking it, even before the Grammy Awards ceremony in February. German producer Frank Farian this week confirmed longstanding rumors the pair, Robert Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan, did not sing on the multi-platinum ``Girl You Know It's True'' album. Farian said the two lip-synced for videos and live appearances. But Pilatus told the Los Angeles Times on Friday the pair had already admitted the truth to Clive Davis, president of Arista. ``We told Clive Davis. We told Sandy Gallin (a Hollywood talent manager). We told everybody six months before the Grammy Awards,'' Pilatus said. Milli Vanilli's former manager, Todd Headlee, said their phony recording was common knowledge at the record company. ``Everyone at Arista who worked closely with the group was walking on eggshells before the Grammy lip-sync performance last February,'' Headlee told the Times. ``When they walked off the stage clutching the trophy, I remember thinking to myself that they may not have deserved the Grammy for their performance, but they sure as hell did deserve an Oscar,'' Headlee added. Roy Lott, executive vice president of Arista, denied the entertainers' account. ``There is now way that anyone ever could have know whether they sang or not,'' Lott said. ``We are merely a distributor of their records. Rob and Fab and Frank assured us that they sang on the record.'' A call seeking comment from Davis on Friday night was not returned. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences will decide next month whether to strip the Grammy Award for Best New Artist. ``It was fraud and we're appalled by it,'' NARAS President Michael Greene said Friday. ``But our hearts go out to these two guys, because they're very easy targets.'' The NARAS awards subcommittee will meet Dec. 5 in New York to discuss revoking the award and the board of trustees will meet later that month to make a final decision. If the Grammy is revoked it would mark the first such action taken in the academy's 33-year history. Casey Kasem, host of the national radio program, Casey's Top 40, said today Milli Vanilli should be ``forgiven.'' ``In all fairness you have to recognize that we all, at one time or another, have been sucked into a situation we regret,'' Kasem said from Washington D.C. in a telephone interview with the Associated Press. ``The album was a major seller and loved by a lot of people,'' Kasem said. ``They (Milli Vanilli) know in their hearts they could have done that but didn't have the opportunity.'' Meanwhile, angry fans turned in their ``Milli Vanilli'' recordings Friday and radio stations vowed to pull the pop duo off the air. ``I think they're dirty scumbuckets,'' said 9-year-old Katie Dickman of Richmond, Ind. ``I used to like them, but not now.'' Radio station WLOL-FM in Minneapolis said it was ``Milli Vanilli Free'' and would no longer play the album. Farian says he was forced to go public with the revelations when the boys told him they wanted to sing on the follow-up record. ``I said, `No. I don't go for that.' Sure, they have a voice, but that's not really what I want to use on my records,'' Farian said Wednesday. In a statement Thursday, the two said they ``have been ready, willing and able to record our own vocals and have been prevented by Frank Farian from doing so.''

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Mass for Slain Jesuits Demands Support of Underprivileged
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 people, including 150 priests, attended a Mass marking a year since the massacre of six Jesuit priests - a case in which army officers were arrested but have yet to go to trial. The Central American head of the Jesuit order said at the outdoor Mass on Friday that worldwide attention to the massacre should be forged into support for the underprivileged in the Third World. ``The developed world's solidarity will not be authentic as long as it is limited to supporting us, the Jesuits, ... while alienation, poverty and injustice continue to batter the disenfranchised,'' said the Rev. Jose Maria Tojeira, provincial for the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus. Six priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter were slain on Nov. 16, 1989. An army colonel, three lieutenants and four soldiers are under arrest and charged with the murders, but the case has not yet gone to trial. No officer has ever been convicted of killing civilians in the 11-year Salvadoran civil war, that has claimed more than 73,000 lives, mostly civilian. The army lost half of its $85 million in U.S. military aid planned for 1991, because Congress was unhappy with El Salvador's progress in prosecuting the Jesuit murder case. El Salvador's far right considered the Jesuits subversives for their contention that the guerrilla war against a series of U.S.-backed governments stems from injustice, repression and poverty - rather than international Communist expansion. Seventeen bishops, including four U.S. prelates, co-celebrated the Mass in a parking lot at the University of Central America, where the slain priests taught. Portraits of the martyrs hung from a wire stretched above the altar - the Revs. Ignacio Ellacuria, Ignacio Martin-Baro, Segundo Montes, Amado Lopez, Juan Ramon Moreno and Joaquin Lopez. The U.S. bishops who took part in Friday's ceremony were the Revs. Walter Sullivan of Richmond, Va.; Carlos Sevilla of San Francisco; Ricardo Ramirez of Las Cruces, N.M.; and Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee. The ceremony took place against a backdrop of fighting between the army and the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. Twenty-six army members died and at least 22 were injured Thursday and Friday in a battle with rebels 61 miles southeast of San Salvador near San Agustin, according to the rebel Radio Farabundo Marti. The army said Friday it did not have a casualty count because the fighting was still going on.

DOC.HEAD: College Dropout Faces Prison After Wild Spending Spree
DOC.TEXT: It'll be the big house instead of the penthouse for a college dropout who lived the good life on bad checks and unpaid credit cards. Anthony DeFelippis, 21, was ordered to spend 37 months in federal prison as punishment for a cross-country spending spree of more than $100,000. He was convicted on felonies for bank larceny and making false statements to a bank. ``I think the only explanation would be the statement `out of control,''' DeFelippis said during his sentencing hearing. U.S. District Judge Michael Mihm cited DeFelippis' unrepentant attitude in levying the lengthy sentence. DeFelippis blamed his problems on his failure to attain a college degree and didn't express remorse for his crimes during his hearing Thursday. The convictions resulted from a series of bad checks, overdrawn credit cards and misrepresentations made to bankers in the two years since DeFilippis, a New Jersey native, quit Bradley University in 1988. After dropping out of school, his only employment then was a part-time job in New Jersey that paid him $4,000 over four months. But records show he fancied silk suits, traveled in limousines, took a joy ride in a helicopter and charged the rental fee to the Chicago brokerage company where he hoped to work. He succeeded in running up a $100,000 tab on his American Express credit card and accruing large debts on other credit cards, according to court testimony. Authorities said he left a string of creditors in Chicago, Los Angeles, New Jersey and Florida. DeFelippis was arrested in Chicago in March 1989 on a federal warrant resulting from his application for a $250,000 loan at a Peoria bank. On his application, he fraudulently claimed to have a $2 million annual income, prosecutors said. FBI agents began tracking him when he returned to the bank to check on his loan application's status. He caught a plane to Chicago and was picked up by Chicago Police while trying to make a large credit purchase at Neiman Marcus, records indicate. He has been held without bond since July 1989. He pleaded guilty to the charges in April.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon State University Official Who Escaped From Kuwait Arrives Home
DOC.TEXT: On the 700-mile trek to freedom across the desert from occupied Kuwait, Ernest Briskey knew the consequences if he was captured. For him, it would have meant life in prison, he said. For those who were hiding him, it would mean death. Disguised as an Arab, the 59-year-old Oregon State University official successfully made the seven-day journey from Kuwait City to Amman, Jordan. ``I now appreciate what life is all about,'' he said. Sporting a beard he grew as part of his disguise, Briskey smiled through tears as he was greeted by his family at Portland International Airport Friday. He wouldn't talk about the details of his escape because he feared for the safety of those who helped him. Asked if he was concerned that he would be caught, he joked, ``if I'd have sneezed, maybe.'' ``There were about 100 points, perhaps, between Kuwait City and crossing the border where one has to be especially sensitive,'' he said. ``There were a lot of soldiers.'' Briskey, assistant vice president for international program development at Oregon State, spent 110 days in hiding. Many of the Americans he knew were taken hostage. Others were able to return home. Some still are in hiding, he said. A food technology expert and former dean of agriculture at Oregon State, Briskey was working as a senior adviser to the Kuwaiti Institute of Scientific Research when Iraqi forces invaded the country on Aug. 2. ``It's been an incredibly brutal destruction of a people and a country,'' he said, ``actually much worse than what has been portrayed perhaps to the American people.'' Briskey said everything of value that could be removed has been taken from Kuwait. ``They took dairy cows, all the chickens, all the computers, all the cars,'' he said. ``They took anything moveable, hospital supplies.'' And he said he heard many tales of brutality. ``I personally know that they did shoot members of families if they found anything American,'' Briskey said. ``I know people who saw this happen. They shot people including a 70-year-old grandfather because a passport was found. I also know that a pregnant woman was stabbed in the abdomen when she complained about medical facilities.'' Asked how he spent his time, Briskey said, ``I listened to the BBC every hour on the hour and I read a lot. I read the Bible twice.'' He said he supports President Bush's actions in the region and only wishes the buildup of forces had come sooner. He hopes war can be avoided but said he saw no signs that Saddam Hussein is willing to withdraw his forces. ``Kuwait is not Kuwait anymore,'' he said. ``It is all bunkered. Ridges are built out of sand with machine guns and all the barbed wire and the mines.'' His wife, Marge, said her husband looked tired. ``He said he hasn't slept for 12 days,'' she said. She also wasn't impressed with the beard. ``We'll be getting rid of that,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Over Northern Coasts; Clear Skies Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the northern corners of the Atlantic and Pacific coasts early today, but skies were clear over much of the rest of the nation, with another day of fair weather anticipated. A cold front over the Pacific Northwest brought showers to Washington early today and they were expected to move across the state into Oregon. Another cold front over the Atlantic Ocean brought showers to Maine and upstate New York, with the rain expected to spread over much of New England. Most of the rest of the nation was looking for sunny skies. The highs were expected to be in the 50s in the Northeast and Northwest, the 60s in the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic states, the 70s in the South and the 80s in the Southwest deserts. The high for the nation Friday was 91 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Tree-Mendous: New York's Rockefeller Center All Spruced Up
DOC.TEXT: The Rockefeller Center tree arrived and the city's first holiday traffic gridlock alert went out, but with 71-degree temperatures it sure didn't feel a lot like Christmas. The 75-foot-tall Norway spruce, donated by a Connecticut man, was hoisted into place Friday morning right next to the center's skating rink and down the street from the Radio City Music Hall's Christmas show. The temperature in mid-Manhattan hit a high of 71 degrees a few hours after the tree was put in place, just one degree short of the 1928 record for the date. During the next two weeks, crews will decorate the tree with 20,000 multicolored lights that will blink to life Dec. 3 at a ceremony hosted by actress-singer Liza Minnelli. The tree was donated by Charles Cenci of Norwalk, Conn., in honor of his father, who planted it in his front yard 61 years ago. ``I figured a lot of people would enjoy it,'' Cenci said. Cenci offered the tree for the city's annual holiday celebration eight years ago, but officials said it didn't grow tall enough to qualify until this year.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Orders Emergency Check of NWA Airbus Planes
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered Northwest Airlines to examine 11 of its planes for possible safety defects, according to a published report. The FAA warned that an instrument critical to controlling the plane has jammed at least six times on A320s operated by foreign carriers and in test flights, the (Minneapolis) Star Tribune reported today. The problem involves loss of trim control, which would affect the nose-up and nose-down angle of the airplane. The Star Tribune reports that documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act indicate the problem could be even worse if the loss of the electrical trim actuator was coupled with malfunctions of two on-board computers that help maneuver the plane. ``This condition, if not corrected, could result in loss of control of the airplane,'' say FAA documents. Airbus Industrie, manufacturer of the A20, and Northwest said the problem can be managed and chances are slim that there would be a combination of events leading to total loss of control. Northwest is the only U.S. carrier flying the European-built plane, which features a sophisticated ``fly-by-wire'' control system that relies heavily on computers. Northwest has ordered 89 more of the planes. Phoenix-based America West Airlines is adding A320s to its fleet, which would make it subject to the same FAA directive.

DOC.HEAD: Couple in Custody for Church Thefts
DOC.TEXT: A husband and wife were in custody today for allegedly stealing crosses, statues and other items in a string of church thefts that have occurred since April, authorities said. Nancy Cox, 47, was arrested late Thursday night at the couple's apartment in nearby South Gate, said Detective Sgt. Mike Woodward. She was booked for investigation of burglary and held on $5,000 bail. Her husband, Stephen Cox, 37, was already in custody in Los Angeles in connection with an unrelated restaurant burglary. That investigation led to the wife's arrest, Woodward said Friday. ``We believe they are connected to 30 to 100 of the church burglaries,'' Woodward said. The thefts all took place in Los Angeles County, authorities said. At the couple's apartment, authorities discovered a 14-inch statue of the Virgin Mary, crosses, radios and other items. ``We've already had people from three churches come and identify items that we recovered,'' Woodward said.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leader Urges Release of All Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric today again urged the release of all Western hostages and many Arab prisoners on humanitarian grounds. ``We have to work for closing the file of the hostages and those unjustifiably detained, be they Iranians, Americans, Europeans or Lebanese,'' Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah said. ``This whole file should be closed because it is a humanitarian issue,'' Fadlallah said in a statement released by his press office. It was the second such plea in two days by the cleric. ``To those who think that releasing the hostages would be in favor of the Western states, we say it would be in favor of humanity, which is not separate from Islamic values,'' he said. Fadlallah is the spiritual guide of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, the umbrella organization for underground Shiite factions believed holding most of the 13 Westerners in Lebanon, including six Americans. More than 300 Shiite Moslems are held at the Khiam prison in south Lebanon, controlled by the Israeli-affiliated South Lebanon Army militia. Several of them are Hezbollah fighters. Hezbollah says an undisclosed number of its members are held by Christian militias in east Beirut. Relatives of four Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon's Christian enclave in 1982 arrived in Lebanon Tuesday in an effort to obtain information. They say they had information the four were held at a prison run by Christian warlord Samir Geagea in the Faraya ski resort northeast of Beirut. Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia said the four were killed by rival Christian chieftain Elie Hobeika. Fadlallah's past statements encouraging the release of foreign hostages appear to have had no tangible effect on the kidnappers, despite the influence of his religious authority. But when a group calling itself Organization Islamic Dawn released Americans Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April, it said the releases were partly due to the ``behests of senior religious leaders.'' The 13 missing Westerners include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. American journalist Terry Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Death for Convicted Arsenic Killer
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - The testimony of nurses was credited with convicting a woman sentenced to death for spoon-feeding her boyfriend arsenic-laced food. ``Our nurses were wonderful witnesses,'' prosecutor Janet Branch said Friday after a judge ordered Blanche Taylor Moore, 57, to die for killing Raymond Reid with poisoned peanut-butter milkshakes and banana pudding while he lay in a hospital bed four years ago. ``Obviously, Mrs. Moore made an attempt to make an impression on them,'' Ms. Branch said. ``Thus she did, and the nurses' very reliable memories four years later were probably responsible for the conviction.'' The same jury that convicted Mrs. Moore of first-degree murder on Wednesday recommended the death penalty on Friday after deliberating four hours. Forsyth County Superior Court Judge William Freeman set the execution date for Jan. 18, 1991. Death sentences in North Carolina are automatically appealed. As the jury's recommendation was read, Mrs. Moore sighed and said very quietly: ``My God.'' If her appeals fail, Mrs. Moore would choose between death by gas or lethal injection. Defense attorneys said they expect to do better during their appeals. ``Our belief is this verdict and judgment will not stand the scrutiny of the appellate court,'' defense lawyer Mitchell McEntire said. ``It's round one of a difficult fight.'' Mrs. Moore also is charged in the poisoning death of her first husband, James Taylor, in 1973, and the poisoning of her estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore, who became sick after their honeymoon last year but survived. She may be tried later on those charges. Reid, of Kernersville, died in October 1986 at North Carolina Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem. He was 50. Investigators began looking into the deaths of Reid and Taylor after doctors discovered last year that Mrs. Moore's estranged husband had been poisoned. Prosecutors said during the four-week trial that Mrs. Moore was driven by a need for money and that she killed Reid to gain part of his estate.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Settlement Reached in Manville Trust Case
DOC.TEXT: An agreement could be completed this weekend that would mark a major breakthrough in a two-decade-old effort to compensate thousands of people injured by asbestos fibers, a lawyer said. Victims would be compensated according to the severity of their illness, rather than a highly criticized system under which claims were processed based on the time of filing. Peter Angelos, a Baltimore asbestos victims' attorney involved in restructuring negotiations, said Friday the majority of a seven-member committee of plaintiffs' lawyers had approved the plan. The deal would also have to be approved by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who earlier this year ordered the overhaul of the Manville trust fund set up to compensate asbestos victims. The trust has 130,000 claims pending. A restructuring would cap a year of turmoil that began when the trust said it had run out of cash to pay future claims and that some asbestos victims would not be compensated until well into the next century. Leon Silverman, the New York lawyer appointed by Weinstein to restructure the trust, declined comment Friday. The Manville trust was created in 1988 as part of the bankruptcy court reorganization of Manville Corp., which declared Chapter 11 six years earlier because it couldn't meet its liability from asbestos lawsuits. Denver-based Manville was once the nation's largest asbestos manufacturers. Asbestos is a mineral used widely for decades in shipbuilding, contruction and other industries. It later was found to cause lung cancer and other serious and often fatal diseases.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Commander Concerned Soviet Arms Being Moved East
DOC.TEXT: NATO's top military commander in Europe says he welcomes the new conventional arms accord, but that he's concerned some Soviet weaponry already removed from Eastern Europe won't be destroyed under the treaty. The treaty does not take effect until its signing, scheduled for Monday in Paris. Moscow has said it has already moved 20,000 tanks, 24,000 artillery pieces and 800 aircraft to east of the Ural Mountains, out of the treaty area between those mountains and the Atlantic. ``They are a concern to me,'' U.S. General John Galvin said Friday. ``They are not in an offensive deployment (but that does) not take away my worries,'' Galvin, NATO's top commander in Europe, told reporters. But he and other NATO officials welcomed the Conventional Forces in Europe accord, finalized by negotiators from the 16 NATO and six Warsaw Pact nations on Thursday, as a political and military milestone. One official said Moscow ``is aware of our concerns'' that arms, subject to be removed under the CFE treaty, do not remain operational east of the Urals. ``We have been given assurances'' this will not happen, said the official, who asked not to be named. He said North Atlantic Treaty Organization will remain ``vigilant'' and monitor the situation. NATO officials say the Soviet arms already transferred to east of the Ural Mountains are in unprotected storage and bound to deteriorate. The CFE treaty is to be signed Monday by the leaders of the NATO and Warsaw Pact nations in Paris in the margin of a 34-nation East-West summit. Only days later, the NATO and Warsaw Pact states will open talks on a follow-up accord on troop levels across Europe. The CFE treaty will bring about, over three years, a 40 percent cut in battle tanks, armored cars, artillery, combat planes and assault helicopters. In all, 100,000 such items are to go - 90,000 on the Warsaw Pact side, mostly the Soviet Union, and 10,000 on NATO's - leaving 250,000 such arms systems in place overall. The CFE treaty provides for verification of efforts to destroy weapons to ensure each alliance will end up with no more than 20,000 tanks, 30,000 armored cars, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters within the treaty area.

DOC.HEAD: Thailand Threatens U.N. Officials Who Aid Burma Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with comment from student leader, refugee official. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Ministry has threatened to expel U.N. or other refugee officials who assist Burmese dissidents living in Thailand, newspapers reported today. Thailand has close ties with the military government that took power in Burma two years ago by brutally crushing a student-led movement for democracy. Thousands fled the suppression and joined armed rebel groups in areas bordering Thailand and India. The Bangkok government began reconsidering the status of Burmese asylum seekers after two Burmese students hijacked a Thai airliner flying to their homeland on Nov. 10. Two other Burmese students hijacked an jetliner to Thailand a year ago. The Nation newspaper said Chamnarn Potjana, deputy permanent secretary of the Interior Ministry, on Friday warned international organizations and aid agencies to stop assisting Burmese students. If they did not, ``no matter whether they are officials of the UNHCR (U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees) or other United Nations agencies, we will ask the Foreign Ministry to expel them from the country as persona non grata,'' Chamnarn was quoted as saying. A Western relief official said on condition of anonymity that the situation of Burmese students in Thailand had become very serious. He said the High Commissioner was reviewing its assistance to the students. ``We have responsibility for these people (students) and we have to fulfill our obligations. At the same time we must take into account the Thai position,'' he said. Thaung Htun, a spokesman for the All Burma Students' Democratic Front, said the Thai government ``should consider the problem of Burmese students from a humanitarian point of view. Any person who fled should have the rights of a refugee.'' Chamnarn spoke after a Cabinet committee meeting to discuss what measures to take regarding the students. He said the committee had recommended the establishment of a holding camp for Burmese dissidents on the Thai-Burma border. The Nation quoted Chamnarn as saying the High Commissioner should use the $120,000 monthly allowance it had for Burmese students to establish the camp. The private U.S. Committee for Refugees estimates there are 2,000 Burmese students living in Bangkok. Another 2,700 are on the Thai-Burma border, according to the All Burma Students' Democratic Front, the main group of exiled students. Thailand considers the students illegal immigrants subject to detention, fines and deportation. They depend on the aid of private relief groups and grants from the U.N. High Commissioner ranging from $40 to $120 a month. According to the U.S. Committee for Refugees, Thailand has repatriated more than 5,200 Burmese, many of them students, since 1988. Amnesty International has cited reports that Burmese authorities have brutally interrogated and tortured some students repatriated from Thailand. The Bangkok Post quoted Chamnarn as saying that in addition to the hijacking, Burmese students were thought responsible for a recent small bomb attack on the Burmese Embassy compound in Bangkok. He said Thailand would deport those who violated its immigration law and penal code.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Spills More Than 4 Million Gallons of Oil Far From Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 to UPDATE with company official comment, and to CORRECT that spill happened this week sted last week. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `In the...'. ADDS 2 grafs on end with further from company official.
DOC.TEXT: The spill of up to 6 million gallons of crude oil by a Norwegian-flagged tanker does not pose a threat to the coastline, U.S. Coast Guard and company officials said. The tanker lost between 4 million gallons and 6 million gallons of oil after it was damaged in stormy seas earlier this week in the north Atlantic. The leak has stopped, said an official with the company that owns the ship. ``In the heavy weather, the pounding it took caused some structural damage to the forepeak, or the forward part of the ship,'' Lt. Brian Crenzine of the Coast Guard in New York said today. The tanker Berge Broker spilled the Arabian light crude oil about 700 miles southeast of Nova Scotia, Lt. Richard Gill of the U.S. Coast Guard in Boston said Friday. The ship, bound for Newfoundland, found itself in the middle of a fierce Atlantic storm Tuesday that damaged two tanks, which emptied into the ocean, Crenzine said. No other oil escaped and the vessel remained seaworthy, Crenzine said. Jim McGrenachan, a spokesman for the Coast Guard in New York, said chances were slim the spill would make it to land. ``Some oil has been released,'' McGrenachan said. ``The tanker was in rough seas. Right now we're not even responding. It doesn't seem to be any kind of threat to anybody. It's pretty far out there. It's so far out in the middle of nowhere.'' On Friday the ship was moving toward a rendezvous with a sister ship, which will take on the Berge Broker's remaining oil cargo, Gill said. Kjell Roevik, the director of Bergesen dy AS, owner of the ship, said in a telephone interview today from his home in Oslo that the leak had been stopped and the Berge Broker was heading southeast. ``It is a very light oil, it is broken down at once and will not reach land. ... It is in the middle of the Atlantic,'' Roevik said. No cleanup efforts were planned, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Clash With Protesters In Johannesburg
DOC.TEXT: Security forces fired shotguns and rubber bullets and used dogs today to break up a march through the city by hundreds of blacks calling for the abolition of black township councils. Police opened fire after about 700 protesters ignored an order to disperse because the march had been banned. The marchers fled in panic as police opened fire with rubber bullets and tear gas. At least four people were wounded by shotgun fire. In another march in Cape Town, police baton-charged protesters. A group of about 200 people trying to join an African National Congress march on Parliament said police beat them with batons. Police used tear gas to disperse a third protest in the Johannesburg township of Toekomsrus. Officials said small groups of people gathered illegally and threw stones at police. An anti-apartheid group, the Civic Association of the Southern Transvaal urged protests to demand abolition of black township councils. The Association and the ANC allege the councils collaborate with the white-led government to perpetuate apartheid. Heavily armed army soldiers in brown battle fatigues were called out in Johannesburg when protesters began hurling rocks and bottles at police vehicles after the march was dispersed. Police officers crouching behind their vehicles fired shotgun blasts up at surrounding apartment buildings. Residents leaning out of windows hurled bottles and yelled curses at the security forces. ``South Africa belongs to us. Get away from here,'' screamed one enraged woman. Protesters chanted, ``ANC, ANC.'' Police used shotguns and tear gas to disperse protesters who attempted to reassemble. Officers unleashed police dogs into the crowds and several people were bitten. Police pulled back several times to try to defuse the situtation. But running clashes broke out again when cheering protesters swarmed into roads, blocking traffic. Running clashes continued for more than three hours near the city's main post office. Police said one police officer was injured, but they had no overall details on injuries or arrests. About 3,000 people took part in the Cape Town march. There were no incidents in the march itself, which had been given official permission. Demands presented to government officials called for the immediate abolition of black town councils. President F.W. de Klerk is dismantling apartheid and has promised to share power with the black majority. But laws segregating residential areas remain in effect, and most blacks live in squalid townships. A statement by march organizers said most blacks believed little had changed despite de Klerk's reforms. ``These demands and actions flow from our sincere commitment to peace and our belief that South Africans must come together to build a just, non-racial and democratic country where we can be truly proud to bring up the generations of the future,'' the statement said. Regional ANC publicity secretary, Trevor Manuel, said the protest showed that there was ``a big chasm between what state president de Klerk and his Cabinet are saying to the world and what they are actually delivering.''

DOC.HEAD: Blimp Advertising Sparks UFO Reports From Worried Residents
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of startled residents in southern San Diego County called police to report a UFO, which turned out to be a blimp on its maiden advertising voyage. Lighted brightly in the night sky to attract attention, the blimp did exactly that Friday night. Police in Chula Vista, National City and San Diego say they got a number of calls from residents worried about an invasion from outer space. ``People think they are seeing UFOs and it's weird,'' a Chula Vista police dispatcher said. ``They see a big thing glowing in the sky and then want to call us.'' The suspected flying saucer is owned by San Diego-based Virgin Lightships, which is part of the London-based business group that includes Virgin Atlantic Airways. It arrived this week at its new base at Brown Field in Otay Mesa, and was making its first voyage through the area as an advertising ploy. Company officials say up to 23 of the blimps are scheduled to be built within five years to advertise for clients throughout the United States and Europe. They rent for about $250,000 a month. Chula Vista is about 10 miles south of downtown San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev To Give More Power To Republics' Council; Ryzhkov May Lose Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with background, quotes from Ryzhkov, deputies. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1, NY10
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed a government overhaul that would give republics more influence and could force out Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who has resisted swift reform. The move appeared to be a concession to Gorbachev's main rival and frequent critic, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, who had demanded a coalition government and Ryzhkov's resignation. Speaking to the Supreme Soviet legislature, Gorbachev also said an emergency program will be drafted within two weeks to deal with growing food shortages. He did not give details. In today's 12-minute speech, Gorbachev elaborated on some of the ideas he introduced in a speech Friday. That speech came at the demand of lawmakers, who insisted the president give an emergency report on the state of the union. Gorbachev's proposals aim to calm growing discontent over the country's collapsing economy and the increasing rebelliousness among the republics, all but one of which have made declarations of sovereignty. ``I appeal to citizens of all 15 republics to support these undelayable measures,'' Gorbachev said today. The separatist movement must be stopped, he said. ``We cannot break up (the union). We cannot go down this path.'' Gorbachev did not make it clear whether he could implement the proposals on his own or if they needed ratification by Soviet lawmakers. But Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet, told legislators that the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, which meets next month, would have to approve any constitutional amendments for government restructuring. Under Gorbachev's proposals, the Council of Ministers headed by Ryzhkov would be replaced by several bodies under direct presidential control. The principal ruling body would be the Federation Council, which would include representatives of the republics. Legislators generally welcomed the proposed elimination of Ryzhkov's job, but unless the republics agree to join the Federation Council, the restructuring is unlikely to solve the paralysis of power in the country. Initial reaction from some republics was negative. An Estonia lawmaker said her republic and the two other Baltic states of Latvia and Lithuania would not join the council. ``We will not take part in any old or new institution which is an institution of federation,'' Marju Lauristin, deputy speaker of Estonia's parliament, told reporters. She suggested the restructuring was an attempt to establish a dictatorship. ``It is concentrating all power in the economy in politics in military affairs in one (person's) hands,'' she said. The Baltics have said that their incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 was illegal and have launched independence drives. Gorbachev said the Federation Council, formed in March, would be strengthened and would meet more regularly. ``Out of a consultative body it should be transformed into an effective structure to coordinate the efforts of the center and the republics,'' he said. Many republics have nullified national legislation and presidential decrees and have declared their laws supreme. The new structure was designed to end such conflicts. Ryzhkov told reporters he had no idea what new role he might have in the new structure, and said he learned of it only 20 minutes before Gorbachev's speech. But he said his job was being eliminated. ``I understood that the position of chairman of the Council of Ministers won't exist. There will be presidential rule, a presidential Cabinet,'' Ryzhkov said. Politicians, demonstrators and commentators have demanded Ryzhkov's resignation for at least a year. Yeltsin has said the country cannot solve its economic crisis as long as Ryzhkov and his Cabinet were in place. Asked if he were willing to remain in a government job, Ryzhkov told reporters, ``I will work as long as the people need me.'' Ryzhkov, 61, was appoined head of the Council of Ministers in September 1985. Previously, he was director of the Uralmash machine building complex in the Ural Mountains city of Sverdlovsk. The Federation Council, comprised of the leaders of the 15 republics and headed by Gorbachev, has been meeting only sporadically and has not taken a major role in policy-making. Gorbachev said that with the strengthening of the Federation Council, the 18-member Presidential Council, created last March to implement domestic and foreign policy, would be eliminated. To strengthen law and order, which many Soviets have complained is breaking down, Gorbachev said that presidential representatives will be appointed and sent to regions of the country. Under recent constitutional amendments, Gorbachev has the power to impose direct presidential rule in restive areas of the country. The Soviet leader appeared to be moving closer to this step with the announcement of the stationing of his representatives in those areas.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes For Return of Communist Property to State
DOC.TEXT: Communist deputies stalked out of Parliament as legislators overwhelmingly approved a bill turning Communist Party property over to the state, Czechoslovak media reported today. All but one Communist lawmaker left the Parliament session in protest, refusing to take part in Friday night's vote, the Lidove Noviny daily reported. The state CTK news agency said the measure was approved by 101 of the 103 deputies present and voting in the House of the People. One deputy voted against it and one abstained. In the second chamber, the House of Nations, 52 of 55 deputies present and voting in the Slovak chamber cast ballots in favor. All 55 Czech deputies approved the new law. The measure was introduced in the house Friday by Deputy Premier Pavel Rychetsky, who stressed that the party's debts to society ``are much higher than the value of the property that is now under discussion.'' Last month, the government proposed seizing all Communist Party property without compensation, in a move pointing to growing anger at the former rulers at a time of economic hardship. Czechoslovak media said last month that Communist property is worth about $237.5 million, a year after the peaceful revolution that ended Communist rule. Government officials said Communist assets totaled $512 million before the revolution. The Communists themselves valued their remaining property at $94 million. The government froze party assets on May 18, starting the process of gradual transfer of property to the new authorities. Party property includes many buildings, communications equipment, recreation centers, newspapers, and other assets. Several Communist deputies called for ammendments to the bill and others rejected it. Miroslav Ransdorf, a deputy of the Communist Party of Slovakia, charged the bill was aimed at distracting attention from the economic crisis, weakening the opposition, and boosting the flagging prestige of the Civic Forum movement. Ransdorf also charged that the bill was designed to destroy the Communist Party economically, Lidove Noviny reported. President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum and its sister organization in Slovakia, Public Against Violence, are the largest groupings in Parliament and the senior partners in the government coalition. Political differences within the Civic Forum over whether it should continue as a loose movement encompassing a wide spectrum of political views or become a political party have hurt its popularity. Czechoslovaks go to the polls next weekend to vote in municipal elections. Prior to the formal voting, all Communist deputies except Miroslav Jansta, left the assembly. ``The Communists have given up their leading role and ideology more easily than their property,'' Lidove Noviny commented. The Communist party voted last November, after huge anti-government street demonstrations, to drop from the constitution the party's guaranteed leading role, which had ensured its domination of society and politics for 41 years.

DOC.HEAD: Hussein Criticizes U.S. Policies on Persian Gulf, Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with with color, additional quotes. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein, who has been reluctant to side with the West in the Persian Gulf crisis, today harshly criticized the United States for applying what he called double standards in the Persian Gulf crisis. Addressing the opening session of Parliament, the king suggested any solution to the gulf standoff should be linked to the Arab-Israeli conflict. Iraq's Saddam Hussein has taken the same position. The Jordanian monarch also assailed the U.S.-led military buildup in the gulf region, and told lawmakers he hoped Jordan's strained relations with Saudi Arabia and other gulf states could be mended soon. State-run Jordan television and radio carried the king's 40-minute address live. Government offices declared today an unofficial holiday and allowed employees for voluntary leave if they wished to attend the parliamentary session. The 80-member Chamber of Deputies, elected a year ago in nationwide general elections, met jointly with the 40-member Senate to hear the speech. The king spoke from his throne, wearing a black-and-gold ceremonial military uniform. Jordan has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait but also is seeking an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, captured from Jordan in 1967. The territories are land claimed by the Palestinians. ``This duality ... forces us to inquire why there has been incessant refusal to link the two crises despite the fact that resolutions have been adopted by the United Nations,'' he said. The king, facing an economic crunch as a result of the gulf crisis, renewed an appeal for financial assistance from gulf states, formerly his main financial backers, as well as emergency aid from the international community. Jordan's relations with gulf states suffered because it dragged its feet in complying with the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. The Amman government says it now enforces the embargo except for crude oil that Jordan receives. Jordanian officials say their economy would be crippled without the Iraqi oil, which is a form of debt payment, pegged at $16 a barrel. In apparent reference to the United States and its allies in the anti-Iraq coalition, Hussein accused unnamed world powers of ``blatant and shameless conduct'' in the gulf region, saying greed was their main motive. ``Their actual goals stem from the desire to control our destiny and the Arab nation's resources,'' he said. Criticizing the military buildup in the region, he denounced ``unyielding positions and economic strangulation in the gulf.'' He attacked the West's ``complacent stand toward Israeli aggression while assuming the role of defenders of international legitimacy and human rights.'' The king also affirmed he would continue to support the Palestine Liberation Organization ``in all possible ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Ambush Hindus, Killing Nine
DOC.TEXT: Four Sikh militants armed with AK-47 assault rifles opened fire on a group of Hindu fundamentalists exercising in a Punjab park today, killing 10 men and wounding 10, police said. Four of the wounded were in serious condition after the early morning attack in Quillewali, 120 miles south of Amritsar, a center of the Sikh separatist movement. Four of the wounded were in serious condition. The Sikhs fired on about 25 people from the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or the National Self-reliance Group, according to Swaran Singh, senior superintendent of the district police headquarters at Faridkot. He said the victims were from Dhalbhwali town, which is separated from Quillewali by a state highway. They had assembled in the park for the daily physical training exercises mandatory for members of the Hindu group. Singh said the gunmen, who drove up in a red car, escaped. The Self-reliance group aims to establish a Hindu India and is an affiliate of the right-wing political party, the Bharatiya Janata. It was the fifth attack on members of the group since 1988. In the worst attack, 23 Hindus were killed in Punjab's Moga town in June 1989. Four other attacks on the group took place in 1988. Sikh militants have killed 2,790 people so far this year in Punjab, a rich farming state where they have fought since 1982 to establish an independent nation for members of their faith. Sikhs have a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab, which adjoins Haryana state on the east and Pakistan on the west. Nationwide, Sikhs comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Sikh separatists claim political and economic discrimination by Hindus, who comprise 82 percent of the national population.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: be justified.
DOC.TEXT: Sixth, on the Union Treaty, the common denominator of our approach and our understanding is that the union must be renovated and preserved. There were speeches with or without references to Lenin yesterday: first divide, then unite. If what is meant, and Comrade Boiko is quite correct here, is a division of competence and powers, qualitative renovation of the entire system of vertical and horizontal relationships, I think it would be supported by all of us, including me personally. But I am categorically against a fragmentation of the state, a redesigning of territorial divisions, destroying centuries-old relationships of people. It is easier for me to say this now: our own bitter experience tinged with the blood of our citizens has, I think, taught us that we cannot separate. (Applause) That is why we must not embark on that road. Without delay and with all due attention, we must tackle the division of powers and authority, implement everything that is contained in our concept of renovating our multi-ethnic state. If there is oxygen, the health of all nations will be good. I think that the Supreme Soviet must speak out in favor of it, and the people must be informed about its position. The draft of the Union Treaty is basically ready. We will submit it as soon as possible to the Supreme Soviet of the Union and the Supreme Soviets of republics. And don't let us be intimidated by the newly emerging fighters for sovereignty, who say that the people are saying (so and so). The people should be asked first. (Applause) It was done in the Ukraine at the most critical periods, and there were never less than 70 percent of those who supported preserving and renovating the union. The same happens everywhere. I am even now getting reports from Georgia. They were very concerned when they heard statements that ties are being torn that it took centuries to establish. Seventh, I think it necessary to stress once again the importance of giving more attention to the problems of the army, to social security of the members of the military and their families. The army is the child of the people. I am repeating the formula which has provided our point of reference for years. Once again I am appealing to the Supreme Soviet to make laws without delay to make it possible for the army to perform its functions and to ensure the prestige of those who safeguard the security of our state. Eighth, it is our duty to help maximum coordination and interaction of soviets. It obviously follows from yesterday's discussion that neither the Supreme Soviet nor local soviets can operate efficiently without the closest coordination and interaction. It is in the interests of our common cause that we reject confrontation, fruitless competition. Comrades, the proposed tasks are aimed at the fulfillment of our strategic goals, further progress of democratic changes in the country. I am appealing to the citizens of all 15 republics to support this program of practical measures, which outline organizational prerequisites for the fulfillment of decisions that have been taken. None of the decisions should be allowed to be suspended, and I, as president, will concern myself with their exact implementation. I am hoping to get the support of all those who are interested in the success of the common cause, the cooperation of all national groups in the country, all creative forces who hold close to their hearts the goals of all-union accord, civic peace, stability without which we will be unable to move further. And those who will oppose these feelings of the people must be defeated politically. (Applause) I am appealing to communists to use all opportunities opportunities to energetically support measures for economic, political and legal stability. I am inviting the cooperation of all public organizations and movements which value the destiny of our motherland. Mass media workers should rethink their role. In other words, let's stop spreading discord and panic, let's proceed to construction. Our future lies only in energetic movement ahead, in achieving the common goals we set ourselves. I appeal to the Supreme Soviet to support these proposals. (Applause)
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
Bush Vows Support for Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Minor editing throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, celebrating the first anniversary of the revolution that toppled Czechoslovakia's communist rule, promised this struggling nation today that ``we will not fail you in this decisive moment.'' ``America will stand with you,'' he vowed in a speech to the Federal Assembly just hours after arriving here for the first ever U.S. presidential visit and again to a rally in Wenceslas Square, site of many turning points in Czechoslovakia's turbulent history. Bush also vowed the West would not leave Eastern Europe in a military ``no man's land.'' Bush also tied the past year of revolution in Europe to the crisis in the Persian Gulf, saying ``I have this feeling in my heart that no peoples understand better what is at stake in the gulf than Czechs and Slovaks.'' ``You know from your own bitter experience that the world cannot turn a blind eye to aggression. You know the futility and vain hope that aggressors can be appeased,'' he said. President Vaclav Havel said Czechoslovakia's own history ``has taught us ample lessons about the consequences of appeasement.'' One-third of Czechoslovakia's territory was ceded in 1938 to the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent Adolf Hitler from conquering other countries. ``It is necessary to resist evil, it is necessary to resist aggression,'' the one-time dissident said. Bush also said the United States would not leave the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe dangling with no security. ``We do not want to see Czechoslovakia, Poland, and Hungary off in some kind of no man's land,'' he said, now that the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact has turned into a political rather than military alliance. Bush said the United States has ``an enormous stake'' in the security of Eastern Europe, a subject that will be addressed in a summit next week of 34 nations in Paris. Bush said he and Havel did not discuss future security arrangements in any detail, although he did say it came up. He suggested the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the group sponsoring next week's Paris summit, would take a more active role in determining Europe's direction in the post Cold War era. The two leaders were wrapped in heavy topcoats against the overcast chill of the Prague afternoon. At the rally, more than 100,000 people crowded into Wenceslas Square and down its long rectangular boulevard to hear Bush and Havel, who laid wreaths at a popular shrine to those who died under communism. Havel said his nation still faces difficult struggles in trying to move from a communist to a capitalist society. He said ``the fact remains that dissatisfaction, nervousness, insecurity and disillusionment are widespread in our society.'' Bush, by contrast, was upbeat. ``Czechoslovakia's revolution is over,'' Bush said. ``Its renaissance has just begun. ... Your nation, like your neighbors to the north and south, faces the unprecedented task for building stable democratic rule and a prosperous market economy on the ruins of totalitarianism.'' The president declared, ``I am here to say that we will not fail you in this decisive moment.'' He said final agreement was reached today allowing Czechoslovakia to enjoy the benefits of most-favored-nation trade status, permitting it to deal with the United States at the lowest possible tariffs and import fee rates. Bush said he also would ask Congress for $60 million to create a fund to spur U.S. investment here. Moreover, Bush said funds to help build the private sector would be drawn from the $370 million already committed for Central and Eastern Europe for the coming year. Noting that Czechoslovakia and its neighbors are braced for seere energy problems, Bush said he had asked the International Monetary Fund to lend up to $5 billion in 1991 to Central and Eastern Europe. The World Bank will commit an additional $9 billion over the next three years, Bush said. On a political note, Bush said he agrees that Prague should be the home of the permanent secretariat of the CSCE, the loosely-defined 34-nation assembly that served as a forum for East-West talks during the Cold War. ``It is right that this city - once on the fault line of Cold War and conflict - now at the heart of the new and united Europe - play a central role as the CSCE seeks to expand the frontiers of freedom in Europe,'' Bush said. Bush, setting out on an eight-day trip to Europe and the Middle East, arrived here to a 21-gun salute. American and Czechoslovak flags snapped in the wind in the courtyard of The Castle, where Havel and Bush held talks. A military honor guard stood resplendent in new navy uniforms modeled on the garb of West Point, replacing the drab green Soviet-style uniforms of the communist era. Clusters of well-wishers, many of them waving American flags, stood along the streets of Prague to greet Bush. Prague was the first stop on a journey that also will take the president to Germany, a 34-nation summit in Paris, a Thanksgiving Day visit with troops in Saudi Arabia and talks in Cairo with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``This wide-ranging trip will take us from the salons of Europe to the sands of Saudi Arabia,'' Bush said in a statement. ``Each stop is meant to bolster the peace, freedom and prosperity that Americans enjoy and for which we should give thanks throughout the year.'' The centerpiece of the visit to Europe will be the signing on Monday of a treaty slashing non-nuclear weapons, the most sweeping agreement in history to reduce weapons arsenals. Yet, Bush said the highlight of the whole trip would be spending the Thanksgiving holiday with U.S. forces. Upwards of 250,000 American troops have been deployed to the gulf and Bush has ordered an additional 200,000 to go there to be ready for a possible war with Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Ryzhkov Took On Bureaucracy That Brought Him To Power
With Soviet-Politics, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who would lose his job in the government overhaul proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, set ambitious goals when he took the post in 1985. One of his first and toughest tasks was to trim the bloated bureacracy inherited from the ``era of stagnation'' under the leadership of Leonid I. Brezhnev. Gorbachev initiated the political and economic restructuring known as ``perestroika'' shortly after he became leader in 1985, and Ryzhkov was a key lieutenant in implementing reforms. But the 61-year-old prime minister has not always agreed with his boss. ``Sometimes I clashed with him on practical issues,'' he said in an interview last summer with the magazine Arguments and Facts. During his five-year tenure, Ryzhkov eliminated 25 ministries and dozens of other central officers were dismantled. In the interview, he described efforts to pare down the entrenched bureaucracy as ``a battle royal.'' Nevertheless, it was the same bureaucracy that he climbed through to reach the post considered the second most powerful in the country. Ryzhkov was born on Sept. 28, 1929, to a miner's family. After graduating from the Urals Polytechnical Institute with a degree in engineering, he began working in 1950 at the giant Uralmash machine-building complex in Sverdlovsk. Twenty years later he became its director-general. He joined the Communist Party in 1956 and became active in politics with his appointment to the Supreme Soviet Commission on Planning and Budget in 1974. In 1981, he became a full member of the party's Central Committee. In 1985, six weeks after Gorbachev became general secretary, Ryzhkov was appointed a full member of the Communist Party Politburo. He was named chairman of the Council of Ministers in September of that year. During his first years as prime minister, Ryzhkov was largely regarded as a faceless technocrat until he took control of a high-profile Politburo commission overseeing relief efforts for victims of the December 1988 earthquake in Armenia. ``Thanks to his TV image, many thought Ryzhkov a soft and irresolute man,'' the Novosti news agency said in a 1989 profile. ``That was so until the Armenian earthquake at the end of last year. The world then saw another man. The mask of reservation fell to reveal frankness and undisguised passionate pity.'' But his popularity proved short-lived. Blame for the abysmal economic conditions sweeping the country was laid at his feet. For the past year, Supreme Soviet lawmakers, demonstrators and intellectuals have demanded the resignation of Ryzhkov and his government. ``Almost each parliamentary session over the past year began with demands for the resignation of the government, and this session hears the same demand,'' Ryzhkov told lawmakers Saturday. ``All this prevents the normal functioning of the supreme executive power body,'' he said. ``The atmosphere created around the government, in fact, dooms its decisions to non-implementation.'' Ryzhkov appeared philosophical about the imminent demise of his job, saying he only learned of Gorbachev's proposals 20 minutes before they were presented to the Supreme Soviet. ``I understood that the position of chairman of the Council of Ministers won't exist. There will be presidential rule, a presidential Cabinet,'' he said. The job of vice president, included in the Gorbachev proposal, was not offered to him, Ryzhkov said. Despite the uncertainty of his future, Ryzhkov said he supported Gorbachev's restructuring plans. But, he said, things will be just as tough under the new setup as they were under his government. ``It will be just as hard for them as us, because our life is such,'' Ryzhkov said. ``We really are at a pivotal stage when the old structure is still being broken down and the new one is being born.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
Baker Sounds Out Foreign Ministers on Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs new to UPDATE with Baker comments, picks up 5th graf pvs; ``At the end...
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today his talks with three African nations yielded positive results in lining up support for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Zaire's foreign minister, Kalimba Wakatana Mushobekwa, said his government would back such a resolution if it were introduced in the United Nations Security Council. ``Yes, we support it,'' he told reporters. Baker also met with the foreign ministers of Ethiopia and the Ivory Coast before heading to Paris to lobby the foreign ministers of Romania, Finland, Britain and the Soviet Union on the proposed resolution. ``I think we've had a positive day consulting with other members of the (Security) Council,'' Baker said but refused to elaborate. ``I don't want to get into the business of counting votes here or predicting results or anything like that. But we've had some good meetings today,'' he said. At the end of the weekend Baker will have met with foreign ministers of eight of the 15 nations that are members of the Security Council, where a resolution on the use of force would have to be approved. Baker has maintained that the United States has not yet decided if it will seek the resolution, which would authorize the use of military force to get Iraq out of Kuwait if peaceful means failed. ``I haven't seen a draft resolution yet,'' he said here Saturday. Even so, the United States appears prepared to circulate by the end of the month the resolution in the Security Council as a last resort to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, which it has occupied since Aug. 2. U.S. officials have said they would like to introduce the resolution this month while holding the chairmanship of the Security Council. Diplomats at the United Nations said Baker is lobbying foreign ministers from the Security Council nations to vote in person on any use-of-force resolution. The ministers would lend weight to the resolution and bolster the image of allied unity if they turned out for the vote, since they seldom occupy their countries' seats on the council except in very grave situations. ``Are we now, on the margins of the council, discussing a new resolution that would turn the screws on Saddam Hussein? The answer is yes,'' Canadian Ambassador Yves Fortier said Friday. Thirteen foreign ministers attended Sept. 25 when the council voted 14-1 to expand its economic embargo to include specifically all air cargo traffic in or out of Iraq and Kuwait. However, most were already in New York for the General Assembly's first week of debate and the World Children's Summit. Several foreign ministers attended the July 1987 Security Council meeting that adopted the cease-fire and peace plan for the Iran-Iraq war, Resolution 598. Baker has already conferred with Joe Clark, Canada's external affairs minister, and broached the idea of the foreign ministers coming to New York, according to Fortier. ``The Americans ... may wish to stress the importance of the meeting by holding it at the ministerial level,'' Fortier said. America and the Soviet Union both have drafted ``use of force'' resolutions, according to diplomats in New York and Washington officials. ``There are a number of concepts that are in play,'' Fortier said. Diplomats say the U.S. version would contain some kind of ultimatum; it would refer to authorizing use of force at some point in the near future, when economic sanctions on Baghdad have tightened. European diplomats who saw the Soviet document say it would put heavy reliance on the so-far passive Military Staff Committee of the Security Council. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. That committee's function, under the U.N. Charter, is to ``advise and assist'' on its military requirements, including ``the employment and command of forces placed at its disposal.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Ershad Protesters Rampage through Dhaka
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government demonstrators rampaged through the capital today setting fire to several vehicles, stoning a Cabinet minister's house and burning an effigy of the president. Police fired tear gas and used steel-tipped batons to disperse crowds, who hurled stones and small home-made bombs at security forces. Amanullah Aman, head of Dhaka University's student union, said 25 people were injured, including five shot by Ershad supporters armed with pistols and sawed-off shotguns. His claim could not be immediately confirmed. Most protesters were students who support opposition parties. The opposition launched a new round of strikes and rallies to demand the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, who took power in a military coup in 1982. He was elected president in 1986 and plans to run again in 1991. The opposition parties have refused to participate in future elections unless Ershad resigns, claiming his last election was rigged. At least eight people have been shot and killed by police since the latest round of protests began five weeks ago. Groups of 100 to 300 people roamed the streets, chanting ``down with Ershad'' and ``no election under a dictator.'' ``My government is determined to crush the anarchic and terrorist activities that have been let loose in the country,'' Ershad told about 8,000 supporters at a rally a mile from the main trouble spots. Without elaborating, the president said: ``Some outsiders are behind the current troubles. They will be wiped out by the people.'' The rally was one of nine scheduled over the next few days in Dhaka by Ershad's Jatiya Party to counter what it called ``anarchy and terrorism launched by the opposition.'' But the pro-government rallies only heightened the tension in this city of 7 million people. Anti-Ershad demonstrators ransacked a platform erected for a Jatiya Party rally near the 5-star Sheraton Hotel, United News of Bangladesh said. University students had called for a siege of Cabinet ministers' homes, but police set up barbed wire barricades on streets leading to the official residences in the center of the city. The trouble started when about 1,000 protesters tried to break through the barricades. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the crowd, which split into smaller groups and roamed the streets. The protesters burned an effigy of Ershad near the National Press Club and hurled stones at the residence of Irrigation Minister Ghulam Mostafa, United News of Bangladesh said. Several cars were burned. Reporters saw about a dozen protesters rounded up by police near Dhaka University campus. At least three police motorbikes, a jeep and a minibus were set afire by the protesters, reporters at the scenes said. The campaign for Ershad's resignation is led Bangladesh's two biggest opposition parties - Sheik Hasina's Awami League and Khaleda Zia's Bangladesh Nationalist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Thirsty Hippos to Get Water From Dam
DOC.TEXT: The government announced it will bore holes in a small dam to provide water for hippos stranded in a drought-stricken section of South Africa. The Department of Water had earlier refused to take action to save the hippos living on a patch of land near the Limpopo River, saying releasing water from the nearby dam could hurt industry in the area. On Friday, it announced a change of heart and said experts would begin the project in the northern Transvaal on Monday. Private donations will cover the cost, the department said. The entire country has been hit by a severe drought and higher than normal temperatures, and wild animals have been invading farms in search of water. The northern Transvaal, in the northeastern part of the country, is among the areas hardest hit. Forecasters say no significant rainfall is expected soon.

DOC.HEAD: Pierre Braunberger, Film Producer, Dead At 85
DOC.TEXT: Pierre Braunberger, who produced the first films of Jean Renoir and Luis Bunuel during a 67-year career in cinema, has died, his family said. He was 85. His family said he died late Friday. The cause of death was not disclosed. Braunberger entered the film industry in 1922 and two years later became a producer of silent movies. He produced Renoir's first film, ``Catherine,'' and Bunuel's first film, ``The Andalusian Dog,'' as well as works by such renowned directors as Alain Resnais, Jean-Luc Godard and Claude Berri. His most recent production was ``Knights of the Round Table'' in 1989. In 1980, he received an honorary Cesar, the French equivalent of the Oscars awarded in Hollywood. Braunberger married in 1964 and had two sons. Information about funeral arrangements was not immediately released.

DOC.HEAD: Last 100 Days Have Been Rough for Sudanese Junta
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Events of the last 100 days have cost impoverished Sudan the support of Egypt, the United States and wealthy gulf Arab countries. Basically all that's left are handouts from Moammar Gadhafi's Libya. The isolation comes as it becomes increasingly likely Sudan will face a famine that Western relief officials say could threaten up to 11 million people. Sudan's troubles began when Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's military government found itself on the other side of the Persian Gulf crisis from its most important friends. Paying back old political and military debts, el-Bashir's junta refused to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. That alienated most of Khartoum's friends, who are demanding that Iraq quit Kuwait. Traditionally, the Sudanese could rely on its big brother to the north, Egypt, to bail it out of trouble. For two decades, food and other aid from the United States and the West have kept the country going through flood, famine and political turmoil. And Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, the first now a bitter enemy and the second an occupied country, had provided hundreds of millions of dollars to help develop an agricultural potential once considered the greatest in Africa. One of the junta's few allies since the invasion has been Gadhafi, the Libyan strongman. He's promised to shore up Sudan's tottering Central Bank with $100 million. He's sent 40,000 sacks of cement to restore schools damaged by floods in 1988. He's pledged to build a system of paved highways in Khartoum, a sprawling, dusty city of mainly dirt roads. Additionally, Col. Youssef Abdul Fatah, Khartoum's deputy commissioner, said Libya donated ``10 huge electricity generators to be used in emergencies and to help in pumping water to some of the capital's districts.'' Welcome as it is, such largesse does little to make up for the loss of Western and Arab support.
