The invasion cost Sudan at least $2 billion in lost remittances from 20,000 workers who were brought home from Iraq and Kuwait by the Sudanese government. The minister of expatriate affairs, al-Saeed Osman Mahjoub, said the repatriated people suffered at least $500 million in ``personal losses'' like abandoned belongings in Kuwait and Iraq. And the junta's economics overseer, Col. Salah al-Deen Karar, told the official Sudan News Agency the country is being ignored. ``We've notified international organizations of our losses and demanded to be treated on an equal footing with countries economically affected by the gulf crisis'' like Jordan and Egypt, he said. But the world is proving unsympathetic to demands that Khartoum be compensated for dislocations to the economy. The message is that Sudan made an uncomfortable bed by siding with Iraq, but it will have to lie in it. In October, Sudan invited Gadhafi as guest of honor at a ceremony announcing the country's future system of government. Not surprisingly, it resembles closely the Libyan ``jamahiriya'' based on Gadhafi's theory that people should rule themselves through mass meetings, not through elected representatives. The junta's debt to Gadhafi was so great that he was allowed to suggest on national television, unchallenged, that ``religion should be distanced from politics. ... If brought together they spoil each other.'' Sudan's basic law is the Islamic Sharia, a 1,400-year-old legal and ethical code. And junta leader el-Bashir is a devout Moslem with leanings toward the fundamentalist National Islamic Front, although it like other political parties has been banned since his coup on June 30, 1989. In the same speech, Gadhafi told the Sudanese a northeast African merger of their country, Egypt and Libya could become a great world power. He attacked the West for laughing at his ideas. During his October visit, Gadhafi also threatened to intervene in Sudan's drawn-out and expensive southern civil war unless the rebels stop fighting. The junta clings to the hope of a solution by force and last month once again used the food weapon, bombing foodstocks to starve the rebels. The decision drew criticism from the United States and other governments who earlier ignored similar activities by both sides. Possibly the decision hardest to explain is the junta's adamant refusal to acknowledge that famine stalks the countryside again, even after a governor in western Sudan declared his region a disaster area. The denial instigated another fight with Washington and made Western relief officials seethe. Without a government appeal, famine relief cannot be organized.

DOC.HEAD: CSCE Summit Will Launch New Era of European Peace
DOC.TEXT: Newly united in a shared belief in democracy, Europe is leaving behind the hostility of the Cold War and embarking on what it hopes will be an era of peace and prosperity. This week's summit in Paris of 34 nations - the United States, Soviet Union, Canada and all of Europe except isolationist Albania attending only as an observer - has been compared to the 1815 Congress of Vienna that drew the map of 19th century Europe. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas bills the meeting as ``the most significant international event since 1945.'' That year World War II ended, leaving Europe devastated and millions dead. Iron Curtain division soon added to the destruction, splitting the continent in half. For most of the next 40 years, communist East and capitalist West locked in struggle to defend their ideals. One of the few institutions that brought the Soviet Union, United States, Canada and Europe together was the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or CSCE, a loose grouping born with the signing of the 1975 Helsinki human rights accord. Subsequent meetings in Belgrade, Madrid and Vienna strengthened the human rights commitments and security provisions of that act, spurring demands for freedom in Eastern Europe. It is fitting that it is the CSCE that will now seal the demise of the Cold War and sketch the outlines of a new Europe governed by trust in the rule of law and a free market. On Monday, the leaders of NATO and the six nations of the crumbling Warsaw Pact will sign a historic accord slashing arsenals of tanks, helicopters and other conventional weapons. New rules known as confidence-building measures will be adopted to ensure that Europe's armies know more about each other than ever before, reducing or even eliminating the danger of surprise attack. The two military alliances that armed Europe to the teeth for 40 years will also sign a formal non-aggression pact. To underline the shift from armed suspicion to dialogue, the leaders will put CSCE proceedings on a more permanent footing by: - Agreeing that the heads of member states and governments meet at least once every two years, their foreign ministers annually and senior officials even more often. - Setting up a small secretariat in Prague, a center for the prevention of conflict in Vienna and an office in Warsaw to help monitor elections. For diplomats like John Maresca, U.S. ambassador to the negotiations on confidence-building measures in Vienna, this marks the end of a long road that began 18 years ago with the arduous negotiation of the 1975 Helsinki Final Act. By enshrining human rights in a document signed by the Kremlin and its allies, it provided Western governments and Soviet and East European dissidents with a legal right to fight for more freedom in the Soviet bloc. ``It contained the seeds of what happened last year'' with Eastern Europe's revolutions, Maresca said. No one expected such sharp, sudden change, he said, but ``basically, that was the objective.'' Now, some of the former dissidents, like Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel and Polish Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, will be in Paris to decide where CSCE should go from here in building a united continent linked to North America and the Soviet Union. One idea, outlined in the landmark declaration that ended NATO's London summit in July, is for an Assembly of Europe, a kind of CSCE parliament. In three days of public speeches and a 90-minute closed-door session allowing freer discussion, the leaders may decide to encourage their parliaments to set up this European assembly. It is unlikely, however, that any such assembly - or other possible measures, such as an alliance to alleviate the East's energy woes - will prove an instant panacea for Europe's remaining ills. The CSCE adopts all decisions by consensus, a mechanism Maresca says serves to protect ``the essential interests'' of all members, from the tiny Vatican and Luxembourg to the mighty superpowers. That means painstaking negotiation to overcome any rift. The United States and the European Community, who are supposed to issue a declaration of alliance at the Paris summit, are sharply divided over trade issues, with the Americans arguing the Europeans must slash their massive farm subsidies. Nationalist tensions and economic woes compounded by the Persian Gulf crisis threaten the fragile democracies of Eastern Europe, whose economies are still dependent on supplies from the increasingly fragmented Soviet Union. Some Western countries, most notably Britain, are still rent by internal discord over policy toward Europe. The role of dominant Germany is also of concern. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Bonn's foreign minister since 1974, was, in the words of a Bonn diplomat, ``one of the spiritual fathers of the CSCE process.'' Aware that CSCE offered a chance for German unity, Genscher always gave the process the high profile it lacked, for example, in the United States. In the days preceding the Paris summit, newly united Germany - firmly anchored in NATO and the EC - signed accords with Moscow and Poland that guaranteed its present borders but also underlined its pivotal role as the partner of East and West. The Paris speech of Chancellor Helmut Kohl will be a test of how Germany intends to wield its new might and live up to promises it will now shoulder more global responsibilities. ``This special conference ... marks the final overcoming of the East-West conflict,'' Kohl's spokesman Hans Klein said. ``It will introduce a new epoch in European history.''

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Visits School, Prague Sights
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush visited a primary school in downtown Prague on Saturday, joking with children that her dog Millie knows more about high matters of state than she does. ``Millie sits in the National Security Council meetings every morning,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``She probably knows more about the Persian Gulf and Czechoslovakia than I do,'' she told a class of 11-and 12-year-olds studying English at a special school. Mrs. Bush, accompanying her husband on the first presidential visit to Czechoslovakia, arrived at the school with Olga, the wife of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel. The 20 children treated them first to a traditional Czech folk welcome gift of bread and salt, presented by two girls in embroidered national costume. Then the children showed off their knowledge of English in a small play that reflected the general air of expectation surrounding the Bush visit to this central European nation. The performance featured a detective called Hot Dog who was trying to find out why so many people had gathered around the school. Eventually, his American counterpart, named Cool Cat, told him it was because Mrs. Bush was coming. Mrs. Bush presented her book, including photographs of President Bush playing with the dog in the White House's garden, and told the children she loves working on her computer, gardening and reading. She also advised the children to go to the institute for mentally handicapped children she visited earlier, saying that they should go there to see ``how lucky you are.'' The Institute for Social Care of Youth provides treatment for 126 mentally handicapped children. In a classroom of 10 severely handicapped boys, two staff members helped youths to draw with colored pencils or water colors. ``Very nice, very nice,'' Mrs. Bush said as she examined the artwork admiringly. Most of the boys communicated in noises, not words. A 7-year-old boy named Michael, seeking attention from the first lady, was invited to say hello. He sat on a translator's lap and gave Mrs. Bush a kiss. Later, Mrs. Bush visited the historic Charles Bridge, the graceful structure that connects Prague's two most beautiful quarters either side of the Vltava River -- the Old Town, and the Lesser Town. Olga Havel, dressed in a quiet black and red check two-piece, again accompanied the American First Lady, together with a Prague historian who explained the history of a statue of St. Barbara on the bridge and some sights of the magnificent panorama around. ``I never thought I would be lucky enough to be here,'' Mrs. Bush told waiting journalists.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Seen Vital for Economy, as Well as Ecology
DOC.TEXT: Pollution is so bad in Eastern Europe that it is causing economic as well as environmental decay, an American researcher said in a report Saturday. Rivers are so foul they can't be used for industrial cooling and children become sickened by toxic chemicals in the air. Cleanup costs will be astronomical, and must be treated as an essential part of the region's economic recovery, argues Hilary French, a senior researcher at the Worldwatch Institute. ``Given the degraded environment's toll on human health and biological productivity, decontaminating Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is best seen as a precondition to economic development, not an obstacle,'' she writes. The study, ``Green Revolutions: Environmental Reconstruction in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union,'' was published Saturday by Worldwatch, a policy research organization based in Washington. Despite the report's catalog of horrors, it also voices optimism that significant improvement should be possible. ``The emergence of a fairly strong environmental movement there is certainly a very hopeful sign,'' Ms. French said in an interview. ``And the problems are severe enough that it is widely recognized that they'll have to be dealt with.'' She cites estimates by East European economists that Poland is losing 10 percent to 20 percent of its gross national product each year to environmental degradation and Czechoslovakia 5 percent to 7 percent. The health costs of pollution in those and other countries are also staggering, if difficult to pin down. ``Investments in environmental protection are thus virtually guaranteed to provide economic benefits,'' she writes. The difficulty, naturally, will be finding money for the environmental investments when other problems also cry out for cash. Poland's environment minister estimates that environmental projects could cost $20 billion over the next 10 to 20 years, and Czech officials believe they may have to spend $23.7 billion for pollution control over 15 years, according to the Worldwatch report. Ms. French also cites an estimate of $249 billion to $308 billion as the cost of bringing the environment of the former East Germany up to Western standards. ``Those numbers are imposing,'' she acknowledged. ``But that amount of spending has economic benefits of its own.'' The cleanup should create jobs, even as closing down hopelessly dirty and inefficient factories throws thousands of people out of work. In addition, the steps toward energy efficiency and waste reduction that will improve the environment are also essential to making the enterprises of what was the East Bloc globally competitive. ``Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have a unique opportunity to cull from 20 years of Western experience in addressing environmental problems,'' Ms. French writes. ``They could `leapfrog' the West in both policies and technologies.'' In turn, the East European cleanup could provide new insights on how to deal with West's worst pollution sites. Also, health research in Eastern Europe is likely to provide more information about hard-to-study links between human illness and toxic substances in the air and water. ``The reports that have come out are still not very scientific as far as associating effect with cause,'' Ms. French said. ``But you don't want to talk about East Europe as a laboratory, when there are human beings involved.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Pleads Innocent To Misconduct
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto pleaded not guilty today on a charge of misconduct and accused her successors of wrongdoing. ``I am innocent,'' Ms. Bhutto declared before a special court trying one of seven corruption cases against her. In the case before the court today, the 37-year-old is accused of approving the sale of 487 acres of federal land outside the capital of Islamabad for a luxury hotel and resort. The land was sold to a cousin of Ms. Bhutto's at rates far below market value, prosecutors say. After a three-hour hearing today, Ms. Bhutto defended the sale as a good decision because the capital had no facilities to house visiting dignitaries. ``Even today, I believe this is a good project,'' she said. Ms. Bhutto faces six similar charges before other special one-judge tribunals in Lahore and Karachi. Ms. Bhutto has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, claiming the cases are designed force her out of politics. Conviction on any one of the charges could cost her seat in Parliament and banish Ms. Bhutto from politics for as much as seven years. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, nepotism and abuse of power. She was replaced by a caretaker government comprised of opponents and former allies who filed corruption charges against her as well as members of her family and former administration. Last month, Ms. Bhutto and her left-leaning Pakistan People's Party were overwhelming defeated by the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance led by her fiercest opponent, Pakistan's new prime minister, Nawaz Sharif. Ms. Bhutto today accused Ishaq Khan and Sharif of using their influence obtain huge bank loans and then defaulting on repayment. ``Those who have defrauded billions of rupees have not been taken before the special tribunals, while I who served the people selflessly am forced to stand trial,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Child Killer Becomes First Tunisian Executed Since 1987
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of raping and murdering 13 children was hanged Saturday, Tunisia's first execution since a change of governments in 1987. The Justice Ministry said Naceur Ben Salah Allala Damerji was hanged at a Tunis prison after President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali rejected an appeal for clemency. Damerji first began his killing spree in 1986 and was arrested last year, authorities said. There had been no executions in Tunisia since Ben Ali took over from longtime President Habib Bourguiba in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Korea Retreating From Reform, U.S. Rights Group Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: South Korea has retreated from some of the democratic reforms it pledged prior to the 1988 Seoul Olympic Games, the U.S.-based human rights organization Asia Watch says. Despite promises, South Korea ``continues to deny the fundamental rights of workers, labor organizations, writers, publishers, opposition leaders and others,'' Asia Watch said in a 100-page report released during the weekend. The report, titled ``Retreat from Reform,'' focused on curbs against freedom of expression and worker rights. It said about half of South Korea's more than 1,000 political prisoners are workers and labor organizers. South Korean workers' desire for a larger share of the country's new prosperity has become a source of major conflict with government and industry leaders concerned that higher wages will hurt competitiveness and economic growth. Asia Watch also criticized President George Bush's administration for pursuing South Korean human rights issues through ``quiet diplomacy'' rather than publicly condemning abuses. This approach undermined the stated U.S. policy of encouraging democratization, it said. Bush should have spoken out on human rights at his White House meeting with President Roh Tae-woo last June, Asia Watch said, describing this as one of several lost opportunities. ``Retreat from Reform'' described South Korea's National Security Law as vaguely-worded and ``draconian.'' It urged revision of the law to ease curbs on dissent and free expression, with release of those detained for peaceful activity. Asia Watch accused the Roh government of a contradictory policy in promoting normalization and eventual unification with communist North Korea while punishing private citizens for advocating unification or making contacts with the north. This was described as ``an unacceptable limit on freedom of expression.'' South Korean labor laws and practices fell short of International Labor Organization standards of free bargaining and association, the report said, describing crackdowns on union activity in the Hyundai industrial group, the broadcasting and publishing industries and among public and private schoolteachers. Asia Watch is affiliated with Human Rights Watch, Helsinki Watch and other organizations that monitor rights set forth in the 1975 Helsinki East-West agreement. The organization also released a statement from the South Korean Justice Ministry branding ``Retreat from Reform'' as ``biased judgment.'' The ministry said Asia Watch ``heeded only the one-sided and superficial allegations by the lawbreakers'' who have perpetrated violent demonstrations and subversive activities ``inan attempt to overthrow the free and democratic system of the nation.'' It said the government makes ``utmost efforts to ensure due process of law'' and criticized ``misguided tendencies among some to falsely eulogize lawbreakers as `political prisoners' or `prisoners of conscience'.''

DOC.HEAD: West African Forces in Liberia Use Both Bombs and Leaflets
DOC.TEXT: Three rival armies have raped, looted and pillaged Liberia for 11 months, and there seems to be no end to the brutal civil war. An estimated 10,000 civilians have been killed and more than half the nation's 2.3 million people are refugees. Soldiers sent by five other West African countries to stop the fighting are using both bombs and propaganda leaflets in an attempt to persuade rebel leader Charles Taylor to end the war he started. It began Dec. 24, when Taylor led his rebels into Liberia from neighboring Ivory Coast to oust the government of President Samuel Doe, who was accused of corruption, human rights abuses and violent repression. Thousands of peasants, including children as young as 8, joined Taylor and overran most of the country. A dissident faction that broke with Taylor's National Patriotic Front captured Doe and tortured him to death in September. Then the 8,000-member West African force moved in with tanks and planes, drove Taylor's forces out of eastern Monrovia and stopped fighting in the capital. A Nigerian newspaper, the Lagos Guardian, said today the West African force had surrounded the rebel-held port of Buchanan and expected to take it within a week. After the West Africans reopened Monrovia's Spriggs Payne Airfield to helicopters and light aircraft this month, some members of an interim government were flown in. Taylor has his own administration in the interior and rejected the interim government, chosen by exiled Liberians. Amos Sawyer, a veteran leftist opposition leader who is president of the interim government, was shuttling among West African capitals last week in pursuit of a cease-fire. The other warring parties - the Liberian army and rebels led by Prince Johnson - have said they welcome the interim government and its mandate to organize fair elections. Interim government spokesman Edward Dunn said, however, that Johnson sent a letter threatening some of the ministers. Dunn, the government protocol officer, said Johnson warned some to stay away from Monrovia, including Baccus Matthews, the interim foreign minister, and Gbai Bala, a former adviser to Doe. Hundreds of Liberians have gathered on the docks of Freetown, Sierra Leone, hoping to follow the interim government home, apparently preferring the hardships of Monrovia to refugee camps where food also is scarce. President Joseph Momoh of Sierra Leone has said his government would not accept any more Liberian refugees unless more international aid was provided to take care of them. Two weeks ago, Momoh rejected a request sent through the U.S. Embassy that 160 children orphaned by the war be allowed into Sierra Leone. He also said the United States was not doing enough to help refugees despite its historic ties with Liberia. Freed American salves founded Liberia in 1847. They subjugated the natives and their descendants dominated the country until 1980, when Doe seized power in a coup. Africa Watch, an American human rights group, said in a report Oct. 26: ``Because past U.S. support for Doe played a major role in the destruction of the country today, the Bush administration has an important responsibility to do more to assist the victims of the conflict.'' ``All parties to the conflict have committed grave abuses of human rights against civilians,'' it said, and criticized the West African army for bombing raids that, according to survivors, have killed hundreds of civilians. The report criticized the multinational army for accepting into its ranks members of the Doe army and Johnson forces who agreed to a cease-fire in the civil war. European relief workers reported this month that food distribution had to be suspended temporarily in Monrovia, where hundreds of people have died of starvation, because army soldiers were stealing food from civilians. Since then, the West Africans have tried to talk the soldiers back into their barracks and the nearby presidential mansion, where they had been trapped by Johnson's forces. Some rebels continue to desert. West African leaflets dropped from planes urge them to give up ``this useless war.'' Taylor's radio station has broadcast orders that no fighters leave the front without written permission. The Ivory Coast, already sheltering thousands of Gio and Mano tribespeople who were the targets of Doe's soldiers, also has become a refuge for civilians of Doe's Krahn tribe. In its report, Africa Watch said Krahns were fleeing Grand Gedeh County, a Krahn stronghold on the Ivory Coast border, at a rate of 1,000 a day. Those who cross the border tell horror stories. ``I saw them kill a mother and her 3-year-old twins, and two others,'' a refugee teacher said. ``My two brothers are missing, and three other members of my family. I don't know where they are because we fled in all directions when the rebels attacked. So many people died that you don't have enough paper to write down all their names.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi General Warns West Would Face Toughter Fight Than It Thinks
DOC.TEXT: A top Iraqi general said Saturday that U.S.-led military forces would face ``uncalculated developments'' that would thwart any attack they launched to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. The warning came from Maj. Gen. Mundhir Abdul-Rahman, a missile expert and head of the Iraqi army's morale and guidance department. But it was difficult to determine whether the general was speaking in his capacity as a specialist in long-range weaponry - or as chief military morale booster. Writing in Al-Qadissiya, the army's daily newspaper, Abdul-Rahman questioned the value of Western air superiority if the aim was to take Iraqi territory. He said his country was prepared to defend itself despite plans to increase U.S. troop strength. U.S. officials announced earlier this month that another 200,000 U.S. troops would join the 230,000 Americans already deployed in the region. Britain's Independent newspaper reported Saturday that Iraq is believed to have assembled three so-called ``superguns'' able to fire shells a distance of more than 450 miles. U.S. intelligence sources believe the guns, largely assembled from British-made components, may have been delivered to Iraq before production of these exotic weapons was discovered earlier this year. In his article, Abdul-Rahman wrote: ``The surprise element by Iraq will make the American aggression face uncalculated developments and unexpected results in (Iraq's) reaction, which would make their execution of aggression according to its plans impossible.'' Iraq could come up with a military surprise that would not allow U.S.-led forces to ``manage the crisis the way they like,'' Abdul-Rahman said. The latest announced increase in American troop strength will raise the U.S. forces in the region to 430,000 soldiers, Marines, airmen and sailors - believed to be about equivalent to the number of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and their strategic reserve in southern Iraq. President Bush said the extra forces were was needed in case it became necessary to launch a military strike to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. Iraq overran the emirate on Aug. 2. Abdul-Rahman questioned the idea of a surgical air strike by the U.S.-led forces. Military experts say Western air power is technologically superior to Iraq's air strength of around 500-plus comat jets. The combined air power of the United States, Britain, France and their allies in the gulf region now totals more than 1,000 fighters and attack aircraft. ``Never in the past was the Air Force able to end war,'' Abdul-Rahman stressed, a point on which many western analysts agree. Abdul-Rahman said the balance in ground forces was in Iraq's favor with ``numerical superiority, war-tested experience'' and support weaponry. ``When the American administration launches its aggression, whether now or in the near future, it will go into a war with a position which has been made late and wrong in its strategic calculations. ``It will not be useful to send more troops to join the military buildup in the area to reverse that position,'' the general said. Iraqi officials have said that the underlying reason for the Western presence in the region was to try to knock President Saddam Hussein from power. They said the Western powers fear Iraq is becoming a military counterweight to Israel in the Middle East and that they want to dominate the region's oil resources. Before leaving Washington Friday on a tour that will take him to Europe and the Middle East, Bush said there is ``a ticking of the clock'' on the Gulf crisis. Al-Qadissiya was not the only Iraqi newspaper to advise the anti-Iraq alliance against military action. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, reported the government-run daily, Al-Jumhuriya, warned Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to ``stop using direct and indirect threats, assuring that Iraq possesses a lot of surprises.'' If there are such surprises in store, U.S. officials seem bent on uncovering them. Astronauts on a secret space shuttle mission on Friday deployed a surveillance satellite, according to sources at the U.S. space center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. Published reports have said the spacecraft will either eavesdrop on communications in the gulf or conduct photo surveys of Iraq and Kuwait. The satellite would be the latest in a fleet. At least 12 other reconnaisance, electronic surveillance, early-warning, meteorlogical and navigation satellites already relay data 24 hours a day. They include systems that can spot tank tracks in the desert and others that can give B-52 bombers greater accuracy.

DOC.HEAD: Where's The Beef? Army Promises `A Burger on Every Bayonet'
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Where's the beef? The Wolf burger makes its desert debut Sunday bringing a tasty morsel of Americana to front-line troops who are fed up with prepackaged Army chow. It may not come from the golden arches, or be a Whopper oozing with onions and catsup, but it's free. And so are the french fries, sodas, hot dogs and grilled cheese sandwiches that will be cooked on the U.S. military's version of a traveling fast-food stand - the Wolfmobile. It was the brainchild of Chief Warrant Officer Wes Wolf, 42, of Monterey, Calif., who dreamed up the idea in the middle of organizing Thanksgiving dinner for most of the 230,000 Americans in Operation Desert Shield. Maj. Gen. William ``Gus'' Pagonis, the U.S. Army's logistics chief, gave Wolf's name to the food-mobile, the military's treat for the GI fast-food junkie stranded in the sand dunes and surviving on cold rations, hot TV-style dinners and an occasional hot cooked meal. ``We have a generation of soldiers including myself that grew up on hamburgers and french fries, and so we're going to provide that,'' Pagonis said. ``Out in the desert, you're going to see these Wolfmobiles.'' The first Wolfmobile left Friday for the 1st Cavalry Division camped in the desert in eastern Saudi Arabia and the two Army cooks manning it will start grilling Wolfburgers and hot dogs on Sunday. Wolf said 80 Wolfmobile trucks were being dispatched to the desert, where they would move among the front-line units. Even if the Wolfmobiles can't get to every forward unit, Pagonis said, at least ``when the soldiers come back to their base camp they can get french fries and a hamburger.'' Much of the griping from Americans deployed here following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 has focused on food, and the complaints have been loudest from front-line units forced to eat more prepackaged combat rations. ``Gen. Pagonis insists that the soldiers in the desert receive the same quality food that we're giving to the soldiers back here in the rear,'' Wolf said. ``He doesn't care what is forward as far as equipment ... and he's very, very concerned about that.'' Short-order food is more popular than regular hot meals at Army bases in the states. So Wolf and Pagonis first decided to open a fast-food dining facility. It's called The Pentagon and is open nightly, serving pizza, hot dogs, hamburgers and chili, but it's only available to soldiers in rear-line units. Then it was time to take care of the soldiers in the desert. ``That's when we came up with the idea of a mobile-type truck,'' Wolf said. ``We thought, well there's no reason that we can't ... put a couple of military cooks in there, get the supplies from the Saudi government. Then, the soldiers can just walk up and order a hamburger, fries and a soda and just walk away without paying for it.'' Saudi Arabia is supplying all food for the U.S. forces here under an agreement with the United States. The Wolfmobile is a 30-foot-long, two-ton truck with a fold-out window and a ramp to walk up and order food. It's equipped with a Franklin stove, grills, a deep-fat fryer, freezer, refrigerator, a grilled-cheese maker and eight heat lamps to keep the food warm. Each truck can feed between 500 and 800 soldiers before it needs to be resupplied. Even though Wolf isn't planning to retire from the army yet, the rangy soldier likes the idea of franchising Wolf burgers some day. And he's already got the slogan: ``A burger on every bayonet.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Health Chief Says Shortage `Deadly Serious'
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is grappling with a ``deadly serious'' shortage of drugs and other medical supplies as the result of U.N. sanctions against the Baghdad government, the health minister said Saturday. Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Sa'eed also said the country is also running out of milk for babies, and complained that many countries had refused to send supplies ordered before the embargo was imposed. The sanctions were approved as part of an international effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait after its Aug. 2 invasion. But they exempt ``supplies intended strictly for medical purposes.'' Sa'eed accused Turkey, Iraq's northern neighbor, of preventing large quantities of medicine and milk from reaching Iraq. He provided no details. ``It is deadly serious, and as the minister of health, I think it is not only inhumane but also criminal to deprive my people from medicine and other medical supplies,'' Sa'eed said at a Baghdad news conference. He said Iraqis have been most affected by shortages of medicines with short shelf lives, plus vaccines and milk for infants. He cited a severe shortage of antibiotics and medicine for people with heart problems and diabetes. The minister said some newborns receive only 3 pounds of food a month, compared with a minimum standard of 10 pounds. He said he feared some were already suffering ill effects. ``I'm really worried about our children. They might not be able to receive a sufficient amount of nutrition,'' he said. He said polio posed a threat to children's health because of the lack of vaccines. The health minister was also critical of the chairman of the U.N. committee that supervises that embargo for reporting that Iraq had medical supplies that could last 10 years. The chairman, Marjatta Rasi of Finland, ``should be better informed about the needs of newborn children, but I'm afraid that her statement was not only childish but irresponsible,'' Sa'eed said. Rasi said earlier this month she feared that Iraq could make biological or chemical weapons from components of some medicines that had been supplied under embargo exemptions. Iraq denied that. She said some experts believed certain medical supplies could last 10 years. Iraq produces some of its own antibiotics, painkillers and other simple drugs. But the health minister said: ``Our industry is a really small one.'' Painkillers, cold medicine and other such drugs have been scarce in Baghdad pharmacies since the first days of the embargo, when some people began hoarding. The government has been encouraging research of herbal medicines, as well as their practical use by health professionals.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Flood Across Europe, to Waning Welcomes
DOC.TEXT: Yevgeny and Julia Loukyanov, late of Moscow, spend their days looking in shop windows at things they can't afford or sitting in a crowded refugee center, wondering what the future holds. ``We can't work because we can't get work papers,'' said Julia, 25, ``but the worst thing is, after all this we'll probably be kicked out of the country.'' The young Russian couple are part of Europe's greatest refugee migration since World War II. It became a tide sweeping from east to west after the Communist regimes of the Soviet bloc collapsed a year ago. When the first thousands came, seeking better lives in a more secure future, citizens of the western democracies cheered, embraced them and offered gifts. But they came in millions, had to be housed and fed, and took jobs westerners felt were rightfully theirs. Welcome began turning to resentment. West Germany committed billions of dollars of public money to the economic derelict that was East Germany for 40 years until reunification. A combination of the westward flow of Europeans and a huge migration from Third World countries has increased racial and ethnic tensions, created severe housing shortages and caused social welfare costs to balloon. Now the Soviet Union may be on the point of disintegration, which could add 15 million more refugees to the flood. ``The Soviets themselves have been mentioning anything from 2 million to 15 million,'' said Jonas Widgren, an asylum consultant at the office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva. Economic conditions are getting worse in the Eastern European countries, which means the number of people heading west is likely to grow. ``The year 1991 will be the worst year economically for ... Eastern Europe since World War II,'' said Heinrich Machowski, an expert on East bloc affairs at the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin. Nearly 2 million people have sought asylum in 10 western European nations since 1983 and millions more have immigrated illegally. According to U.N. statistics, the number seeking asylum in the 10 countries soared from 61,100 in 1983 to 300,500 last year. Nearly 400,000 more are expected by the end of this year, plus about 1 million ethnic Germans who have automatic German citizenship. In addition to East Europeans, the newcomers include refugees from such countries as Lebanon, Iran, Sudan, Tunisia, Algeria, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. ``I left Sudan because I was put in prison for my political views,'' said Ahmed Alseed Gasm, 27, another refugee at the Bonn shelter. ``I need that (residence) permit because I can't go back home.'' West European nations are tightening immigration laws and cracking down on illegal immigrants, but that has not stemmed the flow. Public resentment is turning to violence. In Florence, Italy, earlier this year, masked youths assaulted African street vendors with baseball bats. Rock-throwing German youths have attacked tent cities set up by Romanian gypsies. Some parents in a German town refused to send their children to a school whose gymnasium had been a temporary shelter for gypsies. They expressed fear their children would catch diseases or be infested with lice. Gypsies fleeing ethnic troubles in their home countries are seen on German streets in growing numbers. Several hundred camped out in trailers at Berlin's Brandenburg Gate until police ordered them to leave. Gangs of young German ``skinheads'' frequently attack Turks, Vietnamese and other foreigners. In Paris, African immigrants were the targets of an anti-squatter eviction campaign. For weeks afterward, several dozen former squatters lived in makeshift tents at a corner of Sacre Coeur basilica. Austria, which was the neutral bridge between East and West for decades, sent soldiers to stop Romanian refugees ariving via Hungry. The Freedom Party nearly doubled its parliamentary seats in this fall's elections, partially on the strengths of its anti-immigration stands. Germany's wealth, proximity to the former East bloc and history of generosity to refugees has made it a prime destination. It expects asylum-seekers to total nearly 200,000 this year, plus the ethnic Germans from former Soviet bloc countries. Officials said Friday they will assign 20 percent of all asylum-seekers to the formerly Communist east starting in December. Refugee centers are overflowing. Army barracks, empty warehouses and rented boats on the Rhine are used as emergency shelters. Yevgeny and Julia Loukyanov left Moscow in October, fleeing a nation they feel is about to come apart. Social welfare is paying their expenses at the Bonn refugee shelter until a decision is made on their application for asylum. Officials indicate they have little chance of acceptance because the end of the Cold War removed most reasons for granting asylum to Soviet citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Whatever the Outcome, Case Is Important Ethics Watershed
DOC.TEXT: Are the ``Keating Five'' senators victims of a flawed system, or cynical cash-grabbers who championed the dubious cause of one jet-set constituent at the expense of everyone else in the country? What is being examined in their Senate ethics hearing: the way the entire institution operates or the conduct of five members? And how did a Senate leader, two national heroes, a former prosecutor and a man who arrived 23 years ago as a reformer come to this pass? ``It would be hard for it not to be a landmark case,'' associate Senate historian Donald Ritchie said of the tale unfolding before the Senate Ethics Committee. ``Whatever comes out will affect the way business is done. They'll all have to look at themselves. It will be an important precedent for how to judge the behavior of other people in the future.'' There are long days of witnesses and cross-examination to come, including an opening statement from Arizona Democratic Sen. Dennis DeConcini, who did not have time to speak Friday. But Robert Bennett, the ethics committee's blunt special counsel, already has presented his star witness: four tall stacks of paper. Paper, he said, is the only reliable source of information on the web of contributions and favors linking the five senators to Charles H. Keating Jr. and his zealous attempts to thwart the federal regulators closing in on his failing Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. ``Paper doesn't suffer from human emotion or frailties, nor does it change with time,'' Bennett said. ``Paper doesn't have faulty recollections. ... It's highly credible, this paper.'' Bennett said the tens of thousands of documents his staff had examined showed no evidence of misconduct by Sens. John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. - the first a former astronaut, the second a former Vietnam prisoner of war. But he also implied that Democratic Sen. Don Riegle - the Michigan veteran and one-time rebel who now chairs the Senate Banking Committee - was not being straightforward about his role. And he suggested that DeConcini, a former prosecutor, and Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California crossed an ethical line in their dealings with Keating. Glenn, McCain, Riegle and Cranston denied any wrongdoing before the committee Friday, and DeConcini is expected to do the same this week. Much of the future testimony will center on the existence and location of that line under a system in which names on the contribution list inevitably turn up among those requesting help. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., a member of the ethics panel, has already argued that ``the committee cannot act on the basis of laws, rules and standards that some people might like to see. ... The committee must use the standards that are in place.'' But Bennett and some on the panel said former Illinois Sen. Paul Douglas had developed guiding principles that are now well established. Make sure a constituent's cause has merit, Douglas wrote in a book on the subject. Allow a decent interval of time between a contribution and a favor, and don't try to bully or intimidate officials. Ritchie agrees that there is an ethical line, but he says it keeps moving and is easy to cross unwittingly. ``Much of what people consider unethical today was ethical in the past,'' the historian said. ``Daniel Webster argued cases before the Supreme Court for a fee while he was a senator. Senators used to take retainers from large corporations. ... In the late 19th century it was considered legitimate for Washington newspaper correspondents to serve as clerks of committees of Congress while writing for the paper.'' The Keating case concerns a timeless issue, influence peddling. But Ritchie said its scope - involving five senators - is unprecedented. The only comparable case occurred more than 100 years ago, he said, when two House committees and one in the Senate uncovered a bribery scheme meant to head off a congressional investigation of railroad transportation rates. Rep. Oakes Ames was accused of using undervalued railroad stock to bribe the vice president, two senators and three House members - including the speaker and Rep. James Garfield, who never cleared up his connection but later became president. When asked how he had decided who would get the stock, Ames replied that he ``gave it where it would do the best,'' Ritchie said. The Keating case has taken on even broader significance in view of the collapse of the S&L industry, which could cost U.S. taxpayers up to $500 billion. Part of that is the $2 billion Lincoln failure, for which Keating now faces criminal and civil charges. Ritchie compared the Keating hearings to a congressional investigation into the 1929 Wall Street crash. He said that inquiry laid bare the banking industry's abuses and gave the public some sense of who was responsible for the crash. ``If Keating were the only banker in the country who had problems, it would be different. But he's symbolic of a much larger problem,'' Ritchie said. Bennett made clear he does not believe the ``Keating Five'' should be blamed for the S&L mess. But he did say it would be fair to ask if they had thought carefully about what would happen if Keating got what he wanted. The senators had other constituents, he said, among them the depositors who lost their savings and the U.S. taxpayers who will foot the Lincoln bailout bill. ``Who was listening to their concerns when the meetings and phone calls to regulators were occurring?'' he asked. Bennett was billed as a fact-finder, but often sounded so prosecutorial that he brought protests from senators both on and off the ethics committee. ``You asked me to call it the way it was,'' he said at one point. ``And I'm going to do that.'' There were those who liked his calls and those who didn't. McCain emerged from Day One letting out a long, loud breath of relief, and Glenn lauded Bennett for doing a fine job. Cranston snubbed the whole affair, watching it on TV in his office, until it was his turn to speak Friday. Riegle shook with anger and tension during comments to reporters, and DeConcini fought to restrain himself. ``I don't think anybody would contend that this is a fair process,'' DeConcini said tersely. ``I didn't create this world. I just happen to live in it.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Prague
DOC.TEXT: Following is the transcript of an address delivered by President Bush on Saturday at Wenceslas Square: Thank you, Mr. President. And thank you, my Czech and Slovak friends. It is a tremendous honor to me to be the first sitting American president to visit this proud and beautiful country, and to be able to join you on the first anniversary of the extraordinary Velvet Revolution. What a powerfully moving sight it is. There are no leaves on the trees, but it is Prague spring. There are no flowers in bloom, and yet it is Prague spring. The calendar says November 17, and yet it is Prague spring. Your declaration of independence claims the forces of darkness have served the victory of light; the longed-for age of humanity is dawning. Today, the freedom-loving people of the world can bear witness that this age of humanity has now finally and truly dawned on this splendid nation. Seven decades ago, an unprecedented partnership began between two presidents, the philosopher Tomas Masaryk and the idealistic scholar, Woodrow Wilson. It was a partnership as well among Czechs and Slovaks to join together in federation. And yes, it was a long, hard road, from their work on your declaration of independence to this magnificent celebration today. I am proud to walk these last steps with you as one shared journey ends and another begins. Our countries share a history. We share a vision. And we share a friendship, a friendship Masaryk described to Czech-American soldiers 70 years ago. He said, ``Do not forget that the same ideals, the same principles ever unite us. Do not forget us, as we shall never forget you.'' And that is why I'm here today - we have not forgotten. And the world will never forget what happened here, in this square where the history of freedom was written. The days of anguish, the days of hope. So many times you came here bearing candles against the dark night, answering the call of Comenius to follow the way of light. These brave flames came to symbolize your fiercely burning national pride. A year ago the world saw you face down totalitarianism. We saw the peaceful crowd swell day by day in numbers and in resolve. And we saw the few candles grow into a blaze. And we saw the square become a beacon of hope for an entire nation, as it gave birth to your new era of freedom. This victory owes its heart to two great heroes: Alexander Dubcek - 22 years ago he led this nation in its first sweet taste of liberty. His are the will and compassion that are the living Czechoslovakia. And then President Havel, a man of wisdom, a man of tremendous moral courage. In the dark years on one side sat the state, on the other side Havel; one side tyranny, on the other this man of vision and truth. Among the first was Havel, and now there are millions. Today a Europe whole and free is within our reach. We've seen a new world of freedom born amidst shouts of joy, born full of hope, barreling with confidence toward a new century, a new world born of a revolution that linked this square with others - Gdansk, Budapest, Berlin - a revolution that joined together people fueled by courage and by humanity's essential quest for freedom. And for four decades, our two nations waited across the divide between East and West, two peoples united in spirit and vision, and yet separated by conflict. Today the United States and Czechoslovakia stand together, united once more in our devotion to the democratic ideal. And now with the division of Europe ending and democracy ascending in the East, the challenge is to move forward. In Czechoslovakia, from revolution to renaissance, across this continent toward a new Europe, in which each nation and every culture can flourish and breathe free. On both sides of the Atlantic, toward a commonwealth of freedom based on our shared principles and our hopes for the whole world, a commonwealth inspired by the words of your great Comenius, written three centuries ago, ``Let us have but one end in view, the welfare of humanity.'' A thousand miles to the south, this new commonwealth of freedom now faces a terrible test. Czechoslovakia was one of the first nations to condemn the outrage in the Persian Gulf, one of the first to measure the magnitude of the wrong committed in the name of territorial ambition. It is no coincidence that appeasement's lonely victim half a century ago should be among the first to understand that there is right and there is wrong, there is good and there is evil, and there are sacrifices worth making. There is no question about what binds our nations and so many others in common cause. There is no question that ours is a just cause and that good will - that good will prevail, that darkness is the - in the desert sky cannot stand against the way of light. I salute your courageous President when he joins us in saying that Saddam Hussein's aggression must not be rewarded. Earlier today, I told your Parliament, ``We know this is a difficult time for you, but also a time of extraordinary optimism.'' As you undertake political and economic reform, know one thing. America will not fail you in this decisive moment. America will stand with you. We will continue along the road mapped out by our Presidents more than 70 years ago, a road whose goal was described by Woodrow Wilson, ``to bring peace and safety to all nations and make the world itself at last free.'' For the past 70 years, your Declaration of Independence has been preserved and cherished in our Library of Congress. I say it is time for Masaryk's words to come home. And as humanity and liberty return to Czechoslovakia, so too will this treasured document. On behalf of the people of the United States, I am proud to be able to tell the people of Czechoslovakia, 1989 was the year that freedom came home to Czechoslovakia. 1990 will be the year your Declaration of Independence came home to the golden city of Prague. May it be, for future generations, a reminder of the ties that bind our nations, and the principles that bind all humanity. In 1776, when our declaration of independence was first read in public, a bell tolled to proclaim the defiant thrill of that moment. That bell - we call it at home the Liberty Bell - has for 200 years symbolized out nation's deepest dedication to freedom, dedication like your own. Inscribed on this bell are the words, ``Proclaim liberty throughout all the land.'' We want to help you proclaim your new liberty throughout all this proud and beautiful land, and so today we give to you our last replica of the Liberty Bell. You know, one of our patriotic songs proclaims ``Sweet land of liberty - from every mountainside, let freedom ring.'' And so when bells ring in Wenceslas Square or in Bratislava or anywhere in this glorious country, think of this bell and know that all bells are tolling for your precious liberty, now and forever. And so now I am proud to ring this bell three times - once for your courage, once for your freedom, and once for your children. May God bless Czechoslovakia. Thank you very much.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev Speech to Supreme Soviet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th pvs, `Fourth on...' to add dropped phrase on time frame; Pickup 9th, `Fifth, specifically...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the Supreme Soviet today, as translated by The Associated Press: Comrades, addresses made at yesterday's session of people's deputies by members of the Supreme Soviet, representatives of republics, my talks with other comrades during the session show that a (general) opinion has formed that the Union Treaty should be moved ahead faster. But even before that, strong radical measures are needed to improve the situation in the country as far as the political and economic stability is concerned, as well as public law and order, discipline, and normalization of inter-ethnic relations. It is my understanding that the comrades think that an urgent reform and strengthening of the state power structure is the major priority. In this connection I propose the following: First, to vest qualitatively new powers into the Federation Council. It should be transformed from an advisory body into an effective structure to coordinate the efforts of the center and the republics. I will emphasize this: anything affecting the entire country, whether decided by the center or republics, must be discussed and given the go-ahead by the Federation Council. A mutually acceptable basis for a decision is to be worked out there. Its work must be done on a regular basis, be open to the society. The inter-republican committee can become the working organ of the Federation Council. Highly qualified experts and specialists with powers to represent republics would work in it on a permanent basis. Second, in this case, to dissolve the Presidential Council and establish a National Security Council. To launch without delay a radical reorganization of the central executive (branch of) power, subordinate it to the president and introduce changes of the structure and personnel, remove outdated structures, form new ones. I will not name them all, but I have mentioned most of them. New people of initiative, capable of innovative thinking, should be brought into the Cabinet. The issue of a vice-presidency obviously needs to be resolved. Concurrent decisions have to be made to ensure efficient operation of governments at local level. All this must be done without delay, without waiting for a Union Treaty, as I have been urging all along. But I understand that you have brought here all concerns, all the feelings of the society. Taking all this into account, we must act and solve everything in the Supreme Soviet as the situation demands, even before the Congress of People's Deputies (convenes). Third, justified demands are being voiced to consolidate law and order, guarantee the safety of each citizen of our country. Urgent changes of structure and personnel, both in the center, republics and at local level, are called for. And something else: we must do our best to prevent global and general intervention into the activities of law enforcement organs that is practically paralyzing now their operation. There are laws adopted here by ourselves, and if we have any self-respect, we ought to allow them to work. (Applause). I propose to form within the framework of presidential power an organ to coordinate the activities of law enforcement agencies to combat organized crime, shadow economy, profiteering and other manifestations of criminal activities that are sweeping the country What I have in mind is a special service reporting to the president. We would invite energetic and highly skilled professionals. This question has been worked out, and the new organ can start work in 10 to 12 days. A chamber of control must be established for the president with authorized representatives in all regions to ensure implementation of laws, decisions and directives. Fourth, on food, I will repeat that resources are not less than last year, it is basically a matter of regularizing the system of supplying the population with products they need, of how accurate regions and republic are in meeting their obligations. Besides, we need to take stock of what we have and control it well. I have issued a directive that a list of urgent measures for supplying this year's produce to the population be worked out urgently and submitted in the next 10 days - two weeks, at the most - for consideration, or at least for your information. Fifth, specifically on measures to ensure the viability of the country. Here I give priority to railway transport and power industry. I am appealing to all soviets, executive and government organs to do all possible to ensure uninterrupted work of these important industries, not to allow any disruptions in moving freight, or any time lost unnecessarily to load and unload railway cars. All operational measures to achieve it - and we have a lot of experience -will be justified.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup 1st graf a0504, ``Sixth on...'
Famed Animal Trainer Bids Goodbye To The Big Top
DOC.TEXT: He performed in places like Madison Square Garden more times than Frank Sinatra, Jack Dempsey and lots of other big names. But after 11,697 shows, animal trainer Gunther Gebel-Williams performs his last death-defying act Sunday with the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus. ``Everybody asks me, `Why now?''' he said in the thick German accent he hasn't lost since he came to the United States 22 years ago. ``I want to step down when I am really good. I don't want to be like Ali, Sugar Ray, `Another fight, another fight.' '' A U.S. citizen since 1979, he calls himself ``German-engineered but a proud American'' and often sports a cowboy hat and a Western-style shirt. Though he's 56, Gebel-Williams remains enviably trim, 141 pounds with a ruddy complexion and his trademark sweep of blond hair. He announced two years ago that he would retire from ``The Greatest Show on Earth'' at the end of the 1990 season. He plans to settle at his winter home in Venice, Fla., with his 20 Bengal and Siberian tigers. After 42 years on the road, he said, training 20 tigers is getting a little riskier because he has lost some of his quickness and his eyesight is not what it used to be. And glasses wouldn't look so hot with his skin-hugging tights and sequined boleros, he joked. ``When you have 20 tigers, it's not easy to act like nothing can happen,'' he said. ``I've been like their father, their brother. I've been in charge always. But when one tiger is hurt, they always blame me.'' His domination in the ring comes from a soft-spoken training method based on mutual respect that separates him from his chair-and whip-wielding predecessors like Clyde Beatty and Mabel Stark, who taught animals to fear them. Gebel-Williams strokes his elephants' trunks, pats the tigers and mumbles commands in German, Indian or English. He welcomes animal rights advocates to attend his training sessions. ``That's the difference between me and everybody else,'' he said. ``I did everything with open doors. ``In 21 years never did somebody say I treated an animal wrong.'' Gebel-Williams began his career when he joined Circus Williams in Germany as an usher at 12. He became so much a part of the Williams family, who had hired his mother as a seamstress, that he added their name to his. By the 1960s, he was well-known as one of Europe's top animal trainers. In 1968, he caught the eye of Irvin Feld, owner and producer of Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, who bought the entire Circus Williams to get their star to come to America. Now Gebel-Williams will yield the ring to his 20-year-old son, Mark. But he won't yield the tigers because he's afraid they won't transfer their devotion to his son. Mark's act will include the African and Indian elephants, white Lippizaner horses, zebras and camels. ``I think it's time for Mark. I have to step back,'' said Gebel-Williams, adding that he'll continue to work with the animals behind the scenes. Gebel-Williams said he didn't plan anything special for his last show, explaining that a change in routine would confuse the animals. And he hopes no one calls for a speech. ``It'll be very tough, but as long as I don't have to talk I can get through it,'' he said. After a lifetime with the circus, it would be impossible for him - and his tigers - to give it up entirely, he said. ``I believe some of my tigers will miss this. Maybe once in a while, I'll take them in the ring in Venice, turn on the music real loud, and let them pretend.''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Pleads in Court, But May Lose Attorneys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th, `The FBI ...' with comment from FBI saying Turner Security official called the FBI about the box. Picks up 14th graf, `CNN general ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega got his day in court, accusing the U.S. government of railroading him by freezing his assets and forcing out his attorneys. A federal judge assured him he will get a fair trial. Meanwhile, at a press conference in Atlanta, Cable News Network on Friday denied a reporter's box full of tapes and other items on the Noriega case was made available to the FBI. But CNN could not clearly explain a sister company's alleged role in getting the box to federal agents Thursday. Speaking extensively to U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler for the first time since he surrendered in January to U.S. invasion troops, Noriega tried Friday to stop him from replacing private defense attorneys with government-paid lawyers. ``I am now at the mercy of a totally unfair and unjust system that chooses my prosecutors and now chooses my defense lawyers,'' the deposed Panamanian dictator said, reading quietly but forcefully in Spanish from a prepared statement. Led by Frank Rubino, Noriega's lawyers say they can no longer work unless the Panamanian's assets are unfrozen to pay them, or the judge raises the $75-an-hour fee cap on court-appointment lawyers. Hoeveler said he would rule in the near future, but reminded the attorneys that raising the caps for the Noriega case was rejected previously. He also said he received communications from ``some exceedingly fine criminal defense lawyers'' willing to take the case under the low government fee schedule. ``I want the defendant to understand he is not being cast adrift by the court and by the judicial system,'' Hoeveler said. Earlier Friday, the private defense team filed a broad motion asking dismissal of all drug charges against their client. It argued that freezing Noriega's assets and taping his prison phone calls was government misconduct. Hoeveler did not immediately rule on the dismissal motion. In the CNN matter, the network claims the FBI contacted Turner Security, a subsidiary of Turner Broadcasting Inc., which also operates CNN. The network says agents told Turner Security they were searching for a box fitting the description of one hotel security officers removed earlier in the week from the room of a reporter assigned to the Noriega case. The FBI maintained that agents learned of the box from Turner Security. Joe Shirley, head of Turner Security, did not return repeated phone calls Friday. William Hinshaw, agent in charge of the Atlanta FBI office, said Shirley called an agent investigating how CNN got the Noriega tapes and told the agent that a box labeled ``Noriega tapes'' had been removed from a hotel room. The agent, Hinshaw said, earlier had contacted Turner Security about interviewing a CNN employee. ``I think when (Shirley) called he ... was just trying to fulfill his responsibility,'' Hinshaw said. CNN general counsel Steven Korn insisted the FBI, not Turner Security, made the first phone call about the box. When asked whether CNN made the box available to the FBI, Korn replied: ``Emphatically, no.'' Asked why Turner Security didn't give the box to CNN, Korn said, ``That's a good question.'' CNN has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn Hoeveler's order, issued last week, barring it from broadcasting recordings of prison telephone conversations between Noriega and his defense team. CNN President Tom Johnson said Friday he didn't know if the recordings contained in the box were audio or video tapes, or if they contained phone calls between Noriega and his legal team. Noriega is being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami on charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Brotherhood Leader Wins Speaker's Post
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood was elected to a one-year term as Jordan's Parliament speaker on Saturday, beating out an ally of King Hussein for the post. Abdullatif Arabiyat, 48, defeated former Interior Minister Sulaiman Arar, who has been speaker for the past year. The vote was 41-28, with 11 abstentions in the 80-member Chamber of Deputies. The Brotherhood stands for the eradication of Israel and stricter Islamic laws in Jordan that would mean banning alcoholic beverages and closing nightclubs. Arabiyat is also speaker of the 22-man Moslem Brotherhood bloc in Parliament. The party did surprisingly well in last year's elections, held after the king allowed parties to contest parliamentary races for the first time. The 40-man Senate is appointed by the king.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Bay Area Newspapers, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0493,0411
DOC.HEAD: Strike Deadline Put On Hold As Bay Area Newspaper Negotiations Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with talks halting for a rest break. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The unions...'.
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders put a strike deadline on hold and negotiated through the night with management in a last-ditch bid to avoid a walkout at the San Francisco Bay area's three largest newspapers. Unions representing about 4,500 employees at the San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco Examiner and San Jose Mercury News had threatened to strike at 5 p.m. Friday if an agreement on a new contract was not reached. They continued talks indefinitely after both sides said progress was being made. After working through the night, negotiators took a break about 7:30 a.m. today and planned to resume at 10 a.m., said Paul Avery, a reporter for the San Francisco Examiner. ``The always hopeful sign is they're still talking,'' he said. ``People who are scheduled to work are going to work until we hear differently.'' As of late Friday, union and management were still far apart on wages after reaching agreement on non-economic issues earlier in the week, both sides said. The unions were seeking a 20 percent pay raise and a four-day work week, while management suggested a wage freeze over the next three years, with $80 lump sum payments made to each employee every six months. ``Everyone is bargaining in good faith, and we feel comfortable in stopping the clock to allow negotiations to continue,'' said union spokeswoman Dawn Garcia. ``I'm confident we will reach an agreement if we stay at it,'' said Richard Jordan, chief negotiator for the San Francisco Newspaper Agency, which runs Chronicle and Examiner business operations. The previous three-year contract, which expired Feb. 2, gave employees an average of 3 percent to 5 percent pay and benefit increases each year. The three newspapers have a combined circulation of about 1 million. Top-scale pay at each is $801 a week for reporters, $669 for clerical and library workers and $675 for delivery truck drivers. The Chronicle and the Mercury News, both morning papers, published their Saturday editions as talks continued. The Examiner, an afternoon newspaper, publishes a combined Sunday morning edition with the Chronicle. San Francisco's last newspaper strike was in 1968 and lasted 55 days. The Mercury News was last struck in 1959, for four months.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Upbeat About Meetings With African Nations
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III picked up the vote of at least one African nation Saturday in his drive to line up support for a resolution endorsing the use of military force to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Zaire's foreign minister, Kalimba Wakatana Mushobekwa, said his government would go along with a resolution in the U.N. Security Council authorizing force if peaceful means failed. ``Yes, we support it,'' he said in response to reporters' questions. But he also expressed the hope that a peaceful way would be found to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. Baker was upbeat after his talks with Mushobekwa and the foreign ministers of Ethiopia and the Ivory Coast, all nonaligned nations who are currently on the 15-member Security Council. ``I think we've had a positive day consulting with other members of the council,'' Baker said after his hour-long meeting with Mushobekwa. ``I don't want to get into the business of counting votes here or predicting results or anything like that. But we've had some good meetings today,'' he said. The United States would like broad support for its moves on the gulf crisis by gaining approval from neutral and Third World countries. After the sessions, Baker was flying to Paris where he was to meet on Sunday with five more nations on the Security Council - the Soviet Union, France, Britain, Finland and Romania. Baker, who flew Saturday morning to Geneva from Brussels, Belgium, opened his latest round of talks with Ethiopian Foreign Minister Tesfaye Dinka. Dinka described the discussions as ``very interesting'' and replied, ``Yes, of course,'' when asked whether they were successful. Simeon Ake, foreign minister of the Ivory Coast, said he wasn't used to revealing private conversations to reporters and hurried off to his waiting car. The talks were held at the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, not far from Lake Geneva. At the United Nations, diplomats said Baker wanted foreign ministers to travel to New York to adopt personally the resolution on use of force. Foreign ministers rarely sit in their country's seats on the Security Council except in particularly serious situations. Baker has insisted that the Bush administration has made no final decision on whether to offer the resolution for a vote. ``I haven't seen a draft resolution yet,'' he said Saturday. But officials seem ready to go ahead and introduce the document in the Security Council before the end of the month. The United States holds the rotating presidency of the council in November. Yemen, an Arab nation which has been sympathetic to Iraq, assumes the chairmanship in December. The United Nations has approved 10 resolutions directed against Iraq since its Aug. 2 invasion of tiny Kuwait. On a trip last week to the gulf, Baker made initial contacts with the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France to get their backing for the use-of-force resolution. As permanent members of the Security Council, they could kill it with a veto. France, China and the Soviet Union have indicated they would like more time to give economic sanctions and diplomacy a chance to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to pull his troops out of Kuwait. On Sunday, Baker will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and may ask about a suggestion by a Soviet envoy that a ``flexible linkage'' be drawn between an Iraqi pullout and a conference to settle the Israeli-Palestinian dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis' Military Crew Orbiting Amid Secrecy
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' five astronauts orbited 170 miles above the world amid military secrecy Saturday after accomplishing their major objective, delivering a spy satellite into space. The crew deployed the spacecraft from the shuttle Friday, sources said. The satellite reportedly is to spy on Iraq by eavesdropping on communications or conducting photo surveys. NASA refused to discuss the Defense Department flight, and Mission Control issued only terse status reports. The last update was Friday evening, when it was announced Atlantis would return to Earth on Monday. ``Things are going well since we don't hear otherwise,'' said Billie Deason, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Ted Molczan, an amateur astronomer in Toronto who tracks spacecraft, said Atlantis is 170 miles high. Two amateur astronomers, one in Florida and the other in Texas, spotted a bright satellite orbiting in front of the shuttle at a slightly lower altitude Friday night, he said. One of the observers said the satellite was rotating in flashing shades of red, gold and a yellowish white, Molczan said. Atlantis returned to space for the first time in eight months with a flawless liftoff Thursday. The shuttle had been grounded over the summer by hydrogen leaks that were fixed by installing a new external fuel tank, plumbing and valve seals. Columbia also was crippled by hydrogen leaks much of the year. NASA expects to launch the spaceship with seven astronauts and an astronomical observatory in early December. NASA prefers to have at least three weeks between shuttle missions, but has said it will not wait that long so Columbia can be up and back by Christmas. That would enable the agency to shut down certain operations at the end of the year for routine maintenance and to save on holiday pay. Atlantis is scheduled to land at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., sometime between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. EST Monday. Mission Control will break its silence Sunday evening to announce a more precise landing time. It is the seventh Pentagon shuttle flight to be conducted in secrecy, and is due to be the last.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Wanted In 5-Year-Old's Slaying Kills Self
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager wanted for investigation of the drive-by shooting death of a 5-year-old girl killed himself after police surrounded his apartment, authorities said Saturday. Rance Benson, 18, shot himself in the head in the inner city apartment late Friday, said police Detective Jim Tiampo. Benson and a 17-year-old boy had been sought in the Nov. 10 slaying of Ashley Johnson, who was shot to death while she played hopscotch at a birthday party, Tiampo said. The name of the 17-year-old, who was arrested Thursday, was not released because of his age. Police said the gunfire that killed Ashley apparently was intended for a group of rival gang members nearby. At a Friday news conference, police asked the public's help in finding Benson. Officers went to the apartment after receiving an anonymous tip that he was inside, and Benson barricaded himself in a bedroom before shooting himself in the head. Police fired no shots, Tiampo said. Earlier Friday, about 200 people attended Ashley's funeral. Mourners also gathered on the street where she was shot to set up a memorial of flowers and religious candles.

DOC.HEAD: Government Official Escapes Injury in Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Two bombs exploded near the spot where the agriculture minister delivered a speech but the official was not injured, a government spokesman said Saturday. No one was hurt in the blasts Friday, but some people were hurt in the panic that followed, said the spokesman, Suvit Yodmani. The incident occurred in the southern province of Yala, about 670 miles south of Bangkok, said the spokesman. The Thai-language newspaper Matichon said the bombs went off about 50 yards from a youth center in front of which the minister, Chuan Leekpai, had given a speech 15 minutes earlier. An unspecified number of people were hurt in the panic, but the bombs themselves injured no one, the paper reported. Radical Moslem groups, some demanding an indpendent Islamic state, are active in the south of Thailand. Moslems account for about 4 percent of Thailand's 50 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Motel Complex Blasted By Suspected Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Masked raiders believed to belong to a nationalist guerrilla group set off explosives at a seaside motel, police said Saturday, but the motel was closed at the time and no one was hurt. About two dozen bungalows and a central building were damaged in the blast Friday night at the motel, on the coast of the Porto Vecchio gulf in southern Corsica. A watchman and his wife at the motel were seized and taken to a nearby home, where a father, mother and 6-year-old girl also were tied up, police said, but none was injured. The six or seven raiders painted the letter ``R'' on a wall, the customary manner in which several recent bombings have been claimed by Resistenza, a nationalist group believed to have been formed by guerrillas dissatisfied with the larger Corsican National Liberation Front. The nationalists are fighting to become independent from France. Following the incident, authorities reported the arrest of two men in Ajaccio, Corsica's biggest city. A firearm, explosives and masks reportedly were found in their vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Prague
DOC.TEXT: Following is the transcript of an address delivered by President Vaclav Havel on Saturday at Wenceslas Square: Ladies and Gentlemen, dear Citizens. In recent years and in particular in the past few months prior to November 1989, most of us felt that tension in our society was building up and the gap between promise and performance between the world of official speeches and the real world was widening at a spectacular pace. We guessed that things could not continue the way they did and that something was about to happen. None of us, however, knew when the crucial change would happen and how it would happen. None of us knew what would be the last drop to make the cup overflow, the snowball setting the avalanche in motion. It was the students who set the avalanche in motion. Last year they decided to commemorate Jan Opletal and the International Students' Day by an independent demonstration. What followed is a matter of common knowledge. A year has passed since then.
