And today we are standing here somewhat embarrassed. We know very well what we still have to accomplish and the question springing up to mind is why do we find it so difficult to launch our joint project off the ground. Is it because we underestimated the legacy of the old regime or overestimated our own capacity? Is it because someone is deliberately trying to thwart our joint effort, or are we marring our own endeavor? So it is with full justification that we are asking ourselves today: Why did we fail to achieve this year even that stint of work that originally struck us as the simplest job of all - namely to shed light on all the circumstances of last year's massacre and punish the real offenders. Why hasn't historic justice been given full rein in a dignified and legally correct way? Why is our political climate systematically poisoned by demagogy, by political, ethnic and racial intolerance? Why - after we had toppled in a humane way an inhuman regime - the crime rate continues to increase at a dizzy rate? Each of these and similar questions can be answered in an objective spirit and explained in a plausible fashion in a wide variety of ways. Whatever the answer or explanation, the fact remains that dissatisfaction, nervousness, insecurity and disillusionment are widespread in our society. This is understandable and to a certain extent it might serve a good purpose. For isn't precisely impatience the factor that the pressure inspiring a more radical and more speedy implementation of social changes? Nervousness and impatience do not worry me too much. What in my view is far worse are the attendant phenomena ever more obvious at every turn: rancor, rivalry, mutual denigration, envy and boundless ambition. It seems to me that these vices infecting our public life are ever more rampant. Are we really a nation capable of reviving its virtues only once in a twenty years' time? Virtues that only last for a few months? Are we really a nation that only manages to kowtow to the oppressor and when the cup finally overflows vie in the bravado of boasting speeches and mutual defamation? I find it hard to believe that this our one and only - our sole chief historical alternative, I find it hard to believe that the spirit of tolerance and wisdom could not ultimately prevail in Slovak souls and in Czech and Slovak public life. A small group of students invited the public to devote this gathering to what could fittingly be described as meditation in which everyone would search his own conscience. Yes, let us try to search our own souls today! Let us try to reflect on our public life in the spirit of calm detachment, with our own conscience being the supreme judge. Let us try to see ourselves in a broader human perspective - let us try to visualize the contours of our frequently parochial, myopic and dimwitted action as perceived by the civilized world! I see much stimulating food for this kind of self-searching thought in the pleasant fact that it is precisely today that we are honored by the visit of a representative of one of the world's oldest democracies, the supreme representative of the great and freedom-loving nation - the President of the United States of America, George Bush! More than two hundred years ago, the newly arisen state found itself confronting a situation very much similar to that confronting us today. The new democracy was subjected to stringent tests and ordeals. The distressing financial and economic situation, doubts about the country's international status and the feuds between different states of the confederation and politicians frequently fueled fears for the country's future integrity. The adoption of the American Constitution was gravely jeopardized. In the most significant political document of the day - in the Federalist Essays, Alexander Hamilton appraised the situation as follows: ``Among the gravest obstacles obstructing the passage of the new constitution, one can easily discern the undisguised interest of a certain group of people in each state to prevent the coming of all changes threatening to restrict their power, to diminish their profits and the significance of the offices they hold; and the perverted ambition of another group of people determined to profiteer from the confusion prevailing in the country.'' The same lines might be written about our own country today.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Harry Lauter, TV Westerns Actor, Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Harry Lauter, a veteran cowboy actor in television Westerns who was co-star of ``Tales of the Texas Rangers,'' has died. He was 76. Lauter died of heart failure at his Ojai home Oct. 30, the Los Angeles Times reported Saturday. A regular black hat in cowboy Westerns, Lauter appeared in such series as ``Wagon Train,'' ``Rawhide,'' ``Gunsmoke,'' ``Bonanza'' and ``Wyatt Earp.'' Lauter also had two series of his own: ``Waterfront'' in 1954, and ``Tales of the Texas Rangers,'' in which he played opposite Willard Parker, from 1955 to 1959. The White Plains, N.Y., native lived in Colorado and Montana before starting his acting career. Lauter is survived by his wife, Doris, and a daughter, Brooke, from a previous marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Thailand Threatens U.N. Officials Who Aid Burma Students
DOC.TEXT: The government has said it will expel U.N. or other refugee officials who provide aid to Burmese dissidents living in Thailand, a newspaper reported Saturday. Chamnarn Potjana, deputy permanent secretary of the Interior Ministry, on Friday warned international organizations to stop helping Burmese students, according to the Nation newspaper. If they do not, Chamnarn was quoted as saying, ``no matter whether they are officials of the UNHCR (U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees) or other United Nations agencies, we will ask the Foreign Ministry to expel them from the country as persona non grata.'' Thailand has close ties to the military government that took power in Burma in 1988, crushing a student-led pro-democracy movement. Thousands fled and many joined rebel groups based along Burma's border with Thailand and India. The government began reconsidering the status of Burmese dissidents after two Burmese students hijacked a Thai airliner flying to their homeland on Nov. 10. Two other Burmese students hijacked an jetliner to Thailand a year ago. Thaung Htun, a spokesman for the All Burma Students' Democratic Front, said the Thai government ``should consider the problem of Burmese students from a humanitarian point of view. Any person who fled should have the rights of a refugee.'' Chamnarn spoke after a Cabinet committee meeting to discuss what measures to take regarding the students. He said the committee had recommended establishing a holding camp for Burmese dissidents on the Thai-Burma border. The Nation quoted Chamnarn as saying the High Commissioner should use the $120,000 monthly allowance allocated to Burmese students to establish the camp. The private U.S. Committee for Refugees estimates 2,000 Burmese students live in Bangkok. Another 2,700 are on the Thai-Burma border, according to the All Burma Students' Democratic Front, the main group of exiled students. Thailand considers the students illegal immigrants subject to detention, fines and deportation. The students depend on aid from private relief groups and grants from the U.N. High Commissioner that range from $40 to $120 a month. According to the U.S. Committee for Refugees, since 1988 Thailand has repatriated more than 5,200 Burmese, many of them students. Amnesty International has cited reports that Burmese authorities have brutally interrogated and tortured some students repatriated from Thailand. The Bangkok Post quoted Chamnarn as saying that in addition to the hijacking, Burmese students were believed responsible for a small bomb attack recently on the Burmese Embassy compound in Bangkok. He said Thailand would deport those who violated its immigration law and penal code.

DOC.HEAD: PRAGUE: country today.
DOC.TEXT: There is one source of optimism that could be tapped - namely the fact that the United States overcame the initial spell of crisis and developed into a powerful citadel of democracy shared by all U.S. citizens, while providing at the same time a source of inspiration and hope for all those who suffer oppression and non-freedom in other countries. How did the United States accomplish this goal and how could we accomplish it? First and foremost, America reached consensus on the most fundamental piece of national legislation - the American Constitution - which codified, and today continues to protect, the fundamental human rights and liberties with unrelenting vigor: freedom of speech, freedom of conviction freedom of assembly and association - as well as the freedom of addressing requests and complaints to the government. Secondly, they succeeded in persuading the American legislators of the necessity of a strong federal government which, however, retained only the most necessary powers indispensable for the exercise of state sovereignty, for ensuring the country's defense capability, for the protection of the international position of the United States as a whole and for the free circulation of material and immaterial property throughout the country. All other matters remained within the legal competence of the states and the people. And most important of all, the Americans, just because they upheld that wide-ranging decentralization of power, gave free scope and elbow room to free decision making and creativity. This decision was expressive of the trust and confidence in the prudence, common sense and moral integrity of the free citizen, it reflected the awareness that the citizen and the state are answerable to each other only in matters delimited by the law, the conviction that the citizens are more competent to administer some of their affairs than the state itself. The democratic and prosperous America of today is the outcome of the endeavor pooling the efforts of many generations of free citizens. There is no other path for us to follow but the path of the same effort - we should each seek and identify our own mistakes and errors, we should insist on our own freedom without curtailing the freedom of others. Dear friends, a year ago, the freedom-loving genius of our nations scored a victory over violence and totalitarian rule. I am convinced that at the present juncture, too, common sense, decency and tolerance will triumph in each of us over ambitious rivalry, egoism and intolerance.

DOC.HEAD: Talking About America's Most Popular Illegal Drug: Marijuana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, Perhaps as, and 12th graf pvs, Other drugs, to CLARIFY that while 38 states make more arrests for marijuana than for cocaine and heroin, total number of U.S. cocaine and heroin arrests is higher than marijuana
DOC.TEXT: Ruth knows that smoking marijuana, once virtually ignored by the public and police, is now considered ``a very deviant thing. It's very taboo.'' The 40-something San Francisco professional is married, has children and a respectable job. She knows that even though California's marijuana law is still relatively lenient, a drug bust could threaten her livelihood. Yet she still smokes high-grade sinsemilla several times a week. Why? ``It's a very nice high,'' she said. ``Often in these drug stories, people forget to mention that part.'' Ruth is far from alone. Marijuana is the most popular illegal drug today, the crack epidemic notwithstanding. Perhaps as a result, 38 states arrest more people for marijuana than for cocaine and heroin combined, government statistics show. Last year, almost 400,000 people were busted on some kind of marijuana charge. The drug's popularity stems in part from the fact that it is a known quantity - almost 66 million Americans have tried it at least once, many of them during its heyday in the 1960s and 1970s. The 1988 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse found that 6.6 million Americans used it once a week or more and 11.6 million had used it in the previous month. It is considered relatively safe. Today's marijuana may be far stronger than its counterpart a decade ago, as the government says, but Harvard psychiatrist Lester Grinspoon notes there is ``no reliable evidence of death caused by cannabis in a human being.'' And it's relatively cheap. John, a scientist who uses sinsemilla several evenings a week, says one ounce lasts him six months. That ounce could cost as little as $100 and the same amount of lower-grade marijuana can run $40. Other drugs - especially cocaine and heroin - are associated with high crime and violence, particularly in the most populous states. Police officers last year arrested 700,000 people for cocaine and heroin nationwide, more than any other illegal drug. But in some states, nearly every drug arrest involves marijuana - 86 percent in Vermont, for example, 82 percent in North Dakota and 81 percent in Maine, according to FBI figures for 1988. Eight of every 10 marijuana busts is for possession of the drug, the FBI says. The reason so many people are arrested on marijuana charges seems obvious to one group - the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, which has advocated marijuana legalization for two decades. Marijuana users ``are easier targets'' than, say, cocaine traffickers, said NORML spokesman John Dunlap. ``They're a much more passive lot. The government knows it's an easy public relations victory.'' Dunlap also contends there are just more marijuana smokers out there - he estimates 30 million people use it once a week, far more than the government estimate of 6.6 million. Many police departments that once paid little attention to marijuana users have changed as attitudes harden toward all illegal drugs. An example is Arizona's Maricopa County, which includes Phoenix. ``The cops basically sort of ignored it'' a few years ago, said Bill FitzGerald, spokesman for County Attorney Richard Romley. Today, the county boasts a ``Do Drugs, Do Time'' program targeting all drug users. ``Every arrested person will be booked into jail for at least a few hours,'' said Romley and County Sheriff Thomas Agnos in a paper describing the program. For a casual user, even a brief jail stint ``drives home the gravity of the offense.'' First-time offenders may enter a diversion program and, according to FitzGerald's figures, three-quarters of the people who did had been arrested on marijuana charges. Across America, government agencies have staged widely publicized raids on outdoor marijuana fields, indoor growing labs and stores that sell equipment for such labs in an attempt to curtail domestic crops that provide an estimated 25 percent of the U.S. supply. The government admits it conducts these raids in large part to impress a foreign audience. ``We cannot expect foreign countries to undertake vigorous anti-drug efforts inside their borders if we ourselves fail to do likewise,'' says the National Drug Control Strategy issued in January. Perhaps another reflection of changing attitudes about drugs, laws themselves are becoming more stringent. Of the 11 states that decriminalized marijuana possession for personal use during the 1970s, four have reversed course in recent years. Alaska, which had actually legalized possession of up to four ounces at home or other private places, voted Nov. 6 to make possession of small amounts a crime again. Maine, Ohio and Oregon had already tightened marijuana restrictions. But in seven other states - California, Colorado, Minnesota, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nebraska and New York - a marijuana arrest is more akin to a traffic ticket than a criminal charge. William J. Bennett, who resigned after 20 months as national drug control policy director, championed the stricter attitude and campaigned for Alaska's marijuana measure. Although Bennett told The Associated Press last December that he believed marijuana was no more harmful than alcohol, he rejected legalization: ``The last thing I would want to do is recommend the wider use of a drug that makes young people stupid.'' Despite the increased risks, many longtime marijuana smokers cannot imagine giving it up. John, the scientist who asked that his real name not be used, said a single puff of sinsemilla ``facilitates the imagination and has allowed occasional creative breakthroughs,'' some of which have led to ``papers published in reputable journals.'' His employers do not require random drug tests, but if they did, ``That would be enough of an insult to my freedom that I would quit and contribute to the brain drain,'' said John, who is single. Steven, a 34-year-old Massachusetts attorney and father of two, said, ``If I didn't use it, I think I'd be an alcohol abuser.'' Alcohol would hurt his health far more, he said. Steven, who did not want his last name used, recognizes the legal dangers, but believes he would face only a reprimand, not disbarment, if he were arrested on marijuana charges. To Ruth, who also did not want her last name used, marijuana is ``the best aphrodisiac there is.'' Alcohol is not an acceptable substitute. ``You get drunk with alcohol,'' she said. ``You get sloppy. And the next day you have a hangover. The worst that can happen with marijuana is you get sleepy.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Government Offices Hit by Grenades
DOC.TEXT: Grenades exploded early Saturday at two government offices in this southern city, causing minor damage but no casualties, police said. In the first incident, two unidentified men threw a grenade at the Land Transportation Regulatory Board office about 6:45 a.m. local time. About 45 minutes later, three men hurled another grenade at the office of the Department of Local Government, police said. There were no arrests and no immediate claim of responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: `The Boss' Gives First Formal Concert in Two Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Quote in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Bruce Springsteen's fans didn't change much during the singer's two-year performance hiatus. Familiar yells of ``Bruuuuce! Bruuuuce!'' were so distracting as he began his first formal concert since 1988 that the Boss had to make a request. ``I'd appreciate during the songs just a little quieter so I can concentrate on 'em,'' he told the sellout crowd at the Shrine Auditorium on Friday night. Springsteen headed the bill for the concert benefiting the Christic Institute of Washington, D.C. The benefit also featured Jackson Browne and Grammy-winner Bonnie Raitt. The show was an acoustic affair, and Springsteen performed solo, accompanying himself with guitar, piano and harmonica through more than a dozen songs, including ``Darkness on the Edge of Town,'' ``Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out,'' ``Thunder Road'' and ``My Hometown.'' His 90-minute set, including encores with Raitt and Browne, was his first formal appearance since the Amnesty International Human Rights Now tour. The fans were hungry. The 4,500 seats available to the public sold out in 45 minutes. The institute, a liberal advocacy group, got the remaining seats in the 6,300-seat auditorium. A second show was added for Saturday night. Proceeds from the concert will finance an institute lawsuit claiming that the U.S. government sanctioned illegal arms sales and drug trafficking to finance private covert operations during the Iran-Contra affair. The lawsuit, currently on appeal in a Florida court, is named La Penca after a village in Nicaragua where a bomb exploded during a news conference for contra leader Eden Pastora in 1984, killing three journalists and injuring more than a dozen other people. Raitt said the institute had been having a rough time with the lawsuit, but ``that's going to change because the truth will out.'' ``Over the past decade the country's been sold an illusion of itself,'' and the Christic Institute is trying to make everyone ``grow up,'' Springsteen told the audience. He was more effusive about developments in his life, particularly the birth this July of his son, Evan. He recalled that when his girlfriend, former backup singer Patty Scialfa, went into labor he ``did Lamaze'' and then went shopping in search of a good joke book. ``I figured the situation would get tense,'' he explained. The book he found was called ``How to be Italian,'' and although he claimed to not have used it, some must have rubbed off. ``The baby came,'' he said, ``and Patty was beautiful - bellisimo!''

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Heart Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The following are highlights of research presented at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association that concluded Thursday in Dallas:
DOC.HEAD: VITAMIN A
DOC.TEXT:
A form of vitamin A common in carrots and many other fruits and vegetables appears to substantially reduce the risk of heart trouble in people who already have coronary artery disease, researchers have found. The findings about beta carotene are still considered preliminary. But they raise the possibility that people whose heart arteries are already clogged may be able to ward off heart attacks and other cardiac problems by consuming the nutrient.
---
DOC.HEAD: HEART ATTACK PROTEIN
DOC.TEXT: A protein that a researcher calls the ``heart attack maker'' is elevated in black Americans and could explain their increased rate of heart attacks, says a study released Monday. ``It is helpful in explaining why some individuals have heart attacks at early ages,'' said Dr. Thomas Pearson of the Mary Imogene Bassett Research Institute in Cooperstown, N.Y. A study of white and black doctors in their 50s revealed that levels of the protein were more than twice as high in the blacks, Pearson said. The protein is called lipoprotein (a). ---
DOC.HEAD: SMOKING-PAIN
DOC.TEXT: Cigarettes increase smokers' pain tolerance and could therefore block the chest pains that serve as a warning for heart disease, researchers said. In studies with 20 male smokers, ages 19 to 44, the researchers found that the tolerance to pain increased with each of three cigarettes smoked. Smokers are known to have a higher prevalence of what is called ``silent ischemia,'' said Dr. Paula Miller of the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. Silent ischemia occurs when blood flow to the heart is briefly interrupted because of the buildup of fatty deposits and cholesterol in the arteries that nourish the heart. Miller's study suggests cigarettes are at least partly responsible for the increased prevalence of silent ischemia in smokers. ---
DOC.HEAD: BYPASS
DOC.TEXT: Men with clogged heart arteries and mild chest pain can be safely treated with medicines alone, and bypass surgery does not help them live any longer, a 10-year study concludes. The study shows that doctors need not rush to perform this common form of surgery to save the lives of those with relatively non-severe disease. ``It's remarkable that there was no difference in total survivorship of these patients after 10 years,'' said Dr. Lawrence S. Cohen of Yale University, a co-author of the study. ---
DOC.HEAD: HOSTILITY
DOC.TEXT: Hostile teen-agers are likely to grow up to be adults who have high cholesterol, according to a study that finds new links between anger and heart trouble. For years, many experts assumed that hard-driving, impatient people with classic Type A personalities were at high risk of heart attacks. But many have grown skeptical of this theory, and some now believe that the truly lethal personality trait is hostility and anger. ``People with high hostility at age 19 tend to have high cholesterol levels at 40,'' Dr. Redford B. Williams of Duke University said Wednesday. Williams' study was among several that suggest that hostile people are more prone to heart trouble - both because of the effects of adrenaline and other hormones on their bodies and their tendency to have unhealthy living habits. ---
DOC.HEAD: SHOCK
DOC.TEXT: Almost two-thirds of the 300,000 Americans who drop dead suddenly each year from cardiac arrest might be saved if automatic shocking machines were made as common as fire extinguishers, heart specialists say. Catastrophic disturbances in the heart's normal rhythm - what doctors call sudden death - account for about half of all heart disease fatalities. Shocking the heart with a machine called a defibrillator can restore normal beating. But the shock must be delivered within five minutes, or the victim will die or suffer brain damage. ---
DOC.HEAD: SNORING-HEART ATTACKS
DOC.TEXT: About 2 million Americans unknowingly suffer from a breathing disorder called obstructive sleep apnea that doubles their risk of dying from a heart attack, researchers say. The disorder, in which people stop breathing for 30 to 60 seconds or longer during sleep, is most common in people who snore, said Dr. Bernard Burack, a cardiologist at the Montefiore Medical Center's Sleep-Wake Center in New York. ``That doesn't mean everyone who snores is going to drop dead,'' Burack said. But patients with the snoring-related disorder have a risk of heart-related death 2.1 times the national average, Burack reported at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association. ---
DOC.HEAD: WRONG RISK
DOC.TEXT: Doctors may be giving bad advice about the dangers of heart disease by not considering the interaction of risk factors such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol and smoking. ``Based on single factor determinations, they may be needlessly alarming or falsely reassuring patients,'' said Dr. William B. Kannel of Boston University. Kannel is one of the principal investigators with the Framingham Heart Study, a 40-year-long study of 5,209 people in Framingham, Mass., 25 miles west of Boston. Kannel and the American Heart Association announced the development of a ``risk factor prediction kit'' that will enable doctors to better estimate patients' heart disease risks.

DOC.HEAD: Black Agents Claim Treasury Unit Discriminates in Hiring, Promotion
DOC.TEXT: Black agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have filed a lawsuit saying the agency discriminates in its hiring, promotion and evaluation of blacks. The suit claims the agency's ``discriminatory policies, patterns and practices ... are manifestations of longstanding discrimination on the basis of a characteristic common class: being black.'' The suit, filed in U.S. District Court here Friday, seeks declaratory, injunctive and back pay relief for agents currently employed at ATF and for as many as 300 individuals who, according to the suit, have sought and been denied employment by the agency. The bureau, established in 1972 under the jurisdiction of the Treasury Department, is responsible for enforcement of laws relating to alcohol, tobacco, firearms, explosives and interstate trafficking in contraband cigarettes. Treasury spokesman Jack Killorin declined comment on the allegations Saturday, saying ``It is in the legal process.'' Michael J. Riselli, one of two attorneys representing the agents, noted that the ATF bureau recently was involved in investigations of racially related bombings in Georgia and Florida. ``It's pretty striking and significant that you've got an agency that from time to time gets called upon to help in civil rights cases ... that doesn't handle its own problems in that area,'' Riselli said in a telephone interview. ``It's been a longstanding problem.'' Riselli said agents Larry D. Stewart of Marietta, Ga., and Mark Jones of Lorton, Va., had tried to get the agency to deal with the concerns in individual informal complaints they filed in June and August 1989. Stewart and Jones are the plaintiffs named in the class action suit. According to the suit, ATF employs approximately 2,000 special agents, of whom 160 are black. Forty of those 160 have been hired since April when Stewart and Jones filed a formal civil rights complaint with the department, Riselli said. The attorney said most black agents are assigned to positions which occupy lower government job classification levels. ``There's never been a black agent appointed to an executive position, and only three have ever been appointed to GM-15 - merit pay or managerial positions,'' Riselli said. Additionally, Riselli said ``many black agents are hired specifically to perform undercover work, often involving drug cases, yet they don't count that service in evaluation for promotion.'' He said Stewart has been with ATF since October 1978 and is supervisory criminal investigator. Stewart has a bachelor's, master's and doctoral degree but has been rejected for an executive position more than 25 times, Riselli said.

DOC.HEAD: Key Elections in Yugoslav Republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina
DOC.TEXT: Bosnia-Hercegovina, whose volatile ethnic feuds sparked World War I, holds its first free election in more than 50 years on Sunday. The results could be crucial to the fragile Yugoslav federation. The central republic is torn by the same bitter geographic, political and ethnic rivalries that plague Yugoslavia as a whole. Ethnic squabbling dominated an acrimonious election campaign. The three rival nationalist groups - Serbians, Croats and Moslems - all have political parties vying for power. Serbian nationalists say that if they lose Sunday's vote they would refuse to recognize the new authorities. In addition to the ethnic-based groups, the vote is being contested by the reformed League of Communists and Premier Ante Markovic's Alliance of Reformist Forces. Those two groups have tried to appeal across ethnic barriers. ``A victory for any of the nationalist parties would trigger uncontrollable tensions,'' said Nenad Kecmanovic, leader of the Alliance in Bosnia. The nationalist parties are the Serbian Democratic Alliance, the Croatian Democratic Union and the Moslem Union of Democratic Action. Stjepan Kljuic, acting president of the Croatian Democratic Union, denied that nationalist parties represented a threat. He said the Communists and the Alliance were trying to frighten voters into believing a nationalist victory would bring chaos and civil war. Initial results from last week's elections in Yugoslavia's poorest state, Macedonia, gave the Communists and Markovic's reformers a clear lead over nationalist parties. Bosnia's capital, Sarajevo, is best-known as the site of the assassination in 1914 of Austrian Archduke Franz Ferdinand by young Bosnian nationalist Gavrilo Princip, which was the spark that ignited World War I. No single party appeared likely to win a clear majority in Bosnia's 240-seat bicameral parliament. But opinion polls indicated the Communists, the Alliance and the Moslems were running ahead. First official results were not expected until the end of the week in the balloting, the republic's first free vote since 1938. Yugoslavia's largest republics of Serbia and Croatia, which sandwich Bosnia-Hercegovina from the east and west, are main rivals to steer Yugoslavia's future political course. Each has laid territorial claims to Bosnia in the past. Serbia, still under Communist rule pending elections Dec. 9, wants to keep power centralized in Belgrade, the Serbian and federal capital. Croatia, where the center-right Croatian Democratic Union ousted Communists in spring elections, wants Yugoslavia transformed into a loose federation of near-independent states. Croatia is backed by Western-minded Slovenia, while Macedonia and Montenegro favor maintaining the federation. Bosnia so far has steered a neutral course, and its future position is to be decided by the election. Both Serbian and Croatian nationalists claim Bosnia for their own, each group citing close historical and cultural links. But Alija Izetbegovic, president of the party that says it represents the region's estimated 1.7 million Moslems, warned: ``Any attempt to redraw (Bosnian) borders ... would cause a blaze that would engulf all nationalities living in the region.'' Serbs make up about 30 percent of Bosnia's population and Croats about 19 percent of the republic's 4.2 million people. Traditional hostility has existed among the Moslems, the Roman Catholic Croats and the Orthodox Serbs since Yugoslavia was founded as a kingdom in 1918.

DOC.HEAD: More States Facing Prospect of Government Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: New York's governor unveiled a plan Saturday to lay off or furlough thousands of state workers, and talk of substantial layoffs is intensifying in several other northeastern states. Across the nation, officials are trying hiring freezes and budget manipulations to avoid letting people go. But as the economy continues to soften, many expect state layoffs to become a common news item. ``Everyone is preparing for it,'' said Linda Carroll of the Council of State Governments. Marcia Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Officers, said half of the states are experiencing a decline in tax revenues, a barometer of a weakening economy. As the states collect less money than expected, budget deficits grow, leaving state executives with the prospect of layoffs. ``This is the third year for many states that have had to make budget cuts and even raised taxes,'' Ms. Howard said. ``They are really to the point where all they can do is cut people.'' In states with major deficits, stopgap measures like early retirement programs and hiring freezes aren't enough. Massachusetts has laid off more than 1,700 state employees, including social workers, mental health and environmental workers, since Sept. 1. State officials spent the last year trying to hold off layoffs through attrition. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo proposed a plan Saturday to correct a potential deficit he said had grown to almost $1 billion. The plan includes 2,000 layoffs and the elimination of an additional 4,000 state jobs through attrition and other actions by the end of the current fiscal year March 31. Cuomo also called for all of New York's 250,000 state employees to take a mandatory, five-day furlough, a move designed to save $135 million. Legislators are expected to return to the capital for a special session to deal with the budget problem within the next several weeks. In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio last week talked of reducing the number of state departments and laying off workers. This comes despite a year's hiring freeze and an increase in the state sales tax and taxes on cigarettes and liquor. State Treasurer Douglas Berman announced Friday the state budget was $600 million in the red and that layoffs were being discussed. Mike Moran, a spokesman for the New York Civil Service Employees Association, said talk of the impending layoffs has a devastating effect among state workers. ``People are worried whether they will have their job or wind up working huge amounts of overtime to make up for those laid off,'' he said. ``What's sad about it is we are talking about people who are providing real services.'' In New Hampshire, 150 of the state's 10,000 workers were cut in April. Dennis Parker, head of the New Hampshire State Employees Association, said clients of the Health and Human Services Department are affected the most. ``The phones are ringing a little longer because there are less people out there doing the job,'' he said. ``It's foolish to think you'll get the same level of services.'' There have been no layoffs in Rhode Island yet, but attrition and an early retirement program for state workers have cut thousands from the payroll. A new state office building, built to house 900 workers, has 650. Still, Brad Southworth, the state personnel administrator, said layoffs are being contemplated. ``They are on the table now with any other action that may be taken,'' he said. Other states are approaching the same crisis faced in the Northeast. Lower than expected tax revenues last week prompted California Gov. George Deukmejian to present the Legislature with a list of cuts totaling $1 billion. Included in the package: a hiring freeze. North Carolina has already imposed a hiring freeze. Texas has raised taxes. Ohio is considering austerity moves. Michigan faces budget cuts. In Georgia, Pete Hackney, the legislative budget officer, said the next Legislature faces the prospect of a ``tax or whack'' budget. ``I certainly hope they can be avoided,'' he said of layoffs, ``but I don't see how.'' Other states seek to avoid crisis by taking early action. Despite a budget surplus, Indiana has reduced the number of state workers from 38,000 to 36,000 through attrition since early 1989. And Colorado has cut 145 workers at the state Department of Labor, a savings of $2 million. Unlike other states, Colorado was able to make the cuts because of an improving economic picture. State unemployment has dropped to 4.5 percent, the lowest in 16 years. Some government watchers believe actual or anticipated layoffs of state workers are the conclusion of a growth in public workers through the past decade. David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union, said there are now 505 state and local government workers for every 10,000 people, an increase from 476 at the beginning of the 1980s. ``It's very disingenuous to believe they can't get along with fewer workers,'' he said. ``A few years ago they didn't have these people on the payroll.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Kitty Dukakis says she's looking forward to Jan. 3, the day her husband, Michael, leaves the governor's office. Mrs. Dukakis told a meeting of the National Association of Social Workers on Friday about her ``one day at a time'' recovery from alcoholism and her battle with manic-depression. She also spoke about her autobiography ``Now You Know,'' published in August. It details her stuggles to overcome addiction to diet pills and alcohol and the ongoing manic depression. ``I am delighted by the response my book received,'' she said, ``but most importantly I'm moved and gratified, humbled really, by the many people who have come up to me on the street and have written to me, thanking me for telling my story.'' Mrs. Dukakis said described the events leading up to her hospitalization a year ago after drinking a small amount of rubbing alcohol. The incident occurred several months after she was released from an alcoholism-treatment program. She said she began to feel depressed again in September 1989, a familiar feeling for her in autumn. ``I had what we call a slip,'' Mrs. Dukakis said. ``Slips and relapses are common among some recovering alcoholics and my slip came in the form of rubbing alcohol I drank in the bathroom of my own home.'' But she said she is excited about the end of her husband's administration and plans that will take them away from the state for about 4\ months. ``Most of all, I am grateful for my sobriety,'' she said. --- SANTA MONICA, Calif. (AP) - When he was in the ring, Muhammad Ali claimed he could float like a butterfly and sting like a bee. Now, the former heavyweight champion hopes his bravado will help kids. Ali will record the rap tune ``Fight Against Hunger'' that will premiere during a television special to raise money for children, said Children's Peace Foundation spokesman Peter Georgi. Ali agreed to drum up support within the entertainment community for the special scheduled to be broadcast in 1991, Georgi said recently. The show will feature satellite links between several nations, including the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, the Palace of Youth in Moscow and the Berlin Wall in Germany. ``Our goal is to carry the momentum of the extraordinary Children's Summit to the next logical stage,'' said Georgi. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - County music singer Lynn Anderson's battle with her former husband, Harold ``Spook'' Stream, for custody of their two children has turned ugly with allegations of drug abuse. The custody fight is over the couple's 11-year-old son and 9-year-old daughter. During a circuit court hearing Friday, Anderson and Stream both testified that although they once used cocaine, they are now drug-free and challenged each other to take tests to prove it. ``I'll be glad to take a blood test or whatever you'd like,'' said Anderson to Stream's attorney. ``I think we're beating a dead horse here. I think both of us have stopped doing anything like that some time ago.'' Stream - from Lake Charles, La., - denied using cocaine, except when he was with Anderson. The couple divorced in 1982. Anderson testified that syringes that a housekeeper said she found in the singer's luggage were for use in medicating her horses. Anderson testified that her career is languishing. She said her concert income has dwindled to almost nothing after publicity about the custody battle and allegations that she abused her children. ``Most of my concert dates were canceled for the duration of the year,'' she said. Anderson, country music's Female Vocalist of the Year in 1971, is best known for her hit was ``(I Never Promised You A) Rose Garden'' in 1970. Temporary custody of the children has been awarded to Stream, a wealthy oilman who has since remarried. --- TOKYO (AP) - Thousands of people carrying lanterns and waving flags thronged to the Imperial Palace grounds Saturday to celebrate Emperor Akihito's enthronement. Akihito, accompanied by Empress Michiko, appeared at a palace balcony and waved to the crowds, led by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Police estimated 47,000 people took part in the event, organized by government and civic organizations. The crowd paraded through main streets on their way to the palace, waving placards hailing the nation's symbolic leader. The imperial couple also waved lanterns as the crowds shouted ``Tenno heika banzai,'' or ``Long live the emperor.'' Akihito formally ascended the throne on Monday to become the first Japanese monarch enthroned as a symbol and not a living god. He became emperor immediately after the death of his father, Hirohito, in January 1989, but his enthronement was delayed until last week, after a period of mourning.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Helps Owner Find Missing Pet - A 9,700-Pound Pet
DOC.TEXT: David Tesch came home to find his pet missing - all five tons of her. Lydia, a 43-year-old elephant, had busted out of a cement walking pen on Tesch's rural spread in central Polk County while he was attending a circus in nearby Lakeland on Thursday night. When he got home, he discovered Lydia had broken through a concrete-block wall, leaving a hole about the size of ... an elephant. Tesch looked for his 9,700-pound pet without any luck. Fearing she might wander off the property and get hurt, he called the Polk County sheriff's office for help. Deputy John Mitchell was dispatched. As he drove around, Mitchell envisioned headlines: ``Deputy Stomped.'' A search of the Tesch grounds was interrupted by a tremendous snort. ``I shined my flashlight at her, then I looked up. And up and up and up,'' Mitchell said. ``She's huge.'' But she's as nice as she is big, he said. Tesch led her quietly back to her quarters. ``No fuss at all,'' Mitchell said. ``Not a peep.''

DOC.HEAD: Alaska's `High Plains Drifter' About to Ride Off Into the Sunset
DOC.TEXT: Steve Cowper, the ``High Plains Drifter'' of Alaska politics, is about to ride off into the sunset again after four bumpy years in the saddle as governor. His single term will come to an end Dec. 3, when Wally Hickel is sworn in as Alaska's seventh chief executive. Cowper, who at 52 years old has had a variety of careers, says he has not yet decided what his next one will be. A private man who admits a low tolerance for public life, Cowper plans only to head for a warmer locale - Mexico. There he will relax in obscurity for a couple of months before returning to his adopted hometown of Fairbanks. It's a fitting exit for the restless politician whose colleagues in the Legislature years ago nicknamed him after the Clint Eastwood movie cowboy - a take-no-guff drifter of few words. Democrat Cowper expects a smooth transition to Hickel, whom he considers a friend. The veteran Republican won the governor's race on the Alaskan Independence Party ticket Nov. 6. Cowper predicts Hickel will be more progressive than many of his conservative supporters expect. Cowper's latest departure from politics comes 12 years after he left his seat in the state House. Both times he decided not to seek re-election. ``Some people want to cling to public office until they fall over dead,'' the Virginia-born Cowper says in his thick Southern drawl. ``I've never been one of that crowd. I got out of public office before voluntarily, and happily I might add.'' This time Cowper leaves behind a state with an improved economy and a higher international profile, but with a dubious future that remains tied to the up-and-down fate of world oil prices. In an interview, Cowper said his inability to wean Alaska from its dependence on oil revenue was a major frustration as oil prices plummeted and then recovered three times during his term. His efforts to promote state income and sales taxes failed when rising oil prices eliminated the pressure on lawmakers to turn to the more stable revenue sources common in other states. ``One of the problems here is that people who stand for public office, for as long as I can remember, have always talked about what's going to happen when the oil money runs out. But it never seems to run out,'' Cowper said. ``People have gotten to the point where they don't really believe it, or they don't believe it's going to happen in their time. It's very difficult to get anybody to sacrifice anything for something that may happen three years from now or 30 years from now.'' And what about Hickel's promises to reduce the budget? ``My observation would be that normally, if you have a large surplus, it's extraordinarily difficult to make major budget cuts,'' Cowper said. Because of the rise in oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait, Alaska could reap up to a billion-dollar surplus next year. Cowper considers his efforts to improve the economy as the top achievement of his administration. ``When I was elected, the Alaska economy was in a very severe downturn,'' he said. ``It was clear that the No. 1 thing on any governor's agenda had to be to do whatever was necessary to put the Alaskan economy back on track. ``You can look at the figures today and tell that that was done,'' he said. Cowper cites as examples the successful effort to get a Federal Express cargo hub in Anchorage, the administration's promotion of international trade, its work with federal regulators to get the state's banking system in order, and his 1988 jobs bill. The outgoing governor says he also laid the groundwork for future trade and social ties with the Soviet Far East. In the Legislature, Cowper's victories included the tightening of a major oil-tax break and major oil-spill legislation after the Exxon Valdez disaster. But he also endured some major defeats. Cowper repeatedly was unable to get one of his favorite ideas, the education fund, through the Legislature. The proposal would have set aside earnings from the Permanent Fund, Alaska's oil-wealth savings account, to pay for education as oil revenues decline. That defeat was symbolic of what Cowper says is a tendency ``for today's generation to grab everything they can as cheaply as possible and leave the next generation holding the bag.'' ``I think we have a duty to make the world better for the next generation, and I frankly don't think many people agree with me. But almost everything we did reflected that philosophy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Demand News Photographer's Film At 2 Live Crew Concert
DOC.TEXT: A photographer covering the 2 Live Crew concert was detained by sheriff's deputies and forced to surrender her film as she left the event. Photographer Kathy Anderson had taken pictures of the rap group inside Club Mirage in this New Orleans suburb when one of the band's crew members asked her to leave. The rap group, whose sexually explicit lyrics have created controversy, had announced before the concert that no pictures would be allowed, but Anderson said club operators told her she could photograph the band. As she left the club, six Jefferson Parish deputies stopped her, she said. Anderson, who works for The (New Orleans) Times-Picayune, said Deputy Chief Eugene Fields demanded that she give up her film. She was allowed to leave after handing him two rolls of blank film. She kept film that contained photographs of the band and one appeared in the newspaper's Saturday editions. Sheriff Harry Lee said Friday the officers stopped Anderson because a minor disturbance had broken out in the club about the time she left. He didn't say why deputies confiscated her film.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 12th graf, `There are ...' to UPDATE with some in crowd whistling Havel's speech in protest; picks up 13th graf pvs, `But Jiri ...' ^Tens of Thousands Commemorate Revolution, Cheer Bush
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands converged Saturday in central Prague to commemorate the beginning of the end of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia and to cheer President Bush for standing behind their new democracy. About 100,000 people crowded into Prague's Wenceslas Square, the site of daily demonstrations last year that led to the demise of the Communist leadership and the election of former dissident Vaclav Havel as president. The events began on Nov. 17 last year when police brutally beat down a peaceful demonstration by students. People streamed to the square hours ahead of the planned appearance of Bush and Havel. Some stopped to purchase caps printed in patches of the American flag, or buttons bearing the U.S. president's photograph. One young man, exhibiting the entrepreneurial spirit that will be needed for a successful transformation to a market economy, hawked copper-colored medals pressed by his father-in-law depicting Havel, Pope John Paul II and the first President of Czechoslovakia, Tomas G. Masaryk. Kids hung from the trees lining the square and students and adults waved Czechoslovak and American flags. ``It is a kind of symbol that Bush came this very day,'' said Zdenek Stojan, a 27-year-old building engineer. ``It shows support of the United States for this country.'' He recalled President Woodrow Wilson's support of Masaryk's drive to create an independent Czechoslovakia in 1918, saying, ``The Americans were at the cradle of the first republic.'' One couple, who happened upon the ceremony while on a day trip to the capital from their home town in central Czechoslovakia, purchased a Czech-language copy of the U.S. Constitution, saying they were curious about its contents. Some felt the timing of the President's visit was inappropriate. ``There are lots of celebrations around Bush and the students who started it are almost forgotten,'' said Petr Novotny, a driver. About 3,000 people whistled during Havel's speech, expressing dislike of his policies and the invitation to Bush. ``The current visit of President Bush is based on the fact that Americans are often confused,'' said Miroslav Sladek, the leader of the right-wing Republican Party, which failed to gain parliamentary seats in the June elections. He charged the Bush trip was aimed at boosting what he called the waning authority of Havel and the political movement he founded, Civic Forum, which won the June elections. But Jiri Votruba, an artist, said Bush's visit was well-timed because ``it's a symbolic day, and symbols, especially in Eastern countries, are very important.'' ``I believe it is important that people here feel that someone as important as the U.S. president is standing behind them because people fear it won't be as rosy as they had hoped,'' Votruba said. And Bush received bellowing applause when he pledged to stand behind the new democracy. ``America will not fail you at this decisive moment. America will stand with you,'' Bush said. His speech was translated into Czech for the crowd. Bush, who was applauded several times during his speech, also praised Havel, describing him as ``a man of wisdom and tremendous moral courage.'' The U.S. president promised two gifts to the Czechoslovak people: Masaryk's 1918 declaration of Czechoslovak independence, drafted in the United States and kept for 70 years in the Library of Congress, and the last replica of the Liberty Bell. ``We want to help you spread liberty throughout your beautiful land,'' he said, then tolled the bell three times ``once for your courage, once for your freedom and once for your children.'' The fervent applause that followed his speech subsided only as the crowd joined in singing ``We Shall Overcome'' - the anthem the students sang as they faced cudgel-swinging police who trapped them in a narrow street near the square on this day last year. Many had tears in their eyes as they raised their hands in a V-for-victory sign, singing the song over and over in both English and Czech. The crowd dispersed with chants of ``Long Live Havel.'' ``I'm glad I lived long enough to see American flags on Wenceslas square,'' said Jindriska Maderova, 48. ``The bell was a very beautiful gift.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge FBI to Release File on Reporter Slain in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Florida's two U.S. senators are urging the FBI to release information gathered during an inquiry into the murder of a Tampa reporter in a cocaine-growing area of Peru last year, a newspaper reported Saturday. Sens. Bob Graham, a Democrat, and Connie Mack, a Republican, want FBI Director William Sessions to reconsider his agency's refusal to disclose the file on the death of Todd C. Smith, The Tampa Tribune reported. The newspaper requested the file last year under the federal Freedom of Information Act. ``One year after Todd Smith's death, the nature of his brutal murder - following his kidnapping and apparent torture - is enveloped in a shroud of mystery. This case deserves to be expedited by the FBI,'' the senators wrote in a letter sent Friday. The FBI was asked by Peruvian officials to investigate the murder shortly after Smith's body was found last Nov. 21 in Uchiza, a small cocaine boom town in a remote area of Peru. Smith, taking a working vacation from the Tribune to research cocaine trafficking and terrorism, was kidnapped at gunpoint from an airstrip in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley on Nov. 17, 1989. His body was found beside a soccer field four days later. Officials said he had been strangled and beaten and had been dead for about 24 hours. A sign found near the body denounced Smith as a spy linked to the Pentagon. It was signed by the Communist Party of Peru, the official name of Shining Path, a Maoist group that launched an all-out guerrilla war in the Peruvian highlands in 1980. More than 20,000 Peruvians have died in that war. U.S. and Peruvian officials have not revealed more details about the killing. Eight months after the Tribune made its request, the FBI said it found one file with information about Smith but refused to disclose it, claiming it would interfere with ``enforcement proceedings.'' The agency has refused to elaborate on the nature of the file or say whether the case remains open, but Attorney General Dick Thornburgh recently assured the newspaper that the investigation is continuing. The State Department, which operates an anti-narcotics force in the Upper Huallaga Valley near where Smith was killed, offered little information. Smith's father, Robert, said he was ``satisfied to believe'' Shining Path killed his son. ``I doubt anyone has access to anyone who has knowledge or the willingness to talk about it,'' he said. Shortly after Smith's death, reports surfaced that he had been ``sold'' as an undercover drug agent to a Colombian narcotics trafficker for a bounty of $30,000. Peru's former interior minister endorsed that story, but journalists and U.S. Embassy officials have since cast doubt on it.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguans Increasingly Unhappy With Mrs. Chamorro's Government
DOC.TEXT: Orlando Lucas brought his family back to Nicaragua the day after President Violeta Chamorro was inaugurated in April, ending years of exile in Brazil, Venezuela and the United States. With the leftist Sandinista Front gone from power and Mrs. Chamorro's promise of a new beginning it was time to return because, as Lucas thought, ``there's no place like home.'' Seven months later, Lucas regrets his decision. He is one of a growing number of people disenchanted with Mrs. Chamorro's administration. ``This is a fiasco,'' said Lucas, an agronomist in his mid-40s. Mrs. Chamorro's supporters, stewing in discontent for months, are now protesting because her government has made concessions to the opposition Sandinistas to buy social peace. She took office April 25 after a resounding victory over Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in Feb. 25 elections. But Mrs. Chamorro allowed Sandinista commanders to remain at the head of the military and police. Those who complain say that, while they believe Mrs. Chamorro is well-intentioned, the minister of the presidency, Antonio Lacayo, treats the Sandinistas with kid gloves and the president's supporters with an iron fist. Lacayo, believed by most Nicaraguans the power behind Mrs. Chamorro, has said his countrymen must shed a winner-takes-all political heritage and learn to coexist peacefully and share with the losers. The simmering discontent boiled over two weeks ago into a protest movement by mayors and demobilized Contra rebels in the rich agricultural region around Juigalpa, 85 miles southeast of Managua. Protesters want Mrs. Chamorro to deliver on promises of land and aid for the former U.S.-backed rebels who for nine years fought the leftist Sandinistas. By the government's own figures, barely 3,000 of the 20,000 rebels who finished disbanding in June have received land. ``Our mistake was scheduling the laying-down of our weapons and failing to schedule the fulfillment of her promises,'' said Oscar Sovalbarro, a former Contra leader also known as ``Commander Ruben.'' ``The (Sandinista) army and police were the only ones who came out ahead,'' he said. ``Now that we have disarmed, we feel repressed and threatened.'' The mayors and former rebels also want Mrs. Chamorro to fire army chief Gen. Humberto Ortega, brother of the former Sandinista president, and the regional chiefs of the Sandinista Police and Sandinista People's Army. ``I voted for a change. There's been no change,'' said Jose Luis Gutierrez, a civilian who helped the Contras when they were still guerrillas roaming the lush hills of Boaco and Chontales provinces, fighting the Sandinistas. The mayors and former rebels have also asked Mrs. Chamorro to fire Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado, in charge of the police, and Lacayo, the president's son-in-law. Lucas, Gutierrez, the mayors and ex-rebels are not alone in their discontent. Mrs. Chamorro's attempts to reconcile her countrymen in post-Sandinista Nicaragua have resulted only in alienating nearly all those sectors that helped bring her to power. Business leaders are bitter. Returning exiles are dismayed. The former rebels feel betrayed. The Roman Catholic Church led by Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo has been unusually outspoken in condemning her government's actions. Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition is deeply divided. Even her own family newspaper, La Prensa, published a stinging editorial this week entitled ``The President Sees With A Limited Perspective.'' It chided Mrs. Chamorro for asking protesters to go back to their homes and jobs and accused her of failing to grasp the country's political reality. ``They cannot go back to work, as President Chamorro would like, because armed Sandinistas are the only law that prevails in many regions of the country, especially the areas where the protests have occurred,'' the editorial said. It accused Mrs. Chamorro of allying herself ``with those who are really sabotaging her healthy government policy'' - a reference to the Sandinistas. Even her estranged vice president, Virgilio Godoy, is rumored to have been stirring up the protest movement. Godoy, while denying his involvement, called it ``a beautiful civic protest.'' The protest movement has blocked off one-fifth of the country and resulted in 10 deaths and dozens of wounded in clashes between police and protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Winning Inventor Likes the Money, Loves the Cause
DOC.TEXT: Robert Kearns' voice lacked the giddiness one would expect from someone about to get a $10.2 million check from a huge corporation. To the 63-year-old inventor, getting justice from the patent system is even more important than the money. Kearns settled a 12-year-old patent infringement lawsuit against Ford Motor Co. last week. And he still has similar suits pending against other automakers. At issue was his patent for intermittent windshield wipers, which go on and off periodically. They are a part of nearly every new car sold these days. For Kearns, who lives in a one-bedroom rented apartment with rented furniture in Houston, the money isn't bad, but the case is mainly about winning fairness. ``I don't mean to be so harsh on the patent system, but an infringer can just follow what has happened in this case and usurp the ability of inventors to start new businesses,'' Kearns said in a telephone interview from a friend's house in Maryland, where the settlement was approved. Ford attorney Malcolm Wheeler said the settlement was fair but Ford would have won if the case had been retried. There will be several million left for Kearns after the Ford settlement is shared with his attorneys. It will easily be enough to buy a house he wants in Texas and to finance his legal battles against 19 other automakers. ``If I don't go further, there really isn't a patent system,'' he said. Each of Kearns' suits alleges basically the same thing - that the companies profited from his windshield wiper patent and he should share the money they made. Settling the cases or winning in jury trials could mean more millions for Kearns. And millions more for attorneys. Kearns and one member of his legal team, Bill Durkee of Houston, declined to say how much the case against Ford cost. There have been estimates that legal bills ran more than $300,000. A standard contingency fee of one third of the settlement would give Durkee's firm $3 million to $4 million. ``(Lawyers) are running a business,'' Kearns said. ``I'm running a cause.'' Kearns had claimed he installed a set of intermittent wipers on a Ford and took it to the automaker. Kearns, a professor at Wayne State University in Detroit at the time, said he was led to believe Ford would buy his invention by the number of questions engineers asked. When that failed to happen, he sued. Originally, Kearns sought $141 million from Ford. In July, a jury ordered Ford to pay $5.2 million, plus interest, for patent infringement, for a total of $8.5 million to $11.5 million. Kearns appealed the award and the settlement was reached before the appeal could be decided. Ford dealers have sold an estimated 20 million Ford, Lincoln and Mercury cars with intermittent wipers. After legal defense costs, the settlement nets Kearns 33 cents per car. The problem as Kearns sees it is the patent system's failure to protect small inventors from predator corporations by making it difficult to prove the validity of their patents. The mere mention of some similar device recorded somewhere before the patent was issued could be ammunition in a corporation's legal guns. ``The inventor is up against every dusty lbrary in the world,'' Kearns said. In some cases, the patent system works fine. ``If a person was an inventor whose only intent was to conceive of something and then pass it on to someone else, maybe that's still viable,'' Kearns said. But when someone like Kearns wants to bring an invention to market, the patent system is a roadblock because it allows for a legal morass like the one Kearns found himself in. And that goes back to money. ``I think the thing that would help the inventors most would be fast trials,'' said patent attorney Richard Samuel of Philadelphia. He represented Gordon Gould in his successful patent fight over the laser. ``I think that probably from a legal perspective, the problem is more one of the cumbersomeness of the courts,'' Samuel said. ``It's an expensive process and the individual inventor can't afford to go through the courts.'' Samuel said things are getting better for inventors though. In the early 1980s, a federal appeals court was established just for patent cases.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Lowers Some Philadelphia Bond Rates
DOC.TEXT: Citing the ``scant progress'' city officials have made toward solving the financial crisis, Moody's Investor Service has demoted two more municipal bonds to junk-bond status. On Friday, Moody's dropped the rating of the city's water and sewer bonds from Baa to B. The airport revenue bonds dropped from Ba to B. Moody's assistant vice president Nancy Barbe called it a ``very significant'' drop. Unless action occurs in the next several weeks, the city expects to run out of money by mid-December, disrupting payroll and services. An effort to avoid the immediate crisis by floating $375 million in short-term notes last August failed when banks refused to guarantee them. In September, Moody's lowered the city's general obligation bonds to a B rating, one rating short of default, following Standard & Poor's Corp. move to drop the rating to CCC, the lowest among major U.S. cities. Standard's rating indicates Philadelphia is vulnerable to default on bond payments. Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other Democratic leaders in the state have proposed trying to float another bond sale to keep from going broke. They also want to raise taxes, pry more money out of the state and federal governments and sell city assets to head off a $229.5 million deficit at the end of the fiscal year. The plan, released earlier this month, received a poor reception from City Council and Republicans. Moody's called it vague. Two members of City Council have promised to offer alternatives this week. ``Everyone seems to be talking about the need for the development of a political consensus before the city's fiscal problems can be addressed. It's not clear that consensus has been achieved,'' Ms. Barbe said. Goode's office did not return telephone calls for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leader: Pope To Back Message that Anti-Semitism Is `Sin'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has promised to push forward efforts, especially in Eastern Europe, to spread the message that anti-Semitism is a ``sin,'' a British Jewish leader said Saturday. The pope met with directors of the British Council for Christians and Jews at the Vatican on Friday and told them he was ``very pleased'' about continuing contacts between the two faiths, including a meeting in Prague in September. Catholic delegates at that meeting condemned anti-Semitism as well as all forms of racism as ``a sin against God and humanity.'' That statement came at the end of the first formal meeting in five years of the Pontifical Commission on Religious Relations with the Jews and the International Jewish Committee on Interreligious Consultations. Sir Sigmund Sternberg, a British Jewish leader present at the meeting Friday with the pope, said he was encouraged that John Paul repeated the words of the Prague declaration. He said he told the Polish-born pontiff that he was concerned about the growth of anti-Semitic incidents in Eastern Europe and expressed his concern that ``the pope's view be known at the grass-roots level.'' ``The pope assured me that he would get the message out'' at the parish level about anti-Semitism being regarded as a sin, Sternberg said. He expressed optimism about efforts, started after the Second Vatican Council in the early 1960s, to improve relations between religions. ``You cannot undo in 25 years the damage done in more than 1,900 years,'' he said. A plan drawn up at the Prague conference called for the establishment of courses for priests to counter anti-Jewish sentiment. It also recommended swift dissemination of recent Vatican statements on Catholic-Jewish relations by Eastern European churches. Sternberg was involved in helping to defuse a major dispute that threatened to derail efforts to mend Roman Catholic-Jewish relations. The dispute centered on the presence of a Catholic convent just outside the site of the World War II concentration camp at Auschwitz, or Oswiecim, Poland. Jewish groups said the convent and its Christian symbols, including a 23-foot-high cross, offended the memory of the 2.5 million Jews who were put to death in the camp only because they were Jews. After bitter controversy, it was decided to construct a religious center for the nuns about a quarter-mile from the death camp.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 50,000 March to Demand Truth About `Gladio'
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 demonstrators marched through Rome on Saturday demanding the truth about the anti-communist network known as Gladio, established during the Cold War and kept secret until recently. The protest, organized by the Communist Party, also called for more disclosure about a series of mysterious terrorist attacks in Italy from 1969 through the early 1980s. The Communists, Italy's second-biggest party, have speculated that Gladio may have been linked to the terrorist attacks attributed to the right wing from 1969 to the early 1980s, when the party came to the brink of power. ``We are here to obtain truth and transparency,'' Communist Party leader Achille Occhetto told the crowd in the central Piazza del Popolo at the end of the march. Premier Giulio Andreotti last month disclosed the existence of Gladio, a network of civilians trained by the Italian secret services to form a guerrilla movement in the event of a foreign attack. It was active until last month. Since his announcement, other European governments have acknowledged similar organizations in their countries. Several were coordinated through NATO and some received U.S. aid. Traffic police said between 50,000 and 60,000 people took part in the demonstration, while national police put the number at 100,000. Organizers said 400,000 people joined in. Some marchers dressed up as gladiators. Gladio was named for the doubled-edged swords carried by Roman gladiators. Occhetto on Saturday called for a special parliamentary commission to investigate Gladio. He also reiterated his demand that Andreotti step down for having failed to disclose the existence of the group. So far, none of the five parties forming the coalition government has endorsed the demands. Parliament last week opened hearings on the secret operation. Gladio is also under investigation by a Rome magistrate. In Germany, meanwhile, a magazine reported Saturday that the job of the German banch of Gladio was preparation for sabotage attacks and resistance behind enemy lines. The government said Friday the German branch still exists. But a government spokesman said the units would not have been assigned to conduct behind-the-lines sabotage operations. The weekly magazine, Spiegel, said the German branch had operated beginning in 1959. It said that the Allied Coordination Committee at NATO had ordered the dissolution of the secret network, and that Germany was to try to accomplish this by 1991. The report, appearing in the magazine's Monday edition, was made available in advance to other news organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Soviet Government Structure at a Glance
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As outlined by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his aides, here is a look at the changes the Soviet president proposed Saturday to the Supreme Soviet legislature: ---
TO BE CREATED OR REVAMPED: ---

Federation Council - Created in March as an advisory board including representatives of the 15 Soviet republics, Gorbachev proposed strengthening and making this organ more active. Gorbachev said it would coordinate actions by the central and republic governments. Aides said it would become the highest body of state power. ---
Inter-Republican Committee - A permanent, working organ of the Federation Council, this new body would be made up of experts from the republics. ---
National Security Council: Made up of representatives of the KGB secret police, Interior Ministry, Defense Ministry and Foreign Ministry, this new body would discuss security and defense issues. ---

Cabinet of Ministers - This new group of government ministers would be subordinate to the Federation Council. It would not have the power to make decisions but would merely implement them. A Gorbachev aide says it would have a ``technocratic'' function. ---

Law enforcement body - Not yet given a title, Gorbachev says this body would act under him and coordinate the work of law enforcement agencies to combat organized crime, black marketeering and other crime. It would include a ``special service'' reporting to the president and have representatives ``in all regions to ensure implementation of laws, decisions and directives.'' ---
TO BE ELIMINATED:

Council of Ministers - This grouping of dozens of ministers, ranging from those in charge of nuclear energy to food production, would be eliminated. It has wielded great power, particularly over price-setting, production targets and allocation of resources. ---
Presidential Council - This 18-member advisory body, which was created in March and made up of political and cultural figures, would be eliminated and its powers given to the Federation Council. ---
Prime Minister - This powerful post, assigned to the person who manages the government structure, would be eliminated, according to the man currently holding it, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Say They Are Eager to Risk Lives For Peace
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: On an island in the Tigris, just a little south of Saddam Hussein's presidential palace, a small group of Europeans say they are risking their lives for peace. It is an idea they hope catches on. ``The idea is to work toward filling the battlefield with peace workers before any war can break out. This has never been done before in history,'' said Ulf Amsell, a lanky 46-year-old transport worker from Sweden. ``If more people follow my idea, it can be effective. Perhaps 5,000 would be enough. This is my purpose.'' Amsell and his companions at the World Peace and Friendship Camp say they are voluntarily making themselves ``human shields'' in this country that is already holding thousands of other Westerners against their will, including some detained at potential military targets. Iraqi officials are delighted to host the European pacifists in the tiny island cottages usually reserved for honeymooners. Their willing presence, in Iraqi eyes, bolsters the government argument that the Western hostages are guests, playing a role for peace by deterring an attack by U.S. and allied forces in Saudi Arabia. But unlike their compatriots, these Europeans can leave Iraq whenever they want. And most plan to stay only for a week or two. ``I am not afraid they will keep me here,'' said Jon Peter Oie, 31, of Norway. ``No one in the world can come here if they keep the peace workers.'' Officials from Iraq's Ministry of Information and Culture have arranged lectures on Iraqi history for the Europeans and bus tours to factory sites around Baghdad. They also trot the peace activists out before the world press. ``We've received many requests and applications from peace activists from various parts of the world to establish peace camps in many parts of Iraq, in many towns and even on the front lines,'' Information Minister Latif Nsayyif Jassim said Saturday. ``We highly appreciate and respect all these volunteers who have come here to serve peace out of human and moral considerations,'' he added. On Saturday, the Europeans were taken to a clothing factory in Baghdad where they were cheered by the women behind the sewing machines. They were also told by the plant manager that the invasion of Kuwait is an Arab problem that can only be settled by Saddam's Aug. 12 proposal, which linked the crisis to the solution of all other Middle East problems. ``We do not support the Iraqi government,'' insisted Rino La Rocca, a 38-year-old photographer from Naples. ``We have been very critical of the government. I support the Iraqi people during this very dangerous situation. ``We are testifying with our physical presence to our desire to avoid war,'' he said. ``We have been criticized by leftist parties in Italy for coming here,'' added Nesi Manlio, 36, another of the 13 Italians at the camp. ``But the parties just say a lot of words about war and do nothing to stop it. ``It is too easy to be against war in Italy. I have a job, a car, a house. It is too easy to say you are against the war. Here i am risking my life and that is important,'' he added. The group at the camp also includes six Soviets, led by Stanislov Korolev, a professor of theology in Moscow. He said the Soviets had never heard of the camp until they were taken there by Iraqi authorities after their arrival in Baghdad. Outside the camp's cottages are posted signs in French and English with slogans such as ``Messengers of Peace Greet Saddam Hussein, Man of the Hour,'' and ``USA Enemy of Man.'' ``Cut Off Heads, Not Sustenance,'' read one. The signs were put up by the Iraqis, and some were decorated with pictures of Saddam. The peace activists emphasized that their presence did not mean support for Saddam. ``I don't want to be used by anybody. I don't support the Iraqi government,'' said Oie. ``I only support peace.'' Antonella Straface, 28, of Bari, Italy, an Islamic philosophy student at the University of Naples, said she had come to Iraq to visit two friends held hostage and to ``see it with my own eyes.'' She said she did not believe what was written about Iraq in Western newspapers. ``The West has supported the policy of this government. All of us know the policy of this man (Saddam) - the policies against the Kurdish people, the people of Iran. But no newspaper in Italy wrote against those policies.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Greet 48th Running of Santa Train
LaserPhoto LH1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of elated children greeted Santa Claus on Saturday as the Santa Train made a bittersweet ride through the impoverished Appalachian mountains. About 12 tons of toys, snacks and gifts were tossed to eager children - and a few greedy adults - as the train made its 48th annual run through Kentucky, Virginia, and Tennessee. The train ride kicks off the Christmas season for small coal towns between Pikeville, Ky., and Kingsport, Tenn. But many who helped Santa toss gifts to excited youngsters lining the tracks spoke of the experience with a tinge of sorrow. ``If you can go and throw this stuff off without crying, you're a better man than I,'' said Darrell Rice of Kingsport, one of the dozens of volunteers aboard the train. The trip is sponsored by CSX Transportation of Jacksonville, Fla., and the Kingsport Area Chamber of Commerce. Companies across the nation donate boxes of merchandise: magnetic backgammon sets, pencils, packets of instant oatmeal, bags of pretzels and comic books. One of the train's seven stops was in Elkhorn City, Ky., straddling the Kentucky-Virginia border. Marietta Hogson of Ferrell's Creek guarded her 5-year-old son, Adam, as a crowd clamored for Santa's attention. ``I'm afraid he'll get trampled if he gets too close,'' Mrs. Hogson said. The train winds through the major coal producing areas of Appalachia, where some communities are suffering from coal industry layoffs. CSX and Chamber of Commerce officials say the gummy bears and tablets that kids pluck from between the rail ties may be all they receive for Christmas. Gregory Belcher of Elkhorn City disagreed. ``A lot of people are out of work in this area, but I don't think it's that bad,'' he said.
