Belcher's son, Christopher, dropped off an armload of tablets, pencils and a cookbook, and then sprinted back to the crowd for more. ``The focus of this, as far as I'm concerned, is the great tradition of the train,'' said Frank Brogden, who has served as Santa Claus since 1984. ``I think some people would think they would be put down a bit if you focus on poverty.'' Parents with video cameras showed up at many of the train crossings. And the seamy side of Christmas was apparent as a group of adults chased the train from crossing to crossing in southwestern Virginia to hoard gifts. CSX spokesman Tim Hensley wouldn't specify the cost of the train ride, formally known as the Santa Claus Special. ``It costs a whole lot of good will,'' Hensley said. ``We operate this train from the bottom of our heart, not the bottom line.'' The tradition began in 1943 when the line was part of the Clinchfield Railroad. Organizing and distributing the gifts is a dizzying effort. For 38 years, Raymond Galyon of Kingsport has helped solicit donations from merchants and businesses. ``I put about 300 hours a year doing this,'' said Galyon, sitting atop boxes of gifts. This year's bounty was valued between $150,000 to $200,000, he said. At a stop in St. Paul, volunteers furiously tossed buckets of gifts at the crowd. As Christmas carols played on a tape player, Santa handed out the larger toys - plastic trucks or dolls - to youngsters. The Christmas spirit aboard the train was infectious, in large part because of Lois Mee of Durham, N.C. She donated 30 boxes of gifts, including 243 dolls with hand-knitted dresses, 112 pair of mittens and hundreds of suckers. ``Honey, this is the happiest day of my life. I'm so thrilled I can't get over it,'' said Mrs. Mee, dressed in a bright red sweater and green jacket. ``I'm tenderhearted, I guess. If I was a millionaire, I wouldn't have a dime.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Saudi Troops Get Ready For Mock Invasion
With AM-Gulf Rdp
LaserPhotos DOD1,2
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy Seals checked a landing zone for mines and obstacles Saturday to prepare for a mock assault from the sea by U.S. and Saudi marines in an exercise menacingly named Imminent Thunder. About 500 to 800 troops will hit the beach Sunday. Commanders said the key objective is to practice an assault from ships that are 30 miles from shore. The technique is called over-the-horizon, which gives the attackers the element of surprise because an enemy won't know which beach is targeted. ``It's a new capability. Nobody else has it,'' said Rear Adm. John B. LaPlante, commander of the amphibious strike force. The war games also allow troops to practice the tricky work of getting troops ashore under cover of warplanes. Troops will be ferried by landing craft and attack helicopters launched simultaneously. ``Amphibious warfare is an immensely complex thing to bring off,'' LaPlante said. ``It's difficult and it takes practice and training.'' Among the first tanks to hit the beach will be an M-60 model nicknamed ``Sodamn Insane.'' Cpl. James Quade, 25, of Lexington Park, Md., said the amphibious exercises have become so commonplace that many Marines are treating it as just another day. ``The only part we get geared up about is to make sure we don't have any of the tanks go down,'' said Quade, a forward observer with Alpha Company of the 2nd Tank Battalion. Reports of the six-day exercise were taken from pool reports, based on briefings given aboard the USS Nassau, the flagship for the amphibious landing. Imminent Thunder is the fourth amphibious exercise staged in the gulf since Operation Desert Shield was launched in August. However, it is the first on Saudi soil, the first to involve U.S. and Saudi marines and the largest force of warplanes used in war games by a multinational force assembled to check Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. About 1,100 aircraft are involved in the exercise, but military officials said they won't all be airborne at once. ``It doesn't mean the skies at the beach are going to be black with aircraft,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Ron Morse, a U.S. Navy spokesman. One of the objectives is to keep aircraft from running into each other. Flight controllers have given different ceilings to helicopters and attack jets such as AV-8B Harrier close support jets, F/A-18 Hornets, F-14 Tomcats and A-6 Intruders. About 50 British aircraft are also involved in the drill, including Nimrod surveillance planes and Tornado and Jaguar attack jets. ``The biggest challenge is to make sure we have aircraft separation,'' said Cmdr. Mickey Haskins, commanding officer of Tactical Air Control Squadron 22. Navy Cmdr. Dave Stewart, also known as ``Air Boss,'' controls the Harriers and Cobra helicopter gunships from the flight deck of the Nassau. ``This is my fifth national crisis in about 20 years, and they're all about the same,'' Stewart said. Although the number of warplanes was significant, LaPlante said the number of Marines and ships involved was ``very modest in size and scope.'' Imminent Thunder involves 16 ships, including the aircraft carrier USS Midway and its battle group and the battleship USS Wisconsin. Five amphibious assault ships are being used. Iraq has called Imminent Thunder a ``provocative act.'' The Pentagon has denied it was designed to stir up the Iraqis. Officials say the landing will be about 100 miles south of the Kuwaiti border on an unnamed Saudi beach.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leader Urges Release of All Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Iranians meeting Christian patriarch, other details, quotes, CORRECT that second appeal since Thursday. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI2
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric on Saturday urged the release of all Western hostages on humanitarian grounds, in his second such appeal in three days. ``We have to work for closing the file of the hostages and those unjustifiably detained, be they Iranians, Americans, Europeans or Lebanese,'' Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah said. ``This whole file should be closed because it is a humanitarian issue.'' Fadlallah is the spiritual guide of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, the umbrella organization for underground Shiite factions believed holding most of the 13 Westerners in Lebanon, including six Americans. ``To those who think that releasing the hostages would be in favor of the Western states, we say it would be in favor of humanity, which is not separate from Islamic values,'' Fadlallah said in a statement. The spiritual leader made a similar appeal Thursday. More than 300 Shiite Moslems are held at the Khiam prison in southern Lebanon, controlled by the Israeli-affiliated South Lebanon Army militia. Several are Hezbollah fighters. Their release, along with that of Arab prisoners held in Israel, has frequently figured among demands put forward by the captors of Western hostages. Hezbollah says an undisclosed number of its members are held by Christian militias in east Beirut. Fadlallah did not directly link release of the Western captives to revealing the fate of four missing Iranians or the release of Arabs in Khiam and Israel. Fadlallah's past statements encouraging the release of Western hostages appear to have had no tangible effect on the kidnappers, despite the influence of his religious authority. But when a group calling itself Organization Islamic Dawn released Americans Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April, it said the releases were partly at the ``behest of senior religious leaders.'' Relatives of the four Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon's Christian enclave in 1982 arrived here Tuesday in an effort to obtain information. They have met with politicians and religious officials. They say they received information that the four are being held at a prison run by Christian warlord Samir Geagea in the Faraya ski resort northeast of Beirut. Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia has said, however, the four were killed by rival Christian chief Elie Hobeika. The Iranians crossed into the Christian heartland Saturday for a 30-minute audience with Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of Lebanon's dominant Maronite Catholic community. The patriarch said he had conflicting reports about the fate of the Iranians and that he would try to establish the truth about their fate. The longest held of the 13 missing Westerners is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Mourn Victims Of Temple Mount Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with reported slaying of suspected Arab collaborator. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian families in Arab east Jerusalem held receptions Saturday to mark the 40th day of mourning since their relatives were killed in the Temple Mount shootings. At Abdel Rahman Kashour's house in the walled Old City, a white flag flew outside instead of a traditional black flag. Kashour's 19-year-old son, Burhan, was by Arab accounts the first to be killed when police opened fire on the mount Oct. 8, killing at least 17 Palestinians. ``This is the day of a wedding, not mourning,'' said Kashour, a 62-year-old electrician, explaining the white flag. He said his son was nicknamed the ``bridegroom of al-Aqsa'' after the revered mosque atop the mount, the third holiest shrine in Islam. The flag was decorated with an Islamic saying: ``There is no God but one God.'' An Israeli government investigation blamed Palestinian stone-throwers for the riot. But it criticized police commanders for their failure to anticipate trouble and said there were instances of ``unsupervised'' gunfire. There has been a shake-up within the police, but no disciplinary action was taken against officers mentioned in the report. The Temple Mount is known to Arabs as Haram es-Sharif, or ``Noble Sanctuary.'' Tradition says Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven from the spot. It is also revered by the Jews as the site of their ancient Temple, destroyed by the Romans. ``God gave Burhan to me and God took him away,'' said Kashour, a devout Moslem. ``What makes it easier is that we believe in God.'' His wife wept. A picture of Burhan hung on the wall, surrounded by flowers and about a dozen small plagues brought by visitors. Hundreds came to Kashour's house Saturday to pay their respects - Burhan's teachers, former classmates, amd neighbors. Atop the house and on a nearby roof, there were also two outlawed Palestinian flags and strips of cloth covered with verses from the Koran, Islam's holy book. The crowd occasionally broke into nationalist songs: ``Palestine needs men to become martyrs,'' and ``Palestine must return.'' Kashour proudly recalled his son, an athlete who ``could jump more than three meters high.'' Burhan, one of the family's seven children, was never jailed during the 35-month-old Palestinian uprising and planned to study art in the United States. ``Last time I saw him, it was 10 in the morning,'' Kashour said. ``Half an hour later, he was dead. He went to pray and was killed. Now I go every day to pray on his blood.'' Elsewhere in the Arab east Jerusalem on Saturday, police arrested three schoolgirls and closed a school after several stone-throwing incidents, officials said. Jerusalem police spokesman Aharon Elchayani said about 200 high school girls demonstrated and threw stones at police near the Mamuniye school. Police dispersed them by firing tear gas grenades, and three of the girls were arrested, he said. Witnesses said that several girls lost consciousness after being overcome by tear gas. Others ran into the St. George Hospital nearby, and police were seen throwing tear gas grenades into the hospital compound. It was the third day of scattered demonstrations in the annexed eastern part of the city, which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The demonstrations were linked to the second anniversary Thursday of the Palestinians' proclamation of ``independence'' in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. In the Gaza village of Abasan, Palestinian militants stabbed to death Musa Ahmed Arafat, 45, after accusing him of assisting Israel, Arab reports said. The death raised to 300 the number of Arabs slain by fellow Palestinians as alleged collaborators with Israel. At least 773 Arabs have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt. Fifty-two Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Arrested in More Anti-Abortion Protests
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred protesters were arrested Saturday in a second straight day of anti-abortion demonstrations outside abortion clinics. Randall Terry, the head of Operation Rescue, was among those detained and loaded into two police buses outside a clinic in downtown Washington, witnesses said. Police had no immediate comment on the number taken into custody, but a local TV station, WRC, said about 300 were arrested. On Friday 340 protesters were arrested as part of the two-day campaign staged by Operation Rescue, a national anti-abortion activist group. ``If we saved one baby today, we accomplished more than anything,'' said Tom Hall of Buffalo, N.Y., a protester who was arrested on Friday. He said those arrested were given citations with $50 fines and released. Operation Rescue members said about 1,000 people from across the country had come to Washington for the demonstrations. On Saturday they demonstrated at three places, including the downtown clinic and a Planned Parenthood office. All the arrests apparently took place outside the clinic, where protesters sang hymns, waved banners and exchanged jeers with those opposed to their cause. A group advocating abortion rights, the Washington Area Clinic Defense Task Force, said some 500 people participated in a counter-demonstration and joined efforts to ensure that women wanting to enter the clinic would not be impeded. Karen Orlando, a member of the task force, said there was some pushing between the two groups but no real trouble. She said three abortion rights supporters were ``mistakenly'' arrested when they were caught in a crowd being moved by police into the buses. She said the protesters were arrested for trying to block the clinic's entrance, but Operation Rescue members claimed one of their leaders, Pat Mahoney, was hauled off by police while he was on his knees praying on a sidewalk across the street. Federal judges in the District of Columbia, Virginia and Maryland have issued permanent injunctions against Operation Rescue, Terry and several of its other leaders to prevent them from blocking entrances or exits to clinics.

DOC.HEAD: Angola's Ruling Party Announces Political Realignment
DOC.TEXT: The governing party has proposed a new strategy of democratic socialism and economic reform, breaking with 15 years of Marxist rule. The central committee of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola announced the new strategy Friday night after a three-day meeting. There was no immediate response from the rebels of UNITA - the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. The announcement came as a delegation from the government met in Portugal with the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels for the latest round of peace talks to end a 15-year-old civil war and prepare Angola's transition to democracy. The talks, mediated by the Portuguese government, were private. A Portuguese official said a statement would be released only after the talks ended, probably Monday. The two sides have met five times in Portugal in the past eight months. Friday's governing party statement said the party would work to introduce a mixed economy in Angola, with protection for private property and foreign investment. Sources close to the central committee said the declaration was a compromise between party liberals and hard-liners. The governing party's rise to power after the collapse of Portuguese colonial rule in Angola sparked a long conflict fueled by heavy infusions of foreign weaponry. South Africa backed the UNITA rebels with troops and arms against the Communist government, while Cuba sent about 50,000 troops to back the MPLA in the civil war. The United States and the Soviet Union sent arms to back their allies in the war, which, according to government figures, has killed more than 350,000 people. Under a 1988 peace accord, South Africa pledged to halt aid to UNITA and Cuban troops began a pull out scheduled to end next summer. However, heavy fighting has continued and both superpowers maintain arms supplies to Angola. The governing party has recently announced its acceptance of multiparty government. Last month, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos said opposition parties could be legalized early next year and elections held within three years of a cease-fire. The UNITA rebels are demanding further political guarantees and want elections before December 1991.

DOC.HEAD: State To Gun Dealer: `You Don't Have To Sell Him the Gun'
DOC.TEXT: A state Department of Justice official who refused to block the sale of a gun later used in a fatal night of terror in a Berkeley barroom says the gun dealer didn't have to sell the weapon. The dealer says he did. The department's statements followed remarks by Bob Weaver of El Cerrito's Old West Gun Room on Friday that the department told him ``there was nothing they could do'' to keep the gun from Mehrdad Dashti, a one-time mental patient. Dashti's Sept. 27 rampage killed John Sheehy, 22, and wounded nine other University of California students before police stormed Henry's Publick House & Grille at the Durant Hotel, freed the hostages and shot the gunman to death. Bob Drake, chief of the Justice Department's Division of Law Enforcement, said Weaver had called the department saying, ``I think we have a mental here.'' Drake said his people checked with the state Department of Mental Health ``and his name wasn't there.'' ``I don't like to be nasty to him (Weaver) but we advised him, `Look, you don't have to sell him the gun. It's your choice,''' Drake said. The Justice Department has no authority to deny the sale of a gun to an individual without lawful evidence, Drake said. Weaver, told of Drake's remarks, said, ``I didn't want to get sued ... I could get sued for prejudice, for discrimination against the man I didn't sell to. I didn't have any proof that he was a mental patient. What more could I do?'' During the state-mandated 15-day waiting period in handgun sales, an acquaintance of Dashti's came in to Weaver's shop and warned him of Dashti's mental problems. Weaver said he partially disabled the safety on the Ruger before first handing it over. Dashti quickly returned it, and Weaver faked a return to the manufacturer ostensibly to get it repaired, then handed it over when the Justice Department declined to block the sale. The police records backed Weaver's story, saying that all through the waiting period, ``Weaver had the gun in the store, but was very reluctant to release it to Dashti.'' Although Dashti got into minor trouble with the law and had been a patient at the Berkeley Mental Health Clinic, it was legal for him to buy handguns. Alameda County authorities had assessed Dashti as a paranoid schizophrenic.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Prague
Slovak Nationalists Mar Revolution Anniversary Rally
DOC.TEXT: About 300 nationalist activists jeered and threw stones Saturday at a speaker addressing some 30,000 Slovaks gathered to celebrate the first anniversary of communism's downfall in Czechoslovakia. The small group of activists surrounded the speaker's rostrum on Bratislava's National Uprising Square and began whistling and throwing stones as former dissident Miroslav Kusy addressed the rally celebrating last year's ``Velvet Revolution'' that ended four decades of communist rule. The nationalists waved banners reading ``Independent Slovakia'' and ``Prague go home'' at the rally called by Public Against Violence, leading party in Slovakia's coalition government and sister movement to Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum. Slovak nationalism, suppressed under the communists, has been rising since last November. Radicals are not satisfied with federal government moves to devolve more powers to both Czech and Slovak republics. Kusy, a prominent philosopher and rector of Bratislava's Komensky University, was visibly shaken as he ducked flying stones and he called on the crowd for support. The crowds responded by falling silent. Police at the edge of the square could not intervene. There were no clashes between the two groups of demonstrators. The marred rally contrasted with the enthusiastic anniversary celebrations in Prague, where tens of thousands packed central Wenceslas Square to cheer President Bush for standing by their fledgling democracy. The nationalists began protesting after Kusy criticized Slovak separatists, saying they should ``decide for nonviolence, peace and legal means.'' He urged ``positive relations'' between all nationalities in Slovakia, saying special respect should be shown for the region's 600,000 minority Hungarians. Calls have become more strident recently for Slovak secession from the Czechoslovak federation formed in 1918, disbanded by the Nazis and forcibly reformed by the communists in 1968. Nationalist radicals were outraged last month when Slovakia's parliament passed a law allowing ethnic Hungarians to use their language officially in areas where they make up 20 percent of the population. Angry protesters marched through Bratislava, calling for a tougher law and demanding the government's resignation, and 25 nationalists began a hunger strike in protest.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Issue: Do Homeless Have Privacy?
DOC.TEXT: A homeless man convicted of murder is appealing his case to the state Supreme Court, arguing his constitutional rights were violated when police searched his makeshift home beneath an interstate highway. David Mooney's case, which the court is expected to decide soon, raises for the first time in Connecticut the question of whether the privacy of homeless people is protected by the Fourth Amendment. The Fourth Amendment protects the rights of individuals ``to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures.'' Mooney, now serving a 50-year sentence at Somers state prison, contends the search was unreasonable because police did not have a search warrant, which they would have needed to search a more traditional residence. Mooney was homeless and living beneath Interstate 91 in New Haven for a brief period in the summer of 1987, when police were investigating the strangulation death of Theodore Genovese, a 48-year-old hospital worker in New Haven. Another suspect in the case implicated Mooney, charging that he and Mooney went to visit Genovese, ostensibly for a homosexual liaison, but in fact to rob him. Mooney has denied any involvement in the crime. After Mooney was picked up for questioning by New Haven police, his girlfriend led police on a search of the spot beneath the highway where he kept his belongings and slept. In a cardboard box, police found a 38-inch belt matching the waist size of the victim. In a duffel bag, they found a pair of bloody trousers. Mooney failed in various motions to have the evidence suppressed, and was convicted in March 1989 of felony murder and robbery. Mooney's appeal raises several questions: What constitutes a ``home,'' and how much privacy can the homeless expect? ``I didn't feel homeless,'' Mooney said in a newspaper interview. ``I felt at home. I felt more at home than when I had an apartment.'' Robert M. Hayes, an authority on the legal rights of the homeless, said Mooney's position is ``legally right.'' He noted that a federal judge in New York ruled last year that, for the purposes of voter registration, a park bench could be considered a home. But he added, ``It's a miserable, wretched right to win. It suggests a social acceptance of homelessness as a fact of life, which should be resisted to the grave.'' In opposing Mooney's appeal, Assistant State's Attorney Judith Rossi argued that Mooney ``was not legitimately residing at the bridge abutment, as he himself realized.'' ``The defendant's decision to `reside' at the bridge abutment does not change either his status as an interloper or the public, i.e. open, nature of the land,'' she said. Last year, Superior Court Judge Joseph J. Purtill ruled that police had a ``perfect right'' to search Mooney's makeshift home without a warrant. ``I have serious questions as to whether or not the Fourth Amendment was ever intended to protect people's rights in such a location,'' he ruled. But Emanuel Margolis, the chairman of the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Mooney's public defender, said times have changed, and the law must change as well. ``This is not some isolated case of a trespasser who comes, without permission, upon a bridge abutment and says `I'm going to be a squatter,'' he argued before the state Supreme Court. ``We have thousands and thousands of homeless in Connecticut.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Agrees to End Boycott Of Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The country's political leaders reached an agreement Saturday that clears the way for two opposition parties to end their four-month boycott of parliament. The floor leaders of the governing party and the opposition held a joint news conference, saying they had agreed to hold local assembly elections in the first half of next year. Mayoral and gubernatorial elections will be held a year later. Differences over the timing of the elections, and the opposition's demand for greater local autonomy in communities, were some of the key issues of the opposition's boycott. ``The agreement obviously is not the best, but it will ensure progress in our political system, for which we made concession,'' said Rep. Kim Hyung-bae, floor leader of the Party for Peace and Democracy, the largest opposition party. ``This cleared all issues standing in the way of political normalization,'' said Rep. Kim Yoon-hwan, of the governing Democratic Liberal Party. All 78 opposition legislators in the 299-member assembly, including 70 from Peace and Democracy and eight from the Democratic Party, resigned in July. They accused the governing party of railroading controversial bills and backsliding on political reforms. The opposition set forth several preconditions to ending their boycott. They included early local elections and cancellation of plans to change South Korea's system of government from presidential to parliamentary. Korean President Roh Tae-woo and other leaders had been seeking a parliamentary system similar to Japan's government, wherein parliament would elect a prime minister to serve as a head of state. The opposition's demand was met this month when a faction within Roh's party rejected the change of government proposal. Roh then backed down and promised not to seek a constitutional revision.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Bill Aimed at Halting Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sent Congress a police reform bill that could curtail torture and threats against prisoners in custody. The proposed legislation was delivered by the president over the weekend. It should pass easily, since the Congress is dominated by the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. According to the government news agency Notimex, the reform would limit police search rights, oblige police to obtain court warrants and stipulate that confessions be made openly before a judge or district attorney. Confessions to police or other law enforcement officers will not be valid under the proposed reform. The purpose of this provision is to stop the widespread practice of eliciting confessions through threats and torture. Human rights groups have long complained that suspects are mistreated by police, especially in drug- or political-related cases. The legislation applies to federal law, but each of the 31 states and the Federal District are expected to eventually include it in their codes of procedures. The reform follows a shake-up in the Attorney General's Office. Javier Coello Trejo, the powerful assistant attorney general in charge of drug enforcement, was transferred in October to head a consumer protection agency. His old job was downgraded and filled by an army colonel.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Food Agency Announces Record Harvest in 1990
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in years, the 1990-91 global cereal harvest will be sufficient to meet world consumption needs, a U.N. agency announced Saturday. However, food shortages are worsening in Ethiopia, Sudan, and Angola, where rains have been scarce or late, said the report from the Rome-based U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization. The lack of food remains a serious problem in war-damaged Mozambique and Liberia, said the report. It also said cereal production and per capita consumption would continue to decline in South America. In its periodical ``Food Outlook,'' the FAO said that world cereal output for 1990-91 would reach a record 1.95 billion tons in the harvest, about 75 million more than the previous year. FAO also forecasted an increase in the world carryover of cereal stocks at the end of the 1990-91 crop year to 18 percent of expected use for the next year. FAO considers a 17 to 18 percent carryover the minimum necessary to protect world food security. Stocks of both wheat and rice are expected to increase, the report said. The crop of pulses - peas, lentils and the like - is estimated to reach a record 60 million tons, a 2 million ton increase compared with last year, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges To Stand with Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told a crowd that filled historic Wenceslas Square on Saturday that ``America will stand with you'' through hard times ahead and he urged European solidarity in the Persian Gulf crisis. Visiting Prague on the anniversary of the revolution that ended decades of communist rule in Czechoslovakia, Bush also said new European security arrangements might be needed to make sure the former Soviet allies do not wind up in ``some kind of no man's land.'' In his speech, Bush likened last year's struggle of emerging democracies against totalitarianism to the current U.S.-led effort to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. ``The darkness in the desert sky cannot stand against the way of light,'' Bush said, addressing about 100,000 people who packed the half-mile long, 200-foot wide ``square'' that is the scene of much recent Czechoslovak history. The first U.S. president ever to visit this central European nation, Bush shared the platform with playwright-president Vaclav Havel. Those in the crowd waved small U.S. and Czechoslovak flags and many chanted ``Bush, Havel. Bush, Havel.'' After their speeches, the two presidents stepped out from their bulletproof enclosure and climbed a wooden platform and joined a folk band that sang ``We Shall Overcome,'' first in English and then in Czech. Many in the crowd joined along, filling the cold and overcast late afternoon sky with the traditional song that was both a protest anthem for the U.S. and civil rights movements of the 1960s and for Czechoslovak students in street protests here against communist rule. A year ago, the square was similarly filled with hundreds of thousands of citizens to begin the so-called ``Velvet Revolution'' that drove communists from power with little bloodshed. ``The world will never forget what happened here in this square where the history of freedom was written,'' Bush said. He praised Czechoslovakia as ``one of the first nations to condemn the outrage in the Persian Gulf.'' Havel reiterated this view and promised Bush continued support during a joint news conference outside the Hradcany Castle, the Czechoslovak equivalent of the White House. Havel shrugged off a question on whether he was concerned that the Persian Gulf crisis was draining away money that could have been used to help support his country's ailing economy. ``It is my opinion that all the resources that are expended on resisting aggression anywhere in the world are finally turned to the good of all mankind,'' he said. Bush was expected to try to further coordinate allied support in Germany on Sunday, where he visits Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and in Paris where he attends a three-day European summit. At the news conference, Bush was asked if he and Havel discussed future security arrangements for Europe in the aftermath of the cold war and the crumbling of the Warsaw Pact. ``We do not want to see Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary off in some kind of no man's land,'' Bush said. ``Thus, we did discuss future security arrangements.'' While he did not elaborate, Bush said he wanted to see a more active role played by the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the group sponsoring the Paris meeting. Future alignments in Europe are expected to be high on the agenda of that session. Bush said the United States has ``an enormous stake'' in the security of Eastern Europe. Both in his Wenceslas Square speech and in an earlier address to the Federal Assembly, the nation's parliament, Bush offered hope of new U.S. economic assistance to the fledgling democracy. ``We know this is a difficult time for you, but also a time of extraordinary optimism,'' he told the crowd in the square, winning loud applause. ``America will not fail you in this decisive moment. America will stand with you,'' Earlier, he said final agreement was reached Saturday granting Czechoslovakia most-favored-nation trade status, permitting it to deal with the United States at the lowest possible tariffs and import fee rates. Bush said he also would ask Congress for $60 million to create a fund to spur U.S. investment here. Moreover, Bush said funds to help build the private sector would be drawn from the $370 million already committed for Central and Eastern Europe for the coming year. The two leaders were wrapped in heavy topcoats against the biting wind in Wenceslas Square. Earlier, Bush and his wife Barbara emerged from Air Force One to a full-fledged state welcome, including a 21-gun salute as flags of both nations snapped in the wind. Bush was to spend Thanksgiving with U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf region and then end his eight-day trip next Friday with a visit to Egypt for talks on the showdown with Iraq. Administration officials accompanying Bush said the United States soon would ask Moscow, Iraq's former chief arms supplier, whether it had supplied medium-range SS-12 missiles to Baghdad in the past. Such weapons could be capable of carrying chemical warheads. Moscow, under a treaty with the United States, was required to destroy these missiles. ``We are going to the Soviets'' on the matter because of recent reports on the possibility, said an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bush meets separately on Tuesday in Paris with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. In his Wenceslas Square speech, Bush presented Havel with a replica of the Liberty Bell that hangs in Philadelphia to ``help you proclaim your new liberty throughout the world.'' He also promised to take steps to return to the country a 70-year-old draft of a proposed Czechoslovakia Declaration of Independence that is in the Library of Congress in Washington. The draft was presented to President Woodrow Wilson by Tomas Masaryk, Czechoslovakia's first president.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gives In: Dumps Prime Minister, Transfers More Power to Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13 grafs for 3-12 bgng `Although representatives...' to UPDATE with new reform party formed; MINOR EDITING, picks up 13th graf pvs, `Legislators generally...' ^LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday proposed dumping his embattled prime minister and giving himself more power to break a political deadlock and swiftly introduce an emergency food program. Losing popularity and power in his centrist position following a lackluster speech to the Supreme Soviet legislature Friday, Gorbachev came out fighting Saturday. In a 12-minute address packed with new proposals, he urged lawmakers to approve a radical reorganization of the executive branch that would put it entirely under his control. Although representatives of several restive republics vowed not to cooperate with the new government, the legislature voted overwhelmingly to give the program preliminary approval. They voted 316-19, with 31 abstentions, to send the proposals to committees to consider amendments and discuss a final draft Friday. Gorbachev's suggestions appeared to be a concession to his main rival and critic, Russian President Boris Yeltsin, who on Friday had demanded a coalition government and the resignation of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Under Gorbachev's proposals Saturday, the Council of Ministers headed by Ryzhkov would be replaced by several bodies under direct presidential control. The principal governing body would be the Federation Council, created in March as a presidential advisory body but which would now be made the highest body of state power and include representatives of the Soviet republics. The proposals represent Gorbachev's attempt to resolve the paralysis of power between the 15 republics and the central government that has blocked economic and political reforms for months. He also proposed an ``inter-republican committee'' under the Federation Council, a National Security Council and a presidential body to coordinate the activities of law enforcement agencies. On the food crisis, Gorbachev promised emergency measures in two weeks for supplying this year's produce to the population. Ryzhkov said this program involves increasing food imports, a Yeltsin suggestion. Apparently overwhelmed by his two jobs of president and Communist Party leader, Gorbachev also suggested naming a vice president. It was the third time this year Gorbachev asked Soviet lawmakers to give him more power. In March, he received the powers of an executive president, including the authority to impose direct presidential rule in restive areas. In September, he was empowered to issue decrees to make economic reforms and restore law and order. A group of 235 former Communist Party members met Saturday to form the Republican Party of Russia, which they said would be a left-center coalition supporting cooperation between Gorbachev and Yeltsin. The nucleus of the party is members of Democratic Platform, a popular faction of reform-minded former Communists who have included Yeltsin and the reform mayors of Moscow and Leningrad, Gavriil Popov and Anatoly Sobchak. Party leaders said the group had about 1,000 supporters in Moscow and small pockets in other Russian cities. It is strongest among the intelligentsia. Reacting to Gorbachev's latest proposals, some legislators said Gorbachev was trying to grab too much authority. ``It is concentrating all power in the economy, in politics, in military affairs in one (person's) hands,'' Marju Lauristin, deputy speaker of Estonia's parliament, told reporters. Legislators generally welcomed the proposed elimination of Ryzhkov's job, but unless all the republics agree to join the Federation Council, the paralysis of power is likely to continue. Many republics have nullified national legislation and presidential decrees and declared their laws supreme. The new structure was designed to end such conflicts. Ms. Lauristin said Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania wanted no part of the new structure, and Georgian, Ukrainian and Armenian representatives said they are not ready to sign a treaty binding their republics in a union. The Baltic states have said their incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 was illegal and invalid and have launched independence drives. All but one of the other republics, Kirghizia, have declared sovereignty to break from the Kremlin. The chairman of Russia's economic council, Mikhail Bocharov, called the proposals ``unrealistic'' because they do not give the republics full independence. While acknowledging the powers of the republics and the central government must be redefined, Gorbachev reiterated in his speech his opposition to attempts to break up the union. ``It is easier for me to say this now: our own bitter experience tinged with the blood of our citizens has, I think, taught us that we cannot separate,'' Gorbachev said, prompting applause. After months of defending Ryzhkov and claiming critics were making him a scapegoat, Gorbachev let Ryzhkov go subtly. He did not mention Ryzhkov's name or specifically call for abolition of the Council of Ministers in his speech. He referred only to creation of a new ``Cabinet of Ministers.'' Deputies said it was unclear whether the Cabinet of Ministers or the Federation Council would serve as a Western-style presidential Cabinet. Instead of abolishing the Council of Ministers and antagonizing bureaucrats, Gorbachev displayed his political skill by proposing their power be taken away. In March, he did the same thing to the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, giving many of its powers to an advisory body, the Presidential Council. On Saturday, Gorbachev proposed abolishing the 18-member Presidential Council and giving its functions to the strengthened Federation Council. ``Anything affecting the entire country, whether decided by the center or republics, must be discussed and given the go-ahead by the Federation Council,'' he proposed. Ryzhkov, a confidant of Gorbachev for a decade, said he believed he would be out of a job. ``I understood that the position of chairman of the Council of Ministers won't exist. There will be presidential rule, a presidential Cabinet,'' the weary 61-year-old prime minister told reporters. Yeltsin has seen Ryzhkov and his associates as the embodiment of the old rule-by-command central bureaucracy. Reformers say the central bureaucracy is inefficient and corrupt, and should be replaced with democratic, free market institutions. The Federation Council could be Gorbachev's answer to Yeltsin's proposal Friday of an ``extraordinary anti-crisis committee,'' with representatives of all republics and concentrating on providing food to the people. Yeltsin did not attend Saturday's session and his press secretary said he would not comment immediately on Gorbachev's proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Rescued Pilots Remember French Underground Heroine
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose exploits in the French underground saved 32 American fliers from the Nazis during World War II was eulogized Saturday by two of the airmen whom she tracked down more than 40 years later. Charline Chable Rotondo died Thursday at Concord Hospital of lung cancer at age 78. She was the first foreign-born woman to receive the Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honor. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower presented her the medal in Paris in 1945 after her escape from the Germans. ``She was very good to us,'' said Alvin Little of Burlington, Vt., who was an injured pilot Mrs. Rotondo hustled out one door as the Germans came in another. ``She did everything in her power to get us through.'' Little, the last man the French-born woman smuggled through her house, recalled how she burst in to tell him the Germans were coming. ``She came in one evening and said, `We've got to go. We've got to get out of here,''' Little said in a telephone interview. ``They were right there, ready to come in.'' While Mrs. Rotondo stalled the Germans, Little and her niece got out another door, he said. She escaped, too. Mrs. Rotondo was captured later, but she refused to reveal information about the French Resistance even though the Germans beat and otherwise tortured her. She escaped when the Allies bombed a train carrying her to a concentration camp. Little, 71, stayed at Mrs. Rotondo's home in Esbly, some 20 miles east of Paris, for three months nursing a broken leg. He said he and the other pilots owed their lives to her and the underground. ``But she went through a lifetime of hell doing it,'' he said. Mrs. Rotondo's husband, Alfred, said that after she moved to the United States in 1974, she tried to find the men she had helped save. ``She was forever looking for these guys,'' Rotondo said Saturday. ``For 10 years I listened to her say `If I could only find one.''' Finally, word of her search reached the Air Force Escape and Evasion Society, a group of escaped prisoners and fliers who had evaded capture. Through those groups, in 1984 she found former flier John Swensen, who lived about 40 minutes from her in Newton, Mass. Rotondo said that when his wife and Swensen met, ``she was as happy as could be. Tears were running down their faces.'' They later got together frequently. ``She remembered me as the man with the big feet,'' Swensen said Saturday. He wore about a size 13 boot. Swensen stayed in Mrs. Rotondo's home about a week before moving on. After the war, Mrs. Rotondo became a fashion designer. She lived in Cambodia, Vietnam, Hong Kong and Taiwan, before moving to the United States. Most recently she lived in Salem, N.H., designing clothes, driving a bus for the handicapped and working for a home care nursing company in northern Massachusetts. Funeral services will take place Monday in Salem. Along with her husband, she is survived by a stepson and two stepdaugthers.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Spokesman Confirms Company Plans Transfers, Firings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with company spokesman confirmation, quotes and details on transfers and firings of workers. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Last month ...'
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. said Saturday it has begun notifying some store office workers they'll either be transferred or fired after New Year's Day. The affected employees are an undetermined number among the estimated 20,000 people who work in areas including customer service, accounting and payroll in the 850 Sears stores across the nation, spokesman Gerald Buldak said. ``It's really too soon to tell'' how many employees will be affected, but most work part-time, Buldak said. He said some staff functions will be merged at a hub office in some stores. ``Employees displaced would have an opportunity to work elsewhere in a store, if a job existed, or would not have a job,'' he said. Last fall, the company began seeking ways to improve customer service and cut costs, Buldak said. Using employee ideas, Sears tested pared-down procedures at 10 stores, he said. Te company began notifying workers late last week that they could be either transferred or lose their jobs through a nationwide cost-cutting effort, Buldak said. Last month, Sears reported sharply lower net income for the third straight quarter, with overall earnings down 30 percent, but said its retail unit had improved. The retail group, called the Sears Merchandise Group, accounts for more than half of all company revenues. It posted a 7.6 percent gain in third-quarter operating income after suffering a 32 percent decline in the second quarter and a $37.4 million loss in the first. The merchandise groups includes 337,000 employees, which includes both store and catalogue sales.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Premier Appeals for Reconciliation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chandra Shekhar cq on 2nd reference
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, in his first national address since taking office, appealed Saturday for an end to the religious and sectarian battles that brought down his successor. ``The age of confrontation should be changed in the age of understanding, compassion and cordiality,'' Chandra Shekhar said in a broadcast on state-run television and radio. Chandra Shekhar, who replaced V.P. Singh on Nov. 10, promised to ``bring this country out of a muddy mire of misery and misfortune.'' It was a virtual duplication of a speech he gave Friday in Parliament, when his government won a vote of confidence. Hours before his broadcast, Sikh militants killed 10 Hindus in the northern state of Punjab. Press Trust of India said 30 other people were killed in Punjab Friday. Sikh militants have been fighting since 1982 to set up an independent nation in Punjab. About 2,800 people have been killed in the northern state this year. Thousands more have been killed in separatist insurrections in Kashmir, in the far north, and Assam in the east. A new Hindu-Moslem conflict, which led to the collapse of Singh's government, has left at least 500 people dead across the country in the last two months. These problems have to be ``tackled with a sense of reconciliation,'' Chandra Shekhar said. ``I humbly appeal to the young men to give up violence and come to the mainstream.'' The Hindu-Moslem clashes came about as a result of a Hindu fundamentalist group's plan to replace a Moslem mosque with a temple in the city of Ayodhya. Singh opposed the plan, thereby losing the support of a key right-wing Hindu party. ``Hindu religion has always pleaded for human approach to all problems. Any killing in the name of religion is criminal,'' Chandra Shekhar said. He said the violence was sapping the government's efforts to fight poverty. India is one of the poorest nations in the world, with an annual per capita income of $330. Annual inflation is officially running at a projected rate of 10 percent. Some recent surveys showed that in rural areas, the daily cost of food has shot up by 25 percent since July. Chandra Shekhar is the leader of the Janata Dal-Socialist party, which controls only 56 of the 522 seats in Parliament. With the backing of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, which has 210 seats, the new government was confirmed by a 280-214 vote Friday. Fifteen legislators abstained and the rest were absent.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Disperse Anarchists in Athens Near U.S. Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Police Saturday shot tear gas at more than 200 youths who hurled firebombs and rocks at the Hilton Hotel near the U.S. Embassy. Two policemen was slightly injured during running battles with the self-styled anarchists who rampaged through downtown Athens. Damage to buildings was slight, police said. The violence came at the end of an annual march to commemorate a student uprising against the 1967-74 military dictatorship. The club-wielding youths firebombed a police bus, a bank, and offices of the governing New Democracy party, police said. They also hurled rocks at the War Museum, a Finance Ministry building, a cinema and shops. The youths, who earlier appeared to be headed for the U.S. Embassy where the march ended, dispersed after the Hilton incident, police said. Many of the attacks occurred near the Athens Polytechnic, or National Technical University, where the annual march began. The Polytechnic was the site of the Nov. 17, 1973, uprising that paved the way for the collapse of the military regime. More than 20 young people were killed as troops and tanks were deployed to oust protestors occupying the building. The marchers file past the U.S. Embassy each year to protest alleged backing by Washington for the ruling colonels of that time. In Saturday's demonstration, protesters chanted anti-government slogans. Police estimated turnout at about 8,000 protesters, thousands lower than in previous years. Clashes between self-styled anarchists and supporters of the governing conservative party's youth movement broke out in the Polytechnic's compound on Friday. Ten injuries were reported. Premier Constantine Mitsotakis, whose party came to power April 8, has been the target of left-wing criticism for his decision to dispatch a frigate to the Persian Gulf region to help enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. Mitsotakis has also drawn left-wing fire for economic belt-tightening measures and a new electoral law that makes it harder for smaller political parties to win representation in parliament.
