Sikh militants have been fighting since 1982 to set up an independent nation in Punjab. About 2,800 people have been killed in the northern state this year. Thousands more have been killed in separatist insurrections in Kashmir, in the far north, and Assam in the east. A new Hindu-Moslem conflict, which led to the collapse of Singh's government, has left at least 500 people dead across the country in the last two months. These problems have to be ``tackled with a sense of reconciliation,'' Chandra Shekhar said. ``I humbly appeal to the young men to give up violence and come to the mainstream.'' The Hindu-Moslem clashes came about as a result of a Hindu fundamentalist group's plan to replace a Moslem mosque with a temple in the city of Ayodhya. Singh opposed the plan, thereby losing the support of a key right-wing Hindu party. ``Hindu religion has always pleaded for human approach to all problems. Any killing in the name of religion is criminal,'' Chandra Shekhar said. He said the violence was sapping the government's efforts to fight poverty. India is one of the poorest nations in the world, with an annual per capita income of $330. Annual inflation is officially running at a projected rate of 10 percent. Some recent surveys showed that in rural areas, the daily cost of food has shot up by 25 percent since July. Chandra Shekhar is the leader of the Janata Dal-Socialist party, which controls only 56 of the 522 seats in Parliament. With the backing of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, which has 210 seats, the new government was confirmed by a 280-214 vote Friday. Fifteen legislators abstained and the rest were absent.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb at Softball Game Kills Canadian Executive, Wounds Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with PLO spokesman denying claim of responsibility, RECASTS lead to reflect that third person had minor injuries; MINOR EDITING; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SCL1-3
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden inside a softball bat exploded Saturday during a U.S.-Chile game, killing a Canadian and injuring three people, including two American Embassy representatives, officials reported. A man claiming to speak for the Chilean branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed responsibility for the blast in a telephone call to a radio station. The caller warned President Bush not to visit Chile, as he plans to do during a South American tour Dec. 2-8. However, a spokesman for the PLO's office in Santiago denied the group was responsible for the bombing. ``We completely, emphatically deny that the PLO acted in the attack,'' he said, refusing to give his name. The attack, the second on Americans in Chile in two weeks, occurred during a game at the National Stadium between teams from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and a Chilean university. Police said the softball bat was stuffed with nearly a pound of dynamite and exploded in the dugout of the chamber team. The blast killed James Thomas, 36, an executive with a Canadian firm exporting seafood from Chile, they said. The game's umpire, Vicente Alcayaga, said at least two other people were wounded, including Thomas Collins, ``a security officer in the American embassy.'' Barbara Nielsen, a U.S. Embassy spokesman, wouldnot confirm Collins' job. She said: ``he is relatively new here, and I don't know his hometown in the United States or other details at this point.'' She said Collins, 28, was ``in serious condition.'' Later, a spokesman for the National Police Hospital, where Collins was taken, confirmed he was in serious condition, but said his life was not in danger. Collins sustained multiple face and body injuries, he said. A second wounded man was identified only as J. Gain, apparently a Canadian. The hospital spokesman, Dr. Jaime Baltra, said a second U.S. Embassy official, Jeff Tickeney, suffered minor scratches on both legs and was treated and released. His position with the embassy also was not immediately available. Police said that the game was nearing its end shortly after noon when the bomb went off. They said another game had been scheduled to start afterward, also involving Americans and Canadians. About two hours after the blast, a man speaking with a foreign accent called Radio Monumental in Santiago saying the PLO was responsible for the attack. The man read a communique saying the bomb was planted ``to mark the second anniversary of the Palestinian state in exile due to the Zionist occupation with the help of the American imperialism.'' ``We want you to know that the PLO has international force,'' the man said. ``We will fight against Zionist and American targets so that our next anniversary be celebrated in our Palestinian land.'' ``This is just an ancitipation of what will happen if American dictator George Bush sets foot on Chile, a motherland we love and respect,'' the statement said. Police did not immediately comment on the claim. Nov. 15th marked the second anniversary of the Palestine declaration of an independent homeland in Israeli-occupied territory. Sergio Brotfeld, deputy director of the government's sports agency, said the Canadian executive had been in Chile for only two weeks. The chamber's team was made up mostly of Americans and Canadians. There were also several foreigners among the small crowd watching the game. On Nov. 4, a bomb exploded in a restaurant in the seaside resort of Vina del Mar, injuring eight people, including three sailors from the U.S. aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln. No group claimed responsibility in that bombing. Since President Patricio Aylwin took office in March, ending 17 years of military rule, there have been several bombing attacks, mostly attributed to the far-left Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front. The National Stadium was used as a detention center for thousands of suspected supporters of former President Salvador Allende after he was deposed in a military coup in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Would Testify if Granted Immunity
With AM-Keating Five
DOC.TEXT: Indicted savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. wants to testify before a committee investigating five senators but only if granted immunity from prosecution, one of his attorneys says. ``My client's testimony might help some senators, it might hurt others,'' attorney Stephen C. Neal of Chicago said in a letter to Senate Ethics Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett. Neal, however, said Keating could not testify if his words might be used against him at a future trial. ``Because of pending criminal investigations Mr. Keating's story cannot be heard at all,'' the letter said. ``The committee can and should immunize Mr. Keating and free him to testify.'' The Nov. 12 letter was made available to news media Saturday, two days after the start of hearings at which four of the senators denied wrongdoing in the case. Under investigation by the committee are Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Donald Riegle, D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. Cranston, Riegle, Glenn and McCain read opening statements to the committee on Friday and DeConcini is expected to deliver his opening statement on Monday. The five senators are accused of interceding with federal regulators on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings & Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., while also accepting at total of $1.3 million in political donations from Keating and his associates. Lincoln's collapse in April 1989 is expected to cost taxpayers up to $2 billion, according to federal regulators. Keating is under indictment in California for securities fraud involving the sale of bonds by American Continental Corp., the holding company that controlled Lincoln Savings. He also is threatened with federal indictment involving Lincoln and the campaign contributions, according to Neal. The attorney said that ``immunizing Mr. Keating to testify might impact some threatened collateral legal proceedings.'' ``But the committee should weigh and balance the public interest in a full, complete, open and fair proceeding against the value of any threatened criminal prosecution of my client for his part with the five senators,'' Neal said in his letter to Bennett. ``The American public has a right to know the full story of these senators and their dealings with my client.'' A source close to Keating, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saturday there has been no reply to the letter.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Smuggler Ordered Killing of Man Who Found Drug Booty
DOC.TEXT: An alleged drug smuggler put out a $100,000 contract on a villager who dug up part of $43 million in cash that traffickers buried in barrels on a farm, according to prosecutors. The evidence of the contract was heard on a wiretap recording played by prosecutors at a bail hearing for Wilfredo Gutierrez Vargas, one of 21 people arrested in Puerto Rico and New York on drug charges. The alleged leader of the ring, Ramon Torres Gonzalez, owned a farm 35 miles west of San Juan on which $43 million in alleged drug profits had been buried in 22 plastic barrels. Local residents found the cache last spring and spent about $11 million before Torres learned what was happening and hid the rest. Neither Torres nor the remainder of the cash has been found. In the Sept. 4 recording, played Friday before U.S. Magistrate Jesus Castellanos, the voice alleged to be that of Gutierrez tells a government informant that he has hired a ``lowlife'' gunman to kill Rene Feliciano Pagan, one of the people who supposedly dug up the money. Pagan was later kidnapped. but police rescued him. It wasn't known if anyone was charged in the kidnapping. Gutierrez, who owns an auto alarm business, and 29 other people are charged in a 27-count indictment with engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise and conspiracy to import and distribute controlled substances. Torres and eight other alleged members of the gang are still at large. According to the indictment, the smugglers brought 4.5 tons of cocaine into Puerto Rico and the United States since 1985. The villagers found the cash in $10, $20 and $100 bills and kept their windfall secret for weeks. They put some of the money into bank accounts and bought everything from VCRs to expensive cars before authorities stepped in. The FBI says it confiscated $4.5 million in cash and property bought with the stolen money. None of the residents were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Demand Lukanov Resign, Protest Turkish Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `President Zhelyu...' to FIX typo; SUBS last 3 grafs bgng, `The state ...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with thousands of Bulgarians protesting at Greek border. No Pickup
DOC.TEXT: Protesters rallied in Sofia and other major cities Saturday, some demanding the resignation of Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov and others opposing restoration of rights to ethnic Turks. Also, hundreds of women staged a ``hunger march'' late Friday through the capital, banging empty pots with spoons to protest bare stores and rations of basic goods, including some foods, electricity and gasoline. Lukanov, whose Socialist government is under growing pressure because of the Balkan country's economic crisis, has been pushing for support in parliament for economic reforms. The reforms would slash state spending but would bring more hardship for Bulgaria's already desperate consumers. President Zhelyu Zhelev, in a nationally televised address Saturday, warned that rising political tensions could lead to violence, and appealed to groups and individuals to ``assume social and personal responsibility'' for their actions. ``No act of force, no violation of the law, no provocation should occur that would compromise us in the eyes of Europe and the world,'' said Zhelev, who has been trying to rally Western aid and support for Bulgaria's ailing economy. Zhelev, a former opposition leader, said he had asked leaders of all political parties to meet and try to resolve differences on Wednesday, when he and Lukanov return from a 34-nation summit in Paris. On Saturday, several thousand people gathered in front of the Alexander Nevsky cathedral in central Sofia, cheering as speakers urged support for ``all actions that will lead to the fall of the government.'' The rally was organized by university teachers, intellectuals and parents who support a student strike at most high schools and universities nationwide. State radio reported the main opposition coalition, the Union of Democratic Forces, organized anti-government rallies in several other towns and cities. Lukanov's Socialists, formerly the Communists, won 211 parliamentary seats in June elections, compared to 144 for the Union, and formed a single-party government after the opposition rejected a coalition. But Lukanov's popularity has slumped with the economy's poor performance. National leaders agreed Friday to postpone a vote on Lukanov's program in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly until Thursday. Deputies on Thursday approved overwhelmingly an amendment to restore rights to Bulgaria's 1.5 million ethnic Turks and Moslems. That sparked protests among Bulgarians in Turkish-dominated regions. Under the amendment, Turks need no longer use Bulgarian names imposed under the rule of former Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. Thousands of Bulgarian Christians drove Saturday to a Greek border post and requested permanent residence to protest the restoration of rights to ethnic Turks in their town, 80 percent of whose population is of Turkish origin. The busloads of Bulgarians - estimated at from 2,000 to 5,000 by police and customs officials - were barred from leaving by Bulgarian border authorities, a Greek customs officer at the Ormenion crossing said. The protesters later returned to their home in the city of Kardzhali, 250 miles east of Sofia. The state news agency BTA earlier had reported a rally by Christians in the town. In Friday night's rally, more than 200 women marched to Lukanov's apartment block. They waved banners reading ``We're hungry in the dark,'' and ``Food for our children.'' They demanded that Lukanov resign. Police surrounded the building, and no clashes or arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Find Plane Believed Missing for Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Divers have found a sunken airplane and a body believed to be that of a man prosecutors suspected of faking his death to avoid a theft indictment and collect $4 million in insurance money, authorities said. The state attorney general's office has been looking for Blan Stewart, a 47-year-old insurance executive, since Halloween night 1988, when his rented single-engine plane disappeared near Lake Martin in east-central Alabama as he flew from Vero Beach, Fla., to his hometown of Huntsville in northern Alabama. Divers combing Lake Martin found a Piper Archer aircraft at the bottom of the 65-foot-deep lake Friday morning, and a body was floating in the cockpit, said Tallapoosa County Sheriff Joe Smith. Smith said the body was well-preserved, apparently because of cold temperatures at the lake bottom. FBI Special Agent Gerald Shockley said the plane's registration number matched that of the plane Stewart was flying when he was last seen. Forensic experts were waiting to examine Stewart's dental records in Montgomery, where the body was being examined Saturday. Attorneys for Stewart's wife, Robin, said clothes found on the body matched those Stewart was wearing. Federal and state prosecutors have speculated that Stewart faked a plane crash and his death to escape charges of insurance theft involving $590,000 he collected but allegedly failed to pass on to insurance companies writing the policies. In addition, he faces first-degree theft charges in Lauderdale County, where he is accused of passing a worthless check for nearly $12,000 to a furniture plant. Insurance companies have posted a $100,000 reward for information on whether he is alive or dead. In September, the FBI obtained warrants charging him with unlawful flight after two people reported seeing him in the Virgin Islands in late November or early December 1989. The FBI said telephone records subpoenaed by the state attorney general's office showed a collect call from the Virgin Islands to Mrs. Stewart's home in Huntsville in March. The call came six weeks before she went to court to have her husband declared dead so she could collect on $4 million in life insurance. A judge ruled, however, there was insufficient evidence to declare Stewart dead. He said Stewart's heirs must wait seven years before he could be declared legally dead for insurance purposes. Officials at the state Department of Forensic Sciences in Montgomery declined to comment until the dental records had been examined. An attorney for Mrs. Stewart, John Heacock, said several people who knew Stewart arrived at the lake in time to see authorities remove the body from the muck-covered aircraft. ``They had no doubt it was him,'' Heacock said. The airplane was spotted by divers hired by Mrs. Stewart who had been scouring the lake bottom since Monday. The plane was discovered in the same area where searchers had focused their efforts since Stewart's aircraft vanished, said Tom Radney, another attorney representing Mrs. Stewart. ``This is in the area where our live witnesses said they heard the plane go down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Weather Prevails Except in Alaska, Atlantic Coast and Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Dry weather prevailed across most of the nation Saturday, but a blizzard brought snow and strong winds to northern Alaska and showers dampaned the Atlantic coast and the Northwest. A cold front scattered rain from Maine through New York state to the mid-Atlantic coast Thursday afternoon while another cold front brought rain to Washington state, northern Idaho and western Oregon. Winds of up to 50 mph were reported along Alaska's northwest coast, sharply reducing visibility and producing wind chill readings of 50 to 65 degrees below zero. Strong gusty south winds blew across the northern and central Plains regions and wind advisories were in effect for western and central Kansas. Temperatures were in the 40s and 50s across much of the nation east of the Rocky Mountains Saturday afternoon while clouds, rain and blustery northwest winds kept temperatures in the 30s in the northern Atlantic coastal region. In the northern and central high Plains, westerly winds pushed temperatures into the 60s and 70s. Highs were in the 70s and lower 80s from southern Texas to Florida. Temperatures in the West were mostly in the 40s and 50s at midday, but warmed into the 80s in the southwestern deserts. Yuma, Ariz., reported a high of 88 degrees at 4 p.m. EST. Early morning lows Saturday ranged from the the 50s and lower 60s in the southwestern deserts to the upper teens and 20s in the northern plateau and the northern Rocky Mountain region. Temperatures dipped below freezing in the early morning hours across much of the northern and central plains region, the upper half of the Mississippi Valley and across the upper Great Lakes region. The nation's low Saturday morning was 15 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki, Trailing Well Behind Walesa, Toughens Rhetoric
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki is trailing far behind Solidarity leader Lech Walesa in polls for this month's presidential election, and he is in danger of being passed by a third candidate, a new poll shows. Mazowiecki, who had insisted on a gentlemanly campaign, has begun sharper attacks on Walesa, saying his former ally in the anti-Communist movement is promising more than he can possibly deliver. The election is set for Nov. 25. If no one wins more than half the vote, the top two vote-getters will face each other in a runoff Dec. 9. The state television polling service reported Friday that Walesa had the support of 35 percent of the voters, to 19 percent for Mazowiecki and 17 percent for Stanislaw Tyminski, a Polish-Canadian businessman. Tyminski's fresh face and proven economic acumen are wooing voters, the pollsters reported. An additional 15 percent of the voters are undecided and the rest backed three other candidates. Although they fought side-by-side for a decade before the June 1989 elections that brought Solidarity to power, Walesa has lambasted Mazowiecki as being ``a turtle'' so cautious that ``he couldn't catch a flea.'' He said he had appointed Mazowiecki to be a ``transitional'' prime minister. Mazowiecki, who pledges to resign as prime minister the day Walesa is sworn in as president, fought back Friday before a crowd of about 2,000 students at Gdansk Polytechnic University in Walesa's hometown. Mazowiecki said he was running for president to protect his government's cautious but determined reform program. The difference between himself and Walesa, Mazowiecki said, was that ``I will not promise that it will be done easily and overnight.'' ``Mr. Walesa ... makes promises that it will not be possible to realize,'' he said. The labor leader has offered to divide up Poland's state-owned enterprise and give each Pole hundreds of dollars. Mazowiecki also suggested that Walesa might undermine democracy by not observing a ``constitutional balance of powers.' ``In a modern democracy, one person cannot stand higher than all the people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Identifies Remains as Haitian Slave Pierre Toussaint
DOC.TEXT:
Scientists have positively identified a skeleton exhumed from a New York cemetery as the remains of a Haitian slave who is a candidate to become America's first black saint, Cardinal John O'Connor said Saturday. A team of archaeologists, forensic scientists and anthropologists determined that a skeleton dug up earlier this month was that of Pierre Toussaint, the cardinal said. ``The definitive identification was made of the bones, all of them in order, not a single one missing,'' O'Connor said at an archdiocesan conference on racial and ethnic issues. ``This indeed is the skeleton of Pierre Toussaint.'' Toussaint was born in 1766 and brought to New York at age 21 by his French owners. Still enslaved, he became a leading hairdresser in the city and was allowed to keep some of his income.
When Toussaint's owner died, he left an impoverished widow and child. In a typical act of generosity, Toussaint secretly supported them for 20 years. The widow freed Toussaint from slavery just before she died in 1807. Once free, he bought the freedom of slaves and lavished money on charities, including an orphanage and the city's first school for black children. He also entered quarantined sections of the city to help yellow fever victims. Toussaint was buried at Old St. Patrick's Church Cemetery in the city's Little Italy section after his death in 1853 at age 87.
He is considered the founder of Catholic Charities because he helped the needy for 66 years when no formal systems of assistance existed. For decades, historians have been studying the life of Toussaint, whose last name means ``all saints.''
The church began working to have Toussaint considered for sainthood last December, said church spokesman Joe Zwilling. ``We're interested in Pierre Toussaint's holiness and what drove him to do things,'' O'Connor said. The examination of his remains is a preliminary step during the period of investigation of his life. The examination occurs before he is considered for beatification, and is only an early step in a process that could take years. Toussaint's remains will stay at Old St. Patrick's Church until they are moved to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where they will be kept with the remains of bishops and other holy people, Zwilling said. ``It will be a wonderful thing for the city of New York if a canonization process ultimately takes place,'' O'Connor said. ``It will restore some pride in the city. It will be a great thing for the church. It will be a fine thing for the black community.'' Digging for the remains began Nov. 1, but the first three skeletons unearthed were determined not to be Toussaint's.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Celebrate Life of Stormie Jones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, ``Everything was ...' to ADD comment by clergyman; picks up 5th graf pvs, `She was ...' INSERTS one graf after 6th graf pvs, `At the ...' to ADD comment from mayor. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Herring also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was eulogized Saturday as a gallant, courageous youngster who strived to live a normal life. The 13-year-old girl who battled organ rejection, hepatitis and medical complications before her body suddenly rejected her transplanted heart last Sunday, was laid to rest in a cemetery in this suburb of Fort Worth. At a 45-minute funeral service, many of the estimated 400 mourners burst into laughter several times as Jerry Conley, a minister at West Freeway Church of Christ, celebrated her life. ``Everything was always upbeat with this very special child,'' Conley said. ``Stormie has conquered life more gallantly perhaps than any person you or I have ever known. Her illness was not her enemy. ``Stormie was a very simple young lady,'' he said. ``She didn't really want all the fanfare that went with all of this. She wantedto be just an average teen-age girl.'' She was later buried at a private ceremony attended only by her family and close friends. At the church service, White Settlement Mayor James Herring read a resolution the City Council approved earlier in the week, recognizing Stormie as an honored citizen. ``She lived her life for others,'' Herring said. ``She didn't desire the notoriety that came her way but she was willing to do her part as a result of that. When called upon to step forward and talk to folks, talk to the news cameras ... she was always there and ready and willing.'' Herring also read a poem one of Stormie's classmates wrote after her death. ``Most say you were just a little girl, but you were an angel to me,'' he read. ``You've been our little lady, your courage was so true. When things seemed to go bad, you always pulled through.'' Stormie died Nov. 10 at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh - where she underwent her historic operation on Feb. 14, 1984. She had been rushed to the hospital from her home with a sore throat and fever. Doctors at the hospital said Friday that Stormie died because her body had suddenly rejected the transplanted heart. The autopsy results surprised Stormie's doctors, who said an organ rejection so many years after a transplant was rare. ``No one expected to see any rejection in Stormie,'' said Dr. F. Jay Fricker, her cardiologist at Children's. ``After all, we had a track record of more than six years of never seeing any heart rejection. So why would we suddenly see it now?'' Fricker said it would take months for doctors to determine, if at all, what caused the heart rejection. Doctors declined to speculate whether FK-506, an experimental anti-rejection drug Stormie began receiving last November, a second liver transplant she underwent last February or treatment for recurring bouts of hepatitis caused the rejection. The blond, brown-eyed girl needed the heart-liver transplant because of hypocholesteremia, a rare genetic disorder that prevented her body from processing cholesterol. Her sister, Misty, suffers from a milder form of the disease. Stormie had few major medical problems the first five years after her Valentine's Day transplant. But she had to return to Pittsburgh in 1988 for surgery to remove a bile duct obstruction. She underwent a mild episode of liver rejection in November 1989 and began receiving the experimental FK-506 instead of the traditional anti-rejection drug cyclosporine. A bout with hepatitis in February slowly damaged her liver, requiring a second liver transplant. But clinical studies done after surgery showed no evidence of heart problems, Fricker said. Stormie began rejecting the second liver in May and was treated with an increased dosage of FK-506. A month later, she received medication for another bout of hepatitis. Recent flu-like symptoms were the only indication something was wrong.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Saudi Troops Prepare For Mock Invasion, Iraqi Warns Of `Surprise'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 10th `Baghdad has...' to CORRECT that maneuvers to come within 10 miles of Kuwaiti border, stedIraqi-Kuwaiti border; pickup graf 11 `No live....' ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with report on Iraqi abuses
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DOD1,2,BRE1
DOC.TEXT: Backed by more than 1,000 warplanes, U.S. and Saudi troops prepared Saturday for a mock invasion near the Kuwaiti border. A top Iraqi general warned the U.S.-led force that his army has a ``surprise'' up its sleeve. President Bush was in Czechoslovakia, beginning an eight-day trip that will take him to the Saudi desert for Thanksgiving with U.S. troops. His secretary of state, James A. Baker III, also was in Europe, seeking support for a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Bush, in Prague to commemorate the first anniversary of the country's peaceful revolution, referred to the Persian Gulf crisis in a speech to Czechoslovak lawmakers. ``You know from your own bitter experience that the world cannot turn a blind eye to aggression.'' he said. ``You know the futility and vain hope that aggressors can be appeased.'' One-third of Czechoslovakia's territory was ceded in 1938 to the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent Adolf Hitler from conquering other countries. In an essay written for the Nov. 26 issue of Newsweek, Bush renewed his effort to rally Americans behind his policies on the gulf crisis. He wrote that ``the world must not reward aggression'' and said the United States ``cannot allow any tyrant to practice economic blackmail'' with oil. Imminent Thunder, as the current six-day exercises in the gulf are named, is being supported by about 1,100 aircraft, the largest force of warplanes yet assembled for a Desert Shield exercise. The drill is meant to emphasize gaining control of the skies, which would be critical to smash Iraqi defenses. ``The first thing you want to do is establish air superiority,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Ron Morse, a U.S. Navy spokesman. Baghdad has called Imminent Thunder a ``provocative act'' because of its proximity to Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. News reports have said part of the maneuvers could come within 10 miles of the Kuwaiti border. No live ammunition will be fired, officials say. The actual landing from amphibious landing craft and helicopters was set for Sunday. It was to involve 1,000 troops from the 4th Marine Expeditionary Battalion. About 500 to 800 troops will hit the beach Sunday, according to pool reports based on briefings aboard the USS Nassau, the flagship for the amphibious landing. Commanders said a key objective is to practice an assault from ships 30 miles from shore. In Baghdad, meanwhile, an Iraqi general said that the U.S.-dominated multinational force would face ``uncalculated developments'' should it attack Iraq. Maj. Gen. Mundhir Abdul-Rahman, a missile expert and head of the Iraqi army's morale department, did not say what the ``surprise elements'' were. But he said they would thwart an offensive. His comments were published in Al-Qadissiya, the army's daily newspaper. It was difficult to determine whether the general was speaking in his capacity as a specialist in long-range weaponry or as chief military morale booster. In his article, Abdul-Rahman wrote: ``The surprise element by Iraq will make the American aggression face uncalculated developments and unexpected results in (Iraq's) reaction, which would make their execution of aggression ... impossible.'' Britain's daily Independent newspaper reported Saturday that Iraq is believed to have assembled three so-called ``superguns'' able to fire shells a distance of 465 miles. U.S. intelligence sources believe the guns, largely assembled from British-made components, might have been deliverd to Iraq before production of the weapons was discovered earlier this year. Abdul-Rahman said his country was prepared to defend itself despite plans to increase U.S. troop strength. U.S. officials announced earlier this month that another 200,000 U.S. troops would join the 230,000 Americans already deployed in the region. They face an estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. In recent comments, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has indicated he still hopes for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. And a Soviet envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, has said he believes Saddam is softening his stance. Still, Baker has been seeking support for a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq if peaceful means fail. He has argued that without such a resolution, the alliance against Iraq will not be presenting a united front. Baker met in Geneva on Saturday with the foreign ministers of Ethiopia, Zaire and Ivory Coast, all members of the 15-nation Security Council. Zaire's foreign minister, Kalimba Wakatana Mushobekwa, said his government would back the proposed resolution. U.N. diplomats say Baker is lobbying foreign ministers from Security Council nations to come to New York and personally vote on the proposed resolution - a rare step. A Baker aide has said the United States would likely put forth the resolution before the end of the month. The Security Council has passed several measures against Iraq, including strict trade sanctions. In Baghdad, the Iraqi health minister said that as a result of the U.N. embargo, a shortage of medicine, other medical supplies and baby formula has become ``deadly serious.'' Jordan's King Hussein, meanwhile, bitterly criticized Western countries Saturday for applying ``double standards'' in the Middle East by not dealing simultaneously with the Arab-Israeli conflict. He accused them of seeking to control Arab resources. In an apparent reference to the United States and Britain, Hussein accused unnamed world powers of ``blatant and shameless conduct'' in the Middle East and said: ``Their actual goals stem from the desire to control our destiny and the Arab nation's resources.'' Hussein's country has been hard hit by the U.N. sanctions against Iraq, its main trading partner. It says it has kept to the sanctions, despite popular support for Saddam in the country. In New York, a human rights group issued a report documenting the crackdown by Iraqi occupiers on the Kuwaiti population. Middle East Watch said Iraq had carried out scores of public executions, midnight searches and arbitrary arrests, according to the report released Saturday. ``In addition to crowded and unsanitary conditions, detainees reported being severely beaten with clubs, metal pipes and electric rods,'' the report reads. ``Mock executions ... were also reported. Some detainees were subjected to electric shocks that caused severe pain and bleeding from the mouth, nose and ear.'' Aziz Abu Hamad, who wrote the report, said in an interview Saturday that his team had been able to track down 250 executions. He said it is ``not a pretty picture and it's getting worse.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Drug Czar to Succeed Atwater as Republican Chairman
DOC.NOTE: EDS: To CORRECT spelling of Fahrenkopf, subs 3rd graf pvs: Such a ....
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has asked former drug czar William Bennett to take over Lee Atwater's job as chairman of the Republican Party in January and Bennett has accepted, GOP sources said Saturday. Bennett, a former secretary of education in Ronald Reagan's cabinet, formally resigned Nov. 8 as head of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. A GOP source said Atwater, who managed Bush's 1988 presidential campaign, will continue to play a major strategy role for the GOP, possibly with a title as the party's ``general chairman.'' Such a structure would not be unique, the source said, citing Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr.'s chairmanship of the Republican National Committee in the 1980s while then-Sen. Paul Laxalt, R-Nev., held the title as the party's general chairman. A formal announcement will not be made until Bush returns from his eight-day trip to Czechoslovakia, Germany, France, Egypt and the Persian Gulf, said the source, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Atwater, 39, has been undergoing intensive treatment for cancer since a tumor was discovered on the right side of his brain last March. His two-year term as GOP chairman expires in January. B.J. Cooper, a Republican Party spokesman, said that Bennett ``is on a short list of people being considered'' to succeed Atwater ``but there's been no formal announcement at this time.'' Cooper said Bush's choice for a new Republican chairman would have to be ratified by the party's national committee in January. Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown, meeting with his party's $100,000 donors in Atlanta, said he welcomes Bennett's appointment as his chief adversary with ``open arms.'' ``If Bennett accomplishes as much for the Republican Party as he achieved at the Education Department and in ridding us of drugs and violence, Americans will have to begin worrying about the future of the two-party system,'' Brown quipped. Atwater was more of a tactician than an ideologue. After GOP candidates lost to pro-choice Democrats in two high-profile governors races in 1989, he acted quickly to move the Republican party away from its hard-line opposition to abortion. But he also had what Democrats denounced as a ``pit bull style of politics,'' citing his use of ``Willie Horton'' ads against Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis in 1988. Horton is a convicted murderer who raped a woman in Maryland while on furlough from a Massachusetts prison while Dukakis was the state's governor. Bennett, 47, also has a reputation for confrontation and brashness. Two weeks ago when Bush accepted his resignation, Bennett called Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., a frequent critic of his drug policies, ``a gasbag.''

DOC.HEAD: Polls Favor Heseltine Over Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Thatcher saying she'll hang tough, new polls; trims. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: As British politicians calculate the pros and cons of life without Margaret Thatcher as prime minister, six polls published Sunday gave a new boost to the man who is trying to unseat her. But Mrs. Thatcher was reported Sunday as saying she will not quit, even if she wins the looming leadership battle in her Conservative Party by only a narrow margin. ``If we win according to the rules, we win, and that's it,'' the Sunday Telegraph reported her as saying in an interview. Mrs. Thatcher said she would not be swayed by the desires of senior party officials. ``The rules were not made by me,'' she said. ``I abide by the rules. I expect others to abide by the rules.'' The newspaper polls showed voters believe Mrs. Thatcher's opponent for the party leadership, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, has a better chance of leading the Tories to victory at the next general election. But the Sunday Express reported in its own poll of 332 of the 372 Tory legislators, who will ultimately decide Mrs. Thatcher's fate, that 162 said they would vote for Mrs. Thatcher. Thirty-one said they would support Heseltine, while 27 said they did not know and 112 refused to answer. At the midpoint of a six-day party campaign that could bring the end of Mrs. Thatcher's 11{ years in power, a headline in Saturday's editions of the Financial Times reflected a new mood: ``The spell is finall broken.'' Since Heseltine announced his candidacy for Conservative leader and prime minister Wednesday, some of Mrs. Thatcher's old friends have defected. The Sunday Times endorsed Heseltine over Mrs. Thatcher, saying voters were ``jaded with her and tired of her ways to an extent that has made her an electoral liability.'' The Times said its decision to go against Mrs. Thatcher was a painful one, but warned: ``If the Tories do not change their leader, the voters are likely to change their government.'' Even some of her supporters have been lukewarm. The Economist magazine endorsed her, but only after saying: ``Mrs. Thatcher, truly a world figure, no longer commands respect where it matters most for Britain: in the European Community. To her fellow EC leaders, she has become a bore, a ranter, nothing more.'' In the Telegraph interview, Mrs. Thatcher said she might hold a referendum on the constitutional issues relating to Britain's role in Europe, an issue which has split her party and threatened her leadership. The debate about how much sovereignty Britain should yield to the European Community is an explosive one for the Conservative Party. Mrs. Thatcher strongly opposes plans by the other 11 community nations for a single currency and what she sees as a federal Europe. Heseltine has argued for a less confrontational British approach in Europe. A Market and Opinion Research International poll for the Sunday Times suggested the Conservatives trailed Labor by 11 percent with Mrs. Thatcher as leader, but jumped to one point ahead of the opposition under Heseltine. The pollsters interviewed 1,059 voters Friday. A Gallup poll of 1,006 adults Thursday and Friday for the conservative Telegraph indicated 63 percent of Conservatives voters believed the party was most likely to win the next election under Heseltine. Only 35 percent said the same of Mrs. Thatcher, who enjoyed less Tory confidence than former deputy prime minister Sir Geoffrey Howe, with 38 percent. Sir Geoffrey, who resigned earlier this month, helped prompt Heseltine's bid when he stood up in the House of Commons and denounced Mrs. Thatcher as a liabilty to Britain's vital interests in Europe. A poll for the Sunday Correspondent by the market research consultants ICM Research suggested the Tories were 12 percent behind Labor if Mrs. Thatcher remains Tory leader. But her party vaulted to 8 percent ahead under Heseltine. The company interviewed 947 voters Friday. Similar results were published in polls for the liberal Observer; the Mail on Sunday and the Independent on Sunday. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd ran well behind Mrs. Thatcher and Heseltine in most of the polls. Hurd discounted speculation he may stand in a second ballot, saying Mrs. Thatcher had his ``full backing.'' No margin of error was given in the polls. It is considered unlikely that Heseltine, who resigned from the Cabinet in 1986, can win outright on Tuesday, but even Mrs. Thatcher's supporters are thinking aloud about what happens if that first ballot is inconclusive. Since nobody knows how the secret vote will go Tuesday, everyone can speculate. Among the possibilities: -Mrs. Thatcher crushes Heseltine on the first ballot and leads the party into the next general election, which must be held by mid-1992. -Mrs. Thatcher wins but Heseltine runs strongly, eroding her authority as leader of the party and the government - the ``nightmare scenario,'' in the words of the pro-Thatcher Daily Telegraph. -Heseltine forces a second ballot, opening the door for other candidates to step forward and putting Mrs. Thatcher under great pressure to quit. A second round of voting, if necessary, would be on Nov. 27, with the possibility of a third round on Nov. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Injuries Reported at Anti-Soviet March in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name of radio station in 2nd and 4th grafs to Radio Vilnius sted Vilnius radio
DOC.TEXT: Red Army soldiers fired warning shots and beat some protesters Saturday to break up an anti-Soviet march outside a military base in Lithuania, news reports said. At least five people were reported injured. The draft-age youths, estimated at 200, chanted anti-Soviet slogans as they marched from Cathedral Square in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, to the military base, Radio Vilnius said. There, they threw down their draft cards, according to the report. The official Tass news agency reported that the protesters chanted ``Soviet army, get away from Lithuania!'' and other similar slogans. The demonstration developed into a scuffle at the gate, Tass said. Tass and Radio Vilnius reported that the Soviet soldiers fired warning shots and used water cannons to disperse the crowd. The Lithuanian report also said the soldiers ``ran out into the street and began to beat the demonstrators'' and local police. Five people sought medical treatment after the clash, the radio report said. Tass confirmed there were injuries but did not say how many. Soviet soldiers reportedly drove through the streets of Vilnius after the protest and fired machine guns, apparently to intimidate residents. The demonstration, organized by the Lithuanian Liberty League and other groups, was held to support Lithuania's claim that it should be participating in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that begins Monday in Paris, both reports said. Lithuania declared independence in March but later froze measures to realize it because of an economic embargo by the Kremlin. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday said Soviet soldiers and their dependents in the Baltics have had their civil rights violated as the republics have asserted their independence from the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to fix overline
Blasts Reported Near Shrine
DOC.TEXT: Explosives apparently set by leftist radicals went off Sunday near the Grand Shrines of Ise, which Emperor Akihito is to visit next week, police said. The blasts caused no injuries and only minor damage at the main train station in Ise, and along the Kinki Nippon Railroad, which Akihito and Empress Michiko will use when they travel to Ise to pray to the sun goddess next Tuesday and Wednesday. A police official who spoke on condition of anonymity said batteries and wiring of the type used in detonators were found near some of the bomb sites. The Ise station is a short walk from the shrines, the most important in Japan's Shinto religion. The shrines are believed to be the home of sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom the emperor is by legend descended. Leftist radicals claimed responsibility for about 40 fires, missile firings and bombings around Tokyo during Akihito's state enthronement ceremony last Monday. The radicals oppose the monarchy as a remnant of Japan's prewar nationalism and have vowed to continue their attacks until after the final enthronement-related ceremony in early December.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Newspaper Workers Go Door to Door for Support
DOC.TEXT: Striking Daily News workers, some accompanied by their children, went door to door Saturday asking people to cancel their subscriptions to the tabloid. ``It's very moving to hear a child tell somebody, `My mom or dad is out of work because of the strike, don't buy the paper,''' said Ray Melville of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 3. About 350 strikers and their supporters fanned out through the New York borough of Queens, knocking o doors and asking subscribers to stop having the Daily News delivered. It was the latest union effort to cripple distribution of the newspaper, which has published every day since the strike began Oct. 25, despite sporadic violence. Some newsstand vendors said they were intimidated into keeping the News off their shelves. The News has hired homeless and unemployed hawkers to peddle the paper on street corners. The News said last week that it was printing 600,000 copies a day and selling about 400,000, down from 1.09 million before the strike. Company officials said 2,000 of its usual 12,000 outlets were selling the newspaper, the nation's third largest metropolitan daily.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Reports Hundreds of Exections in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 6th graf, `In particular ...' to UPDATE with source saying executions had been tallied only since Aug. 5. Picks up7th graf, `The occupation ...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi forces in Kuwait have executed at least 250 people, arbitrarily detained thousands more and are systematically erasing all signs of Kuwaiti culture, a human rights group charged Saturday. About one month after the Aug. 2 invasion, the Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein began a harsh crackdown in response to both armed resistance and peaceful demonstrations in the oil-rich emirate, the watchdog group Middle East Watch said in a report. ``Since then a systemic pattern has emerged of gross abuses,'' the report said. ``Free expression has been muzzled and free assembly banned; and violators are severely punished.'' The author of the 18-page report said that while conditions in Kuwait were grim, they were not as severe as some news reports have portrayed them. ``There have been diplomats and other reports saying there were 7,000 summary executions,'' Aziz Abu Hamad said in an interview. ``We only tracked down 250 such executions. But it is still not a pretty picture and it's getting worse.'' The report tallied only those executions that took place after Aug. 5, three days after the invasion, Hamad said. The availability of food and medical care is rapidly dwindling, Hamad said. More than 5,000 people have been arrested, and of about 3,000 still in detention, 14 percent are under 20 years, he said. The occupation has produced between 300,000 and 400,000 Kuwaiti refugees but the report said that there is no Iraqi policy to replace them with Iraqis. While individuals live in fear and hardship, the invasion has also resulted in the slow erasure of Kuwaiti culture, the report said. ``Iraqi occupation authorities embarked on large-scale, systematic appropriation of the equipment, furniture and archives of Kuwaiti institutions, including hospitals, schools and museums,'' the report said. ``Iraqi troops confiscated valuables from homes during searches and from those fleeing the country,'' it said. Many Kuwaitis are homeless and have little or no access to hospitals, which have all been taken over by the Iraqi military. Many medical personnal have been detained or killed, the report claimed. Hamad, a consultant to Middle East Watch, said he met with more than 200 refugees who have recently fled Kuwait, and conducted about 70 interviews with people who were active in the community and had direct contact with Iraqi forces. Middle East Watch was formed in 1989 to monitor human rights abuses in the Middle East. The interviews took place in several cities in Saudi Arabia, Cairo and New York City during October and early November. Those interviewed included doctors, hospital administrators, civic leaders and academics as well as people who had been detained or have relatives who had been detained or killed. ``They were people who couldn't take the conditions anymore, the abuse, the lack of food, and fled,'' Hamad said. Maltreatment and torture of detainees has been widespread, Hamad said. Reports of sleep deprivation, beatings with sticks and pipes and threats of killing other family members were common among former detainees, he said. ``In addition to crowded and unsanitary conditions, detainees reported being severely beaten with clubs, metal pipes and electric rods,'' the report said. ``Mock executions ... were also reported,'' it said. ``Some detainees were subjected to electric shocks that caused severe pain and bleeding from the mouth, nose and ear.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Drill Tests Emergency Workers
DOC.TEXT: Paramedics, firefighters and even trained dogs got a taste of the Big One as they pulled ``victims'' out of collapsed buildings and crushed cars Saturday during Indiana's largest disaster drill ever. State emergency officials called the earthquake drill a success, saying they would now be better prepared for the real thing. But they admitted no practice event could imitate the stress of a true catastrophe with real victims. ``We can simulate almost everything but personal feelings,'' said Dave Perkins, operations director for the State Emergency Management Agency. ``We can't mimic the emotional stress.'' The exercise attracted more attention than most annual diasaster drills because of a New Mexico scientist's disputed projection of a 50-50 chance for an early December quake along the New Madrid Fault, said Jerome Hauer, the agency's director. The fault runs from Marked Tree, Ark., north to Cairo, Ill., and affects parts of Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Illinois and Kentucky. Earthquake experts have declared Iben Browning's projection meaningless. But Hauer said it has helped focus public attention on the possibility of a Midwest earthquake. During the drill, which involved more than 200 people, rescue workers were tested on their abilities to respond to the devastation that would be caused by an earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale, followed by two strong aftershocks. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A magnitude of 6 or more can cause severe damage in populated areas. The drill provided the state's first test of an innovation for dealing with such disasters. A small airplane flown by the Civil Air Patrol videotaped the disaster scene and relayed pictures to a monitor at the Vanderburgh County Emergency Management Agency. The drill was a bit too realistic for some volunteer ``victims.'' At least three Ivy Tech students suffered symptoms of mild hypothermia after waiting in a chilly basement about four hours to be ``rescued.'' An ambulance took one to a hospital, where he was treated and released, a hospital spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Indonesia to Ban New York Times Reporter
DOC.TEXT: Indonesia is banning an American reporter because of an article the government considers offensive to President Suharto, the national radio said Saturday. ``The article is insulting to the head of state and the nation,'' it quoted Information Minister Harmoko as saying. Harmoko said the New York Times reporter would be prohibited from entering the country. The Nov. 11 Times story, written by Steven Erlanger, said Suharto's children profited from businesses connected with most major government projects, including toll roads. It said Suharto's ability to protect those business interests could affect his decision in 1993 to step down or remain in office for a sixth five-year term. Contacted in BAngkok, Thailand, where he is based, Erlanger said: ``I regret this reaction to my article. I meant no disrespect to President Suharto. I simply reported on an important issue that many Indonesians discuss and discussed with me.'' The government in 1986 banned an Australian journalist after the Sydney Morning Herald published a critical story. The article said Suharto's family and friends had amassed huge personal fortunes. Relations between the two countries soured as a result of the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Tells of Captivity in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: An American who was wounded by Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait and recently allowed to leave contended that Westerners being held by Iraqi forces oppose a full-scale war but would back a military strike against Iraq. Miles Hoffman, 33, of Columbus, told The Atlanta Constitution on Saturday he left the Persian Gulf with his arm fractured by an Iraqi soldier's bullet and the belief that Saddam Hussein is a deranged dictator who deserves to die. ``The man is a ruthless, bloody murderer who killed at 15,'' Hoffman told the newspaper in a telephone interview from London. ``He needs to be taken out, and he needs to be taken out now.'' Hoffman said he was shot in the arm when he was captured in Kuwait on Sept. 5. He was among 174 hostages freed by Iraq on Nov. 9 after talks between Saddam and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. Hoffman, who had worked for as a financial analyst for the Kuwaiti government, said no Western hostages want war in the Middle East, but ``every hostage that I knew wanted an immediate military strike'' against Iraq. Hoffman's comments echoed those made Monday by a caller to a Cleveland, Ohio, television station. The caller said he was among a group of Americans hiding out in Kuwait and said he supported military action against Iraq. Hoffman was to be reunited in Columbus on Sunday with his family and his fiancee, Nikki Murgatroyd of Forton, England. Hoffman said he was held at two strategic sites in Iraq, part of the ``human shield'' used by Saddam to deter attack by U.S.-led multinational forces deployed to the gulf after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said hostages were fed small amounts three times a day, sometimes eating carry-out pizza, chicken, spaghetti, or just a bowl of rice, Hoffman said. Commanders would ``keep most of the money'' allotted for feeding hostages. Hostages whiled away the hours listening to the radio, playing cards or exercising, Hoffman said. Their captors called them guests ``not out of belief, but out of fear,'' Hoffman said. ``Even the doctors I saw would not admit that we were hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Child Awarded $2 Million in Damages for Field Trip Injury
DOC.TEXT: A state judge has awarded more than $2 million to a child injured when an adult-sized metal swing slammed into her hip during a kindergarten field trip. Jennifer Mangel, 7, was injured on May 25, 1988, during a field trip to Parent's Park at Pinecrest State School, a residential school for the mentally retarded. Lee, who heard the case in May without a jury, awarded $2.1 million in damages to Jennifer and $250,000 to her mother, Nancy C. Glanker of Alexandria. Lee found the Rapides Parish School Board and the state Department of Health and Hospitals, which runs Pinecrest, equally at fault for Jennifer's injury and liable for the damages. State attorneys said Friday they would appeal Lee's ruling, saying his findings were erroneous and the damage award was excessive. An attorney for the school board said the board was considering an appeal. ``To date Jennifer's life has been very sad to say the least, but the quality of her future life is even worse ...'' District Judge Robert E. Lee wrote in his opinion, released Wednesday. ``Jennifer has nothing to look forward to but a life of surgery, pain, anxiety, mental anguish.'' A metal glider-type swing weighing about 60 pounds hit Jennifer on her hip when she slipped while pushing a friend. Lee said an expert calculated the swing hit her with about 300 times the force of gravity. The judge said the the children were not adequately supervised and the park was not safe for children. Joseph T. Dalrymple, an attorney for Jennifer and her mother, said the girl has had two operations and will need several more. She also is likely to suffer from severe arthritis and may need a hip replacement when she is in her 30s, he said. She now wears a brace shaped like a metal girdle that keeps her legs spread wide apart to reduce pressure on the hip joint, Dalrymple said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Major Sentenced to 23 Years For Trying to Kill Wife
DOC.TEXT: An Army major was sentenced to 23 years of confinement Saturday for trying to kill his wife by hitting her with a toilet tank lid. Maj. David Schneider, 35, also will forfeit all pay and allowances and be dismissed from the Army. He was sentenced by the same panel of eight officers that found him guilty Friday of attempted murder and two counts of conduct unbecoming an officer, involving perjury and adultery. He had faced a maximum 26-year sentence. Schneider, a West Point graduate, will serve his sentence at the Fort Leavenworth Disciplinary Barracks. He showed no emotion during sentencing. A civilian court in Platte County, Mo., acquitted Schneider earlier this year in another case involving injury to his wife. Schneider was accused of flipping his wife, Deborah, over a hotel balcony railing. She fell eight floors and survived. Mrs. Schneider has since filed for divorce. She has been unable to remember her fall and could not say whether her husband hit her with the toilet lid while she slept in October 1989 at their Fort Leavenworth home. Military prosecutors accused Schneider of having an affair with a woman in California. ``The affair made him want to kill his wife,'' a military prosecutor, Capt. Richard O'Keefe Jr., said in closing arguments Friday. The defense rested its case Thursday without calling Schneider to testify in his own behalf. Both a pathologist and a crime lab examiner testifying for the defense said the toilet lid did not cause Mrs. Schneider's wounds. In the civilian case, prosecutors had alleged that Schneider threw his wife over a Kansas City hotel railing last November. A jury found him innocent after he testified that he was carrying his wife in a romantic gesture, when she arched her back or fidgeted and he accidentally dropped her.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Will Experiment With Customer Christmas Card Lists
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service will experiment with bar codes on Christmas cards sent by 1,900 Ohio customers to speed up delivery of the holiday mail. The volunteers will share their card mailing lists with the Postal Service, which will create bar code labels for the envelopes that can be read by sorting equipment. The experiment will involve postal customers in Akron, Canton, Kent, Ravenna, Wadsworth and Medina. Postal officials hope the bar labels will help move holiday mail faster. Mail with bar labels is sorted by automatic equipment, rather than by hand. The Postal Service expects to use bar codes on 100,000 pieces of holiday mail this year. The Akron-Canton area alone handles 7 million Christmas cards each season. Lou Eberhardt, a spokesman for the Postal Service in Washington, said concerns over postal customers sharing their private mailing lists was a concern, but officials decided privacy would not be jeopardized.

DOC.HEAD: Two Colleges Each Get Nearly $39 Million Gift
DOC.TEXT: An insurance executive's estate donated $38.9 million each to Samford University and Asbury Theological Seminary in Wilmore, Ky. Officials at the schools said it was the largest bequest to a U.S. educational institution since 1986. The gift was made by Ralph Waldo Beeson, a retired executive with Liberty National Life Insurance Co. who died Oct. 15 at age 89. He had given Samford numerous gifts over the last 20 years. ``It is truly a transformational gift that enables us to leapfrog as an institution,'' said Samford President Thomas E. Corts. The gift to Asbury, a 67-year-old independent seminary with about 700 students, will more than double the school's endowment and provide money for a new preaching center, professorial chairs and scholarships, said vice president for advancement Bob Bridges. The bequest is the largest to a U.S. educational institution since the estate of Lilliore Green Rains provided $40 million bequests to Stanford University, Loyola Marymount University, California Institute of Technology and Pomona College in 1986, according to Giving USA, a publication of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. Beeson's bequest also eclipsed the $21.5 gift of Winton M. Blount to the Alabama Shakespeare Theatre, located in Montgomery. Samford is Alabama's largest private college or university and is affiliated with the Alabama Baptist State Convention. The university has an enrollment of 4,164 students from 43 states and 39 nations. A quiet, retiring individual who downplayed his philanthropies, Beeson told friends, ``It's the Lord's money. He gave me the gift of making it. I am not smart enough to make that much money on my own. It's his money, and I am going to give it back to him.''

The Army and Marine Corps are calling an additional 15,092 reservists to active duty because of the Persian Gulf crisis. The latest call-ups announced Friday bring to 51,587 the total number of reservists activated from all military services since President Bush first authorized their use for Operation Desert Shield in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It is now the largest call to active duty for American citizen-soldiers since the Berlin crisis in 1961, when about 150,000 reservists were activated. Also on Friday the Marine Corps said it was preparing to send to the gulf for the first time a tank battalion with M-1A1 tanks, the most modern U.S. battle tank. Marines now in the gulf are equipped with less-powerful M-60 tanks. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The ``Keating Five'' senators struck emotional chords in defense of their integrity as the Senate Ethics Committee gave them their first chance to publicly respond to a special counsel's influence-peddling evidence against them. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., about to begin radiation therapy for prostate cancer, invoked the names of his son and sister Friday and said that with his career nearing an end, ``my cherished reputation'' was on the line in the savings and loan affair. `With all my heart and soul, I want to make very clear ... I engaged in no unethical conduct,'' the 76-year-old Cranston said. ``You know that I broke no law. You know that I broke no Senate rule. You know that I pocketed no money.'' Equally spirited declarations were offered by three of the other four senators: Republican John McCain of Arizona, and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. The fifth senator, Democrat Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, gets his chance to make an opening statement on Monday, when the panel holds its third day of hearings. After he speaks, committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett will begin presenting witnesses and offering evidence. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Donald Trump christened the lavish Taj Mahal casino less than a year ago as the showpiece of his big-bucks empire. Now it's headed for bankruptcy-court protection, though he still will retain control over it. Trump and his Taj Mahal bondholders agreed Friday to a debt restructuring that will temporarily place the plush Atlantic City, N.J., gambling palace under bankruptcy-court protection and give the investors half ownership. The deal was reached more than 12 hours after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment on $675 million in junk bonds used to finance the casino. Some details of the agreement were still to be worked out, but bondholder representatives said it contained several incentives for Trump to improve the performance of the Taj Mahal. But he also could lose control of the casino altogether if it operates more than 15 percent over budget. ---=

International scholars deciphering the Dead Sea Scrolls have chosen a new chief editor, hoping to speed up work on the ancient manuscripts. The incumbent called the move a power play by academic rivals. The scholars appointed Emmanuel Tov to share duties with editor in chief John Strugnell and complete work still unfinished about four decades after the documents' discovery. ``Once you get to a point where a whole generation who has looked forward to getting published are getting older and dying, the level of frustration gets higher,'' said Eugene Ulrich, theology professor at University of Notre Dame. The Dead Sea Scrolls, first discovered in 1947 in a cave in present-day Israel, are considered one of the richest religious libraries ever discovered from the period that gave birth to Christianity and modern Judaism.
